Bottle. Pours golden with nice head. Aroma is floral, honey and alcohol. Flavor is a wonderful blend of honey, floral, malts and booze. A very good beer, but I would expect nothing less from this brewery.

On tap @ HotD. Pours dark reddish amber with thin head. Aroma is sweet candi sugars and light caramel malts. Doesnt taste quite sweet enough to be a barleywine, more of a strong Belgian, dubbel maybe?  Anyway, very rich caramel and rye malts and solid hops balance out the sweetness. Opens up nicely as it warms.

Tap at Hair Of The Dog, Portland - 06/11/12.
Hazed dark amber with a thin white head that soon clears to the edges.
Nose is candied sugars, malt, toffee fudge and a touch of booze.
Tastes of caramel, fudge, toffee, candied sugars and a little booze.
Fullish bodied with soft carbonation.
Was expecting a little more from Fred!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Batch 83, from a trade. Thanks Arthur! Golden with a mega head! Smell is candi sugar, mostly if not only. Taste is fairly sweet with a little bitterness and a lot of alcohol. Flavors of peaches and again candi with still a lot of alcohol. Oily texture with a nice creamy palate from the "just right" carbonation. Oh and it leaves crazy lacing now that its head turned into a kind of alcoholic meringue. Delicious "belgian"!

Murky gold with lots of sediment.  Luscious nose of apricot, basement, dates, and booze.  Medium-Heavy body, with good, lively carbonation.  lightly sour, with very bitter finish.  Very good, but I dont seem to like this one as much as everyone else...

November 1, 2012 bottle compliments of my great trading partner Brett.  Pours a dirty orange with nice head that faded quickly and lacing.  Aroma of caramel, alcohol and hops.  The caramel sweetness seems to ride throughout, a light fruit maybe apricot is there along with a light bitterness.  Finish is a mild dry alcohol and medium to thick bodied.

A cloudy brown beer with orange highlights and a thin off white head. Caramel apples, sweet cream, and baked bread aroma reminds me of Thanksgiving dinner. Green apples and sugar body up front. Alcohol, and hop bite add an astringency to the finish. Respectable and pleasant.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark orange with a large biege head.  Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit, and caramel.  Taste is caramel malt, dark fruit, honey, spice, and alcohol.  Complex and interesting.

Bottle. Hazy orange amber with huge frothy head. Aroma of raisin bread, spicy rye, smells thick sugary. Same sugary raisin, bread, with a touch of citrus but heavy malt and spicy rye finish. Mouthfeel is slick almost creamy with medium carbonation. Overall it's pushing a little too sugary for my taste but the spiciness adds a nice dimension. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 Batch number 78 from 2010.Pours a dark golden, almost amber, color with a huge 3 finger head. Head dissipates slowly. Smells of spicy rye, raisins, sweet sugary presence, some alcohol, a little hint of a citrus fruit quality, lots of malt. Taste is not what I expected. Starts with the the rye, along with a belgiany sweetness and breadyness from the malt. Then I get more of a spicy rye flavor along with more sweetness and some alcohol. Finishes with dark fruit flavors such as raisins and plums, as well as more sweetness. Taste is very much a mess in my opinion with too many sweet qualities. The rye adds a nice complexity, but with the amount of hops added, the bitterness level is too much and is not balanced out by the sweetness. Even after sitting for 2 years, still get some alcohol presence as well as some hop presence. Does have a creamy mouthfeel, but is also very sticky. High medium to full body. Just not my thing.

Not at all what I expected considering it said that it was a golden ale. Certainly more of a barley wine. This was beautiful on the pour. Rich golden color with a sticky creamy big head. Lovely rich vanilla, toffee, candy corn. Great hops to bitter out some of the sweet. Good balance. Long flavors. Excellent beer. Lives up to the hype.

Batch Number 86 poured into a hopfest "wineglass". 2 fingers of head, little lacing. 
Ar: Smells of strong citrus with a bitter malt. Alcohol is a bit noticeable.

Ap: Golden hue with offwhite head, no lacing to see( might be my glass) good amount of trails of carbonations coming up.

Ta: Slightly sweet with a hoppy character.

Pa: oily with a big mouthfeel. finishes with a hoppy delight.

Overall: I jumped the gun on opening this a bunch early, but I still enjoyed It and will probably go out and buy a few more to save for real this time. But a top notch beer is a top notch beer.

The beer pours a orange copper color with a light fluffy head. The nose has wood, sweet cereal, and barley. The pallet is a sweet maltiness, barley, with a little bit of bitterness from the hops followed by wood and finishes with hops bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Batch#79

Poured from 12oz. bottle into Founders snifter.

A: Holy head Batman! I poured extremely slowly because Ive heard about the carbonation issues with HotD brews. Even with this slow tilted pour it produced a 3 finger head that rose slowly to a 4 finger head. It poured a nice dark apricot with yellowed edges. The bubbles flying around underneath the head are crazy. The retention is otherworldly and the lace is thick and heavy along the class.

S: Trying to fight through the head for smells is tough, but Im picking up some nice caramel malts and some toffee. Some nice dark fruits, plums and dates, with a boozy back.

T: What a mix of flavors. The dark toffee and caramel malts are extremely present up front, then give way to those dark fruits I smelled earlier. The heat is more present in the taste and leaves a little trail down the throat. Some smooth bitterness finishes out the beer.

M: Very oily and creamy. Medium bodied. Leaves an oily film that coats the mouth with a nice mild sweetness. The carbonation is present, but not as prickly as I would have imagined.

O: Waiting for the head to die down was worth it. A very good brew. I really enjoyed the mouthfeel and the tastes and smell really blended nicely.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-30-2011

Pours a deep rich brownish copper color with a two finger or so eggshell colored head that settles to a skim and a ring but sticks nicely. Aromas are corn pops, wood, caramel and just a touch of fresh spicy earthy f;oral hay. On the palate it follows the nose perfectly with a honeyed corn pops richness thats clean and focused where a lot of beers that have this flavor profile go wrong. I cant believe how drinkable and clean tis beer is based on its profile and abv. Complexity at its best with great chewy mouthfeel but not a mouth coating syrupy beer.  YUMMY ! Gotta find one to age now.

Internet purchase. Ok, top of the line sticky thick and creamy head here! It looks like SHAVING CREAM! Just the right touch of hues blending into a fabolous medium deep (medium carbs) amber that in one word says "beer." It displays itself as if to be in an advertisment in the glass. Just so creamy. Aromas of big caramel/toffee and twisted with fruity hops. The raisin and fig come out to mingle with the other candylike malts to say they enjoy each others company. All around its a cake like experiance of malty meets hoppy. Man what is up with this flavor! Desert to the extreme! Supper sugary sweet and not in a cloying way, just in a way that says "slow down man, there was a lot of time, energy, and money that went into me so take some time on the ol palate to figure me out, sip by sip." Its just like the nose conveys, malty meets hoppy to the max. Im blasted with raisin, caramel, fig, cake, pine/fruity hops, tinge of alcohol shooting up the nose, and brown sugars. Ok I guess I get a little excited when rating a hair of the dog, but this beer is a powerhouse of flavor and sweetness if it can be appreciated and handled. Highly sweet, leaves just a light bitter, fig like aftertaste, and gives off a medium bitterness that the malts just love to take away from with their sweetness. Great stuff.

Batch 83. First thought.. Beautiful concentration. Aromas of sweet, honeyed rye, caramel and toast. Palate is rich, concentrated and lingering. Flavors of Brûléed sugar, brown sugar, concentrated dried fruits, malt bread and honey. Reminiscent of a quad in style. Rich and concentrated, with a sticky element at tines. Excellent. Full carbonation, with a velvety mouthfeel. Alcohol is not shy, though is in balance with overall concentration. Not cheap, though you get what you pay for.. A quality beer. Best enjoyed as an after dinner, end of the night type beer. Yummy!

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Pours a golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is of caramel, toffee, sweet malts, subtle citrus, spice and grapefruit. The flavor follows the nose and taste kind of like a mix of a Belgian Strong Blond and a Barley Wine, lots of sweet malt and toffee, almost syrupy, some citrus and grapefruit, pine and spice. The body is full with an oily mouth feel. Overall a pretty interesting brew.
On tap at the brewery. Pours golden with a big white head. Smell sweet tangy rye and sugar. Taste is mellow, alcohol well hidden, peppery and some fruit. Good beer.
Draft at tasting room in Portland. Though typically not my favorite style, this was a hell of a beer!  Complex and superbly drinkable.

Bottle @ Akkurat. 2003 vintage. Pours rather clear deep amberish golden with a small fizzy beige head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and intense with sweet dark bread, caramel, leather, prunes, raisins, alcohol, wood, cookie dough, toffee, vanilla fudge and hazelnuts. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter and malty with sweet dark bread, vanilla fudge, creamy toffee, figs, dates, prunes, cookie dough, caramel, wood, alcohol, bourbon-like sweet roasted coconut and vanilla and hints of pine and leather. Mouthfeel is smooth, round, boozy, tiny sticky sweet and full bodied. Finish is slowly sweet, slightly bitter and very tiny sour with caramel, toffee, alcohol, dates, figs, raisins, roasted coconut, pine and vanilla fudge. 9 years old, clearly oxidized but still amazing. My first HotD beer and I cant wait to try more beers from this brewery. Should also mention that I had this with some creme brûlée which not surprisingly was a perfect match.

Deep gold color with 2 finger dense white head.   Aroma is muted with notes of sweet malt and honey.  Flavor is a bit strange.  Nice honey/malty sweetness but maybe overcarbonated, taste is aggressive but not in a good way.  Hard to describe.  Texture is a bit oily

Re-rating this a bit after letting it warm.  Taste is a bit better, buttery, some toffee, pretty solid. Overcarbonation fades with time and an the mouthfeel is very nice.

11/VIII/2012 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ RBBSG - BB: n/a - (2012-877) Thanks to ajax25g for sharing the bottle!
Little cloudy orange beer, creamy off-white head, bit adhesive, stable. Aroma: sweet, huge on the sugar, bit woody, more sugary, bit piny, some exotic fruits, honey. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: pretty fruity, sweet malts, honey and sugar. Aftertaste: sugary, lots of alcohol, fruity, nice bitter hops, dry ending.

Batch 83
Golden colour, white head. Malty aroma, light hoppy, caramel, orange marmelade and raisins. Quite sweet flavour, light bitterness, malt, raisins and hops. Full and very smooth. Finish sweet dried fruits and malt, with a hops touch.
(From 33cL bottle @ RBBSG II, Wilrijk. Courtesy of ajax25g. Thanks Alejandro!)

Batch 86, 2012 bottle thanks to michaelinwa.  Pours a murky dark orange color with very little head.  Complex syrupy aroma of caramel, nuts, cream, and vanilla.  Smells a bit like cake and butter pecan ice cream to me for some reason.  Taste is unusual, almost like melted butter pecan ice cream.  Very interesting though.  Sweetness is not quite overpowered by the strong bitterness in the middle.  Slightly rough finish with an alcohol burn.  Love the flavor but but a bit rough.  I think this beer would be better after sitting a few years.

Bottle@ RBBSG, courtesy of Alejandro. Hazy amber coloured beer with a huge white head. Light malty and short hoppy hinted aroma. Full light creamy palate. Finish is malty light fruity and somewhat alcoholic with a longer stronger, light yeasty vanilla alcholic hoppy touch. Medium.

thx. to Alejandro // 33 cl. bottle sampled @ RBBSG 2012 // batch 83 // hazy orange with a small white head // sweet caramel smell, oranges, marmalade, still full of the american hops which are supposed to go out with age. grapefruit, fruity with some malt // taste is full of bitter american malts, grapefruit, pine, bitter caramel, lots of it, quite fruity as well, honey, apricot, apricot, long bitter hop finish, dash sugar // thick and smooth body, lower carb. // wonder how this one tastes like ones a big chunk of the hop is gone from it
Bottle. Pours a orange color with big white head. Caramel, citrus fruit aroma. Caramel, tangerine, and a touch of alcohol in flavor. Nice barleywine.

Bottle. Pours cloudy orange-amber with a huge creamy off-white head that slowly dissipates with clumpy lacing. Aroma is yeast, caramel malt, grapefruit/citrus, a bit of pine. Flavor is alcoholic from start to finish, medium sweet caramel malts and strong hops backbone with grapefruit and pine strong. Yeast notes apparent. Finish is mildly bitter and alcoholic

35,5 cl bottle batch #77 @ home. Rated on 07.05.2011
Aroma feels like an American Strong Ale with ripe, sweet fruits. Palate is too high on CO2. Flavour is sweet with apricot, some caramel, some raisins and some sugar. Some burning alcohol at the end of the glass. Not bad but I must say that I expected more from this beer.
Sampled at RBBSG. Hazy opaque orange color, full sized off-white head. Smell malts, slightly fruity. Taste malts, a bit sweetish, lightly hops, slightly alcoholic. Medium body, low to medium carbo.

Bottle thanks to Suttree. Dark, cloudy orange-amber with a pillowy cream colored head. Very complex aroma containing apricot, chardonnay,  tropical fruit, raisin, caramel, and honey. If I thought about it enough, that list could potentially get a lot longer. The taste is sweet and lightly boozy and full of raisins and other fruit. Full bodied and a little dry. Nice.

Pour slightly hazy copper, with a large and nicely looking frothy white head.
Aroma has a lot going on. Plenty of hops like apricot, pine and tropical fruits. A whole lot of malts as well, like caramel, slight honey, slight cereal, cookie dough. Also slight perfume, cough drop(?), slight cheesy yeasty stuff as well.. Quite tasty.
Taste is rather sweet, with some hoppy bitter notes as well. Medium body, with a slight fizzy carb.

Almost the perfect beer. Mouthfeel and flavor are practically flawless. Uou get lots of sugar, molasses and especially raisin. One of my favorite BWs. Finally got a taste at Memphis Taproom in Philly. The nose was a very appealing in a room temp pint glass.

Im enjoying this beer tonight by the generosity of drabmuh. Thanks a lot Matt!

A: Fred appears very similar in color to a glass of cherry juice. The beer is pretty hazy. There is about an inch of thick, off-white head that slowly shrinks down to 1/4" and holds steady. Ample lacing can be found around the circumference of the tulip glass.

S: The aroma is quite strong and forward. Sweet malts and alcohol take the lead, followed by some underlying fruit scents.

T: Chewy caramels soaked in alcohol. The heat and/or alcohol are really quite prominent in all aspects of this beer. That being said, I dont find it as bothersome as I usually do. Perhaps its because this is a seriously well crafted beer. All in all, I do feel that the alcoholic intensity prevents this from achieving a higher flavor score, as it really dominates the overall presentation in the nose and palate. A few years (or more) in the cellar could very possibly yield a top-notch American Barleywine. Hmm...

M: Thick and heavy, the liquid creates a warming sensation that starts in your throat and runs down into your chest, similar to a shot of whiskey. If I were outside freezing, and really craving a beer, Fred would be a great choice.

D: I imagine that this beer would have no problem hibernating in my cellar until my son is ready to drink it (hes three). That being said, I thought it was really tasty and enjoyable now, though it packs a punch. This is a great brew to share with some friends, as a few ounces in a snifter would be adequate.
Pours cloudy caramel with a huge tan head. Complex aroma and flavor of caramel, dark fruits and spices. Lightly bitter finish. Awesome stuff.
Tons of molasses, honey, and maple syrup flavors, the alcohol body really balances out the sweetness

Fred is a damned good beer. Aroma of caramel, dark chocolate and sour fruits. Taste is complex and rich with caramel tones that end very sweetly. The flavors improve greatly as it warms. The 10% is well masked. Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

comes on easy like a pilsener with some nice apricot and peach cobbler flavor and texture with sweetness and vanilla. flavor then expodes with cigar and wood and hints of rye and old port wine. finishes up a little spicy and like golden, bright and spritey.

Bottle 12oz. [2008]
Pours very dark golden. Almost no head to speak of. Aroma is of sugar, caramel, madeira, alcohol, malt, dark fruits, bread. Taste is of sugar, caramel, warming alcohol, madeira, figs, dates, raisins, dark fruits, tofee, sligth bitterness. Full bodied. Overall: Not easily drinkable. Impressive taste and aroma. Nnever had that beer before, but I would guess its a its peak. Heavy beer, not for sissies.
Dark amber color, thin white head. Almost syrupy mouth feel. Starts sweet with a hint of pears. Then taste nutty, finishes slightly bitter.

Pours cloudy pale caramel. Aroma: sugar, caramel, dark cherry, alcohol, dates, barley, toffee. Beautiful sugary complexity! Taste is of course very sweet. Well balanced, with slight bitter finish. Full bodied beer. Warming alcohol. Syrupy texture. This beer is heavy so that makes it not easily drinkable. Nevertheless, this is a very impressive one, alothough I must confess I am not really familiar with the barley wines...

Bottle. Cloudy, dark dirty penny colored with a permanent tan head. Complex aroma of figs, cinnamon, scotch, and cloves. The flavor starts out sweet, then there's a pile of unique spices, some leather, and a thick, warming finish. Awesome.

Bottle (12 oz) 2008. Thanks to pushkinwow for this one! Cloudy orange/caramel with no head and no lacing. Aroma is quite complex with dark fruits, madeira, caramel, toffee, barley and alcohol. Quite complex! Taste is sweet with dark fruits, caramel, toffee, dates and madeira. A tad less complex than aroma. Slight bitterness. Mouthfeel is sirupy. No carbonation. Warming alcohol. Very good complex barley wine!

In the glass it had a nice amber color with a huuuuge head. The aroma was sweet with a big malty aroma. Also some cooked raisins. Flavor is big. Chewy with more roasted fruits, maybe figs and apricots. There is a slight bitterness but well balanced. Nice alcohol punch with a long finish.
At the source, it is a sweet and hoppy golden ale with lots of flavor and tasty goodness.  Ill save all the accolades for his big brother the bourbon Fred.  But still very good.

12oz bottle from PDX, batch 85. Hazy amber with a thick, foamy beige head. Aroma of sugar, fruity yeast esters, alcohol and honey. Flavor is sweet sugary malt, alcohol and a light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation. This is a pretty good barley wine, really sugary sweet and fruity. I know this one does well with some age but my last bottle I tried to cellar exploded.

Bottle at home. Poured into my snifter a murky copper color, with an overwhelmingly large off-white head. Smell is big raisin, caramel, plum, toffee, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is caramel, plums, sweet, boozy, grassy, and a medium bitter finish that seems to linger. Light hops, but probably subdued because have been sitting on this one for awhile. Very creamy texture with medium carbonation, could possibly be one of the best bodied beers I have come across. Sweet, yet well-balanced, yet somewhat boozy, I dont know, I cant explain it. All I know is that this is a pretty tasty barleywine.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ brewery pours hazy golden.sweet, hoppy, sweet aroma, sweet, a bit bitter flavor.
120712. Tap at the brewery. Pours hazy orange with no head. Aroma sugar, caramel. Smells like a cask. Low carbonation.

Thick persistent head on a slightly cloudy orange brown.   Nose is sweet caramel and floral hops, become huge honeyed aroma with warmth.  Taste much the same-a bit of spice.  Terrific balance-just delicious.  Wish I had got more of this when I could.  Went well with some black bean and anaheim chili nachos.

poured from tap into pint glass. Pours a dark orange color with a nice head.

Well balanced with nice malty aromas of navel oranges, hops, citrus notes and some spice tones. Good depth to it as well.

Full bodied with a real nice and smooth feel. Good depth of flavor with notes of navel oranges, hops and a good dose of spices as well.

This was really enjoyable. Full bodied and well balanced with no hint of the alcohol at all.
heavy malty aroma,golden, clear, light brown foam,light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice heavy light citrus finish.mums

Murky amber with massive, foamy, off-white head / Dry nose of hops, rye, bread, and citrus / Medium body, lively carbonation, some sweetness but overall dry, malty with excellent hoppy balance, and good, very bitter, finish / Flavors of spicy rye, caramel, dates, grapefruit, pine, and wood / Call it a barleywine, but really a big double rye ipa to compare with the best.  Very astringent, possibly too much so, but works well with big malts.
Murky gold pour with a huge off white head. Aroma is toffee, sweet caramel, dill, dough, fucking raisins. Damn it.  Full on the palate, sweet finish, bursting carbonation, low bitterness. Decent.

Bottle. Pours a golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is of caramel, toffee, sweet malts, subtle citrus, spice and grapefruit. The flavor follows the nose and taste kind of like a mix of a Belgian Strong Blond and a Barley Wine, lots of sweet malt and toffee, almost syrupy, some citrus and grapefruit, pine and spice. The body is full with an oily mouth feel. Overall a pretty interesting brew.

Light brown coloured and almost clear. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is heavy malty, different types of breads, faint caramel, light chocolate and some citrus. Heavy sweet flavor, some notes of grain, moderate bitter, more bread. Soft carbonation.

Bottle pours dark gold with large foamy white head.  Aroma of pine hops.  Taste sweet malts, bread, caramel, nice barleywine sweetness,  Palate full and thick, not syrupy with a little carbonation tingle.  Finish slightly bitter with hops and slight alcohol bite.  Alcohol apparent.
Very well executed barleywine.
On tap at the brewpub.  Pours a golden color with minimal head.  Taste is medium to high sweetness and perfumey fruits with light rye and pale malts.  Pretty nice.
This guy has a bit more of a kick than I had expected, but it is wonderful regardless.  Flavorful, potent, wonderful.

Bottle shared from Bierkoning.  Cloudy amber pour with a big white head.  Aroma of fruit, hops, bread and some alcohol.  Flavour of dark fruit, raisins, caramel.  Sweet with a low bitterness.  Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

33cl bottle courtesy of Kermis.
Thin white head.  Hazy amber pour.  Hoppy taste.  Very nice!
MASSIVE head; bronze colored. Honey, pepper, lemon zest nose; spicy in the manner of Duvel. Wonderful balance between malt and hops. Awesome.

Bottle. Cloudy, deep amber/red liquid with minimal off-white head. Really struggled to build any head at all. Aroma is loaded with lots of dark fruit with notes of raisins, plums, sweet pilsner malt, fruity american hops (only lightly), caramel, bread, biscuits and some port. Really nice and complex. Kind of reminds me of a freeze distilled BW I brewed once. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter with lots of caramel and dark fruit and some light alcohol (not disturbing though). Medium to full bodied with low carbonation and sticky, velvety mouthfeel. Beautifully executed BW with lots of fruity action. Really enjoyed it.
An easy gentle sipper. Pours clear, nice head. Malty, bit boozy but not off-putting. Warming alcohol, hops are there but balanced with the malts.
12oz bottle- Batch # 85...Pour is a dark murky orange..Nose is dark fruits, caramel, spice, hops, pine, toffee..Taste is butterscotch, bread, pine, sweetness, caramel, dark fruits, alcohol..

Bottle. Pours cloudy orange with thick white head that lasts a lifetime. Very nice aroma of deied fruit, hops and malt. Apricots, plum, pears, citrus, hint of tobacco, spicy hops, fat malt. Oily mouthfeel of high viscosity. The thickness is perfectly balanced with bitterness that lingers without biting. Wonderful Old Ale or Barley Wine feeling with fresh hops on top. This beer is really well performed. It bounces around in your mouth and takes several different directions in a short time, but doesn't go to far in any of them. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a golden amber with a paperthin head that sticks around with good lacing throughout the drink. Aroma of sweet malts with caramel up front. Also raisins figs and dates with bitter hops in the back. Taste follows the nose but man is this sweet. Tasty but definitely a sipper. Hops are present but a bit overpowered by the malts. Im glad I tried it and I can respect what they put together but not my personal favorite beer.

Bottle. Murky golden pour with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma is pine hop, bread, sweet sugary candy, and malt. Slick palate yet crisp with carbonation. Taste is rich caramel malt, resin, and sugary sweetness. Quite bitter mid-taste but finishes well balanced.

355ml bottle. Pours out amber with a modicum of head. Aroma has lots of phenolic, smokey and endless caramel notes. Taste is smooth buttery caramel mixed in with pine and fruit from the hops. When I say mixed in I should elaborate: the synergy between malt and hops here is astounding. They work in perfect harmony to create an incredible drinking experience. Neither element overwhelms, but they both contribute to the final product superbly. This big beer went down dangerously easily and left me with a huge grin on my face. Fantastic.

Drank this out of a bottle at DLD, bottle was from 1999. Yeah, 13 years aged. Aroma was subtle, with notes of toffee and a touch of chocolate. I enjoyed this, it was like a candy bar - sweet SKOR. My notes describe this as "amazeballs" which pretty much explained both how I felt that day, and that I should probably stop reviewing beers that day.

Bottle poured into my HOTD tulip glass.

A - Pours deep amber orange with no head at all, only a tiny bit of foam around the edge of the glass, leaving no lace at all down the glass.

S - Smells of caramel, butterscotch, vanilla, fruity yeast, oak and a good amount of alcohol. This one smells really sweet with some booze creeping in at the end of each sniff.

T - Starts off with plenty of sugary sweetness that never really goes away. Hints of fruit, vanilla, oak and some dulled piney hops offer some break from the sweetness but it doesnt last long. Finish is sweet with quite a bit of booze burn, lingering on the palate long after the finish.

M - Smooth body with a ton of sweet flavors and moderately low carbonation, almost none really. There is still quite a bit of booze present in this one.

O - I liked this one but it never really wowd me in any way. The lack of carbonation really didnt help either. I wouldnt turn another down but I wont be running out to get more.

Pours cloudy golden yellow with a white head. Some lacing. Hops, fresh baked bread, citrus and peach on the nose. Taste has fresh malt body with plenty of hops, and notes of grapefruit and some funk. Full bodied. After taste is hoppy and sweet. Well balanced and a great ale.
Goldern colour with a white head. Lots of grapefruit hop aroma and flavour.
Delicious sharp alcohol belgian candy sugar flavor. Very carbonated, but not remotely unpleasant. Superior brew.

Batch 84
Very dark-gold color. 
Hoppy but not so bitter. Nice balance between malts and hops.
Very nice beer.
Bottle looks awesome golden brown fluffy white head. Tastes smells caramel hops maybe bit wood spice grapefruit. Not bad

Cloudy, murky mustard brown with a thick, white head. Subtle, but complex nose of juniper and grapes. Full bodied palate offset a bit with alcoholic heat. Otherwise, cascading layers of grains and fruit. Wonderfully complex.

Bottle to oversized tulip (thanks waltersrj).  Looks good; pours an opaque amber-brown with ample head.  pretty good too; lots of hops, but you can tell its got quite a variety in there.  Tastes great; awesome balance and drinks very easy for being 10%.  Very good beer!

Bottle @ Oliver Twist.
Brownish red with a short yellowed head.
Malty sweet nose with raisins, prunes, caramel and toffee with floral hops.
Sweet malty taste with toffee, raisins, caramel, prunes and some leathery notes.
Big body, soft carbonation, oily.

A - pours nice golden amber with very high white head, leaves a layer of bubbles and lacing. S - aromas of  light hops, golden raisins, dried fruits, bananas. Very quiet aromas. M - strong bodied brew with high carb. Lingering bitter hops and alcohol. T - dried fruits, brown sugar, caramel and fruity malts. Hops and hints of spice. O - interesting spicy strong golden ale. 7

355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20110507.
Pours murky brown color with small head. Aroma of ripe fruits like plums and raisins, mild hops, malts and caramel. Flavor of plums, raisins, caramel malts and wood.
5325

On tap at the brewery.  Nice deep golden color with a thin white head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, a little yeast spicy.  Mouthfeel is massively sweet but not cloying, great malt notes hops are just hiding in the background but keep this beer honest.  Really delicious barley wine.

Batch 69, courtesy of HenrikSoegaard. Clear orange with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, caramel, dried fruit, vinious and alcohol. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. Smooth. This has aged really well. 170312

12 oz bottle; batch 74 next to the new bourbon release clear dark gold with huge egg shell white head fading slowly; the complete opposite from the bourbon one; sugary sweet aromas with pils malt, candy syrup, lots of white sugar, piney hops; boozy and sweet, but enough body to make it work; so much sweet sugary goodness; kind of funny that I havent had Fred for a few years, but I am a total Adam whore; Fred has that same complexity and depth, but just not quite in my wheelhouse flavor wise; doggie claws much preferred too as a more straight and in your face hoppy barleywine

Updated Rating 3/22/09 - 12 oz. bottle, batch 71; pours flat and clear gold; strong, fruity, syrupy, velvet texture; raw, grainy, lemon, sugars are heavy; long, dry, sticky finish; lots of candy malt; i love this stuff, but fresh FFTW has it by a nose

Original Rating 3/25/08 (Overall 4.4) - 12 oz. bottle - a long overdue rating of a beer that would probably be on my short list for a desert island; monster white head spills with fruit aromas that are sweet, malty and slightly sour; appearance is cloudy and light orange; drinks with a mouth full and just pure cream; one of the greats

12oz bottle with no freshness date. The label states that this beer will get better with age, but without a bottled on date, how are we supposed to know how old the beer is!?

Poured a hazy golden-copper color with a head that stood a little less than a finger tall. Foam is off-white and has now settled a thin layer. Pretty good retention. Good amount of carbonation bubbles sticking to the inside wall of the glass.

The aroma is big and malty with a good amount of sweetness. Im also getting a bit of butterscotch.

Big malty body up front followed by an ever bigger sweetness! It almost reminds me a bit of maple syrup. Thankfully, theres a bit of bitterness as this one nears the back end of the palate. Thick and flavorful finish.

Full bodied syrupy mouthfeel. It looks carbonation heavy, but its actually got a very light carbonation.

An interesting strong ale overall.

Moreys Bottom Line: This is like a cross between an English Barleywine and Double Bock. Very thick and very sweet. Its definitely a one and done for me. That being said, its a pleasure to sip on.
bottle shared by wray043. Pours hazy gold with a large white head. Aroma is metalic malty and spicy. Flavor is malty and sugared and finishes with heat.

Pours cloudy copper with a massive white pillowy head. Aroma is of dried fruits, cereals, molasses, and a bit of alcohol.. Inviting. Flavor is along the same lines with a bit more fruity hop character. Finish is fairly sweet and very long lasting. Great beer.

On tap at HOTD Brewery and Taproom. 3-oz. taster. Hazy gold with a nice ring of foam around the edge. Strong fruity (overripe grapes and grapefruit) and alc. aroma with some light cereal, maltiness. Extremely fruity flavors, sweet but with a noticeable hop presence and a touch of pepper (rye?). Heavy, creamy palate and light carbonation. Very long balanced finish. Wow! This is a deceptively gentle but very determined beer.
Thick THICK white head with serious lacing. Fruity aroma and hoppy bite. Better than I expected. Very complex, big beer!

Golden-orange color, topped by a half-inch of creamy tan head that leaves a nice trail on down the glass. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, candy sugar, sweet dark fruit, light fruity hops, and a generous whiff of alcohol. Palate is a delightfully sweet, sticky blend of sweet caramel malt and mildly fruity hops.
Draft Rich Os 2012 Gravity Head. Hazy orange, fine white head. Crusty bread aroma. Sweet dried fruit, and orange.

Bottle, courtesy of yngwie. Batch #69. Pours deep golden with a small off-white head. Aroma of biscuits, malt, caramel, dried fruits, mint, alcohol and spices. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, malt, minty notes, dried fruits,some bitterness and some floral notes. Full body, soft carbonation. Really nice barley wine.

Bottle 355ml (Batch #69) @ yngwie
Pours slightly hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and fruity, floral hops. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medum bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat.

355ml bottle pours an orange golden color with a small white head that leaves very little lacing.  Aroma is fruity with some grainy malts and aromatic hops.  Taste is malty and fruity sweetness with some mild hop bitterness.  A genuine high quality brew which I enjoyed immensely.

bottle purchased at "Ma che siete venuti a fà" in Rome, the beer has a compact and thin layer of foam, smelling of exotic fruit and citrus notes given by the hops, the taste has a rather bitter attack well balanced by notes of sweet malts, the ending is rather resinous with notes of pine and caramel.

19 feb 2012, gold/yellow, faint haze, some bubbles. Kind of yeasty, kind of tart, Belgian gold ale. Med body and fizzy. Bitter, pine hops, light gold ale, mild yeast unless and some fun fruity notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

10-FEB-2012,  bottle @home, from "Barleywine".
Clear brown/orange with no head at all. I try a vigorous pour but still no head.
Nose is sweet malts and a touch of alcohol. Orange peel, caramel, dried fruits like apricots and raisins. Taste is much the same. Ends a little bitter, but just a little. Did I save this for too long? 
Sweet with no carbonation at all.
Really a delicious beer. Would love to try a fresh one as well.

12 oz bottle batch 78. Pours a strong golden color with a creamy white head. Aroma is very zesty citric, tropical fruity, marmalade, apricot and honey. A touch of spice as well. Flavor is much of the same, super strong honey, toffee and a bright citric fruity character. Finishes with a note of alcohol along with a lingering honey and pale malty note. slightly syrupy medium to full body and a soft carbonation. Good beer, I would love varying vintages and especially fresh.

Draft @ HotD.  Pours ano range-amber colour with decent head and nice lace.  Aroma is citrus hops, almost a rye spiciness and syrup on the nose.  Taste is quite sweet, with citrus zest and some more of the spice I got on the nose.  Good, but a tad too sweet and syrupy for me.

Had on tap at Hair of the Dog in Portland.  Honestly one of the best beers Ive had.  The color is deceiving.  A bit cloudy and more beige than amber.  Not a barley wine as classified here on RB, but a damn fine beer.  If they had it available in bottles when I was there I would have bought a case!

12 oz into sniffer.  Looks unfiltered pale apricot.  1 finger thick off white head.  Smells of wood alc strong pale malts.  Tastes of even more alc along with orange tart sweet wood.  Heavy on my palate and beautiful.  Overall 9 of 10.

Bottle. Gold with thick white head that dissipates to thin head that retains. Aroma is honey and sweet fruits. Flavor is unique and hard to describe: sweet (pears?), a bit of funk, and a long sweet honey finish. Very nice.
Hazy ciderish pour, white head.  Creamy sweet and bitter, delicious and unlike anything Ive had before.

Received in a trade with P1meatloaf
Batch 84
Pours a hazy golden yellow with a huge white fluffy head.
Smells yeasty, fruity - apricot, sweet, and a nice hop aroma as well.
Taste has a nice maltiness to it with the rye not overpowering, but complimenting. It has a nice fruitiness to it as well, and it is all balanced with a good hop bitterness since this a a fairly fresh batch. 
This is a great beer that is very unique.
Honestly, unreal. I could not believe how amazing this was. Pours perfect. Exceptional head. Creamy and perfect. Love the bottle conditioning. Great aroma. Perfectly balanced.
Bottle. Pours green (okay, that was probably my glass) with a thick white head. Medium bitter, heavy sweet. Creamy texture. Finishes awesome.

Pours like a cloudy apple cider . Aroma is quite different ....almost like sweet apples....fruity and citrusy. Flavor is quite complex, sweet and hoppy. Nice finish, short and slightly bitter. Nice barley wine, alcohol nicely masked. Worth trying ! Cheers !
Pours a hazy golden with a thin white head and a sweet aroma of hops. Taste is complex, flavors of hops and fruits with a bitter finish. Flavorful and good barley wine.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on December 20th, 2011.
Appearance:Pours a medium cloudy brown with light white head.
Aroma:Aroma is of malt, bread and somethign sweet..
Taste:Light bitterness, strong bready malt, and some fruit.
Palate:Medium body, some carbonation but not too much.
Summary: This was different for a barley wine, and interesting.
Very nice looking, pale head. Sharp, hoppy smell, good balance of bittering hops and maltiness in the flavor. Quite smooth and the bitterness doesnt linger into the aftertaste. Excellent!

Not like any barleywine that Ive ever had, and very good.  Pours with substantially more carbonation than any barleywine Ive seen and a big white foamy head...like a saison.  once it settles its very much barleywine though, think, sweet, but not overly so.  Palate starts as bright fruit - pears and apples, and a sweet statisfying finish.  Its a little thick but not syrupy.  You also do get some of the hops throughout, which provides a nice balance.

Aroma- wheat, hay, funk, monster malts, hops, resin
Appearance- hazy orange, big white head, lacing to the max
Taste- malt bomb, funk, hop madness, mild citrus flavors, spiciness, other such complexities 
Palate- syrupy sweet, medium carbonation, thick and creamy
Overall- A novelty beer for the most part IMO.  Sort of reminds me of 120 but more complex and slightly more cloying.  It has a great base but perhaps takes it a bit far.  Mysterious and fun but slightly overrated.
This was good.  Thinner than I was expecting but about what youd anticipate once you see the hue of her.  Nice CO2, well balanced, awesome brew.

Bottle thanks to thome50.  Deep gold/pale amber and hazy with creamy head.  Citrus/pine/grapefruit hops, sweet and fragrant, with a hint of refined caramel malt.  Flavor is citrusy with grapefruit hops and a decent amount of the sticky, sweet malt.  Lightly dry with a trailing hop bitterness.  Pretty much a solid DIPA-type brew with a solid maltiness.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours brownish-copper with a lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of caramel, rye, some cereal, plus a lot of hops.  Flavor strong of both the malts and hops.  Thick texture.  A great beer.

12oz bottle, split into Danish samples.  This is certainly World Class.  Quite hop forward, still displays some grapefruit tones which I find uncommon in a beer of such strength.  Clean and very drinkable while being bold filled with citrus and pine tones as well.

Batch 78 bottle pours clear orange into a snifter.  There is a one finger white head perched on top.  Aromas are sweet citrus and very hoppy.  Taste is barleywine like, but more citrus and finish is not overly hoppy.  Resinous overtones with sweet citrus is mostly what I get.  I was thinking the rye might stand out more, it is present, but not dominant.  Palate is full, average carbonation, excellent lace all down the glass.  No real alcohol warmth, as I was expecting.  Pretty smooth brew for how heavy it is.  Overall, not really a barleywine, but has some BW notes.  A very tasty brew.

Pours opaque orange with a massive head that leaves behind a lot of lacing. Aroma is hops, pineapple with a touch of spruce. Quite sweet on the palate with a surprising bitter hoppy finish. Taste is caramel, tropical fruits, grapefruit.
It is floral with good hops. I do not usually like hoppy beers because they usually leave a bitter after taste in my mouth. This was not the case. Fine beer.

12 oz.  Batch 83.  Golden pour with tons of fluffy white head.  Retention is phenomenal.  One of the best looking beers I have seen.  Nose is complex with citrus, malt, hops, bready yeast, and maybe honey.  Taste is very sweet and malty with some nice front and back end hop bitterness.  Great mouthfeel.  Really good.  Glad this one is available anytime I want it.

Pours a beautiful ruby amber color with a very small white head. Aroma has a lot of old-age. Thick notes of oak, caramelized sugar, syrup, figs, raisins and candy attack the nostrils tantalizingly. Taste is extremely malty. Big on the burnt sugar and deep, dark caramel. Almost roasted with notes of cinnamon and vanilla in the fiiish. Also some tea-like notes in the beginning. Slightly oxidized but not at all disturbingly so.

1.5 Liter bottle
This beer had lots of toffee/sugary notes and fruity alcohol tones. It is one of the best Barley Wines that I have had.

bottle from ölkonsortiet cons 20111102 Göteborg
ar: vinos, prunes, dadel, 
ap: ruby, 1 cm thick of white stouty head
f: warming, sticky, thick, vinos, peppery, great bitterness, wee carbonatinon

Bouteille de 12oz. Merci Patrick et JB84. Batch 82. Surprenant demblée par sa couleur dorée-miel et sa mousse blanche ce barley wine est toute une découverte. Le nez est un mélange de fruits, de fleurs blanches, de miel de trèfles et de sucre. La bouche est très expressive avec ses saveurs amères de houblons puissants. Le sucre est bien présent. Un produit distinctif.

(Courtoisie de JB84)  Batch 82.  Le liquide a une robe dorée passablement embrouillée.  La tête mousseuse est durable.  Au nez, les houblons sont vivants et se choquent à des effluves de sucre candi et de miel.  Les notes fruitées explosent, le caramel se définit davantage.  Les saveurs suivent les parfums.  Les houblons font un fabuleux travail : ils sont bien goûteux et justement mordants.  Les fruits sexpriment fortement : les papilles sont heureuses.  La base maltée est complexe et apaisante, principalement goûteuse en caramel.  En bouche, le liquide est moyennement rond avec une effervescence faible et une texture huileuse.  La finale est légèrement chaude et portée par des houblons frais et parfumés.  Sans aucun doute une bouteille fraîche.  La prochaine ira à la chambre froide pour quelque temps.

Bottle provided by FullObs...Thanks a bunch!... it pours very hazy amber with medium white head.... the aroma is hoppy, malty with notes of caramel.....the flavor is sooo nice very malty barley wine and nice caramel taste... nice mouthfeel sweet and caramels.... hoppy and bitter finish....

12 oz bottle. Batch # 82. My golly this beer has a huge head. Giant, white, pillowy, and lacy--hangs around forever. After it recedes a bit, it looks like an ice cream float. Has a golden hue with a light haze. Aroma is fruity. It doesnt have an overripe fruit nose like a lot of barleywines have, though. Its more appetizing than that. Has a bit of a Belgian funk going on. Its also a little bready. Taste is like liquid candy skating across the tongue before a wave of bitterness comes along to balance things out. Alcohol is very noticeable, but its not detrimental to the overall effect of the beer. Tastes nothing like any barleywine Ive ever had. It tastes like a lot of imperial pilsners out there (yes, I know its an ale). I think its its own beast--a completely unique beer not chained down to any one particular style. The body on this thing is huge; has a creamy mouthfeel and medium-soft carbonation. Lip-smacking good. One of the best beers Ive ever had, hands down. I wish it was bottled in a 750 ml bottle--I want more!

Bottle from Whole Foods store, Bowery, New York, NY. (Batch 81) A dark orange/golden coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Sweet, fruity, yeasty Belgian aroma. Tastes sweet, malty, caramel, hint of vanilla, slight bitterness. Rich, boozy and warming. This barley wine is a class act indeed. Lovely stuff.

Bottle - Batch #84. Have also had Batch #s 81 and 82. These are great beers. The complexity is amazing and grows as the beer warms up. Well balanced between a sweet begining and a dry bitter finish. A little boozy, but that is to be expected.

12 oz. bottle- Pours deep golden (barleywine?) with a huge head, pour this one slowly, seriously 90% foam, and a thick foamy blanket of lace, nice looking beer. The aroma is pretty funky and tart, does this have brett in it? I also detect sweet grapefruit and candy sugar in the aroma. The taste is at first very Belgian, yeast, sugary, but after the swallow the hops take hold, very bitter and piney, unique beer. The alcohol is a little more present than I would like, It kind of leaves a burn on the tongue. Body is thick, carbonation is high. Overall I really liked this beer, unique, is it a Belgian ale, is it a barleywine, is it an American strong ale, I think you could classify this as any one of them. The aroma I did like slightly better than the taste, just because of the alcohol presence, but I couldnt quite give it a 7 in the taste department, I wish I could have given it a 7.5. Halfway through my totally changes on the flavor, the alcohol although still present, has mellowed, and this beer just gets more complex as it warms, I am going to raise my overall from a 16 to an 18, great beer!

Pours an opaque orange/gold color with a gigantic foamy tan head...outstanding retention and lacing.  Aroma has some slight funk to it...also citrus, spicy notes, and some earthiness...a bit floral.  Flavor has sweet citrusy grapefruit, earthy rye notes, nice hoppy spice, and just a touch of tart funkiness.  Mouthfeel is super lively...silky...and just a bit sticky and the finish is hoppy and leathery...warming.  Very unique and tasty barleywine.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2014 36cl, Batch 87, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, sweet/bitter and slightly alcoholic/fruity, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, rocky head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Flaska från Khiosk. Riktigt rejäla söta dofter och smaker av honung, vanilj, fikon, torkad frukt, karamell och sirap. Alkoholen värmer, liten beska men nästan ingen humle alls. Riktigt gott men i sötaste laget.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2015 Pre festival beer shared at a hotelroom. Pours orange amber with a very tiny head. Aroma is burnt caramel, sweet sugary malts, figs, syrup, ripe sweet fruit, spicy and some oxidation, Taste is burnt sugar, caramel, spice is here aswell, light chocolate, figs, vanilla, a tiny minty note, some dryness and cinnamon.

Bottle at the Hotel in the middle of nowhere in Germany the night before Borefts Beer Festival. Brought by RasmusOtt. Batch 69. Pours really nice light chestnut, but has no head. Aroma has caramel and sherry notes up front, clear signs of oxidation, figs, burned sugar, cinnamon and dark muscovado sugar. Taste has caramel up front, figs and oxidation notes, has a "darker" malt taste with burned sugar, dark caramel and cocoa notes, a hint of cinnamon and weak bitterness. Its definitely past its prime, though still very enjoyable. Would love to try it fresh.

Bottle 33cl from Papsoe thanks a lot, a cloudy amber beer with low head. Nose is very hopy and agrume like. Aroma is very sweet, agrume like, notes of dry fruit like grapes, apricot, some resin notes, very syrupy, caramel, some bitterness and acidity. Not bad but too sweet.

clear amber, small white head, ok retention, crazy lacing... some mild spicing, light yeastiness, yeasty, sweet malts minimal hops.. spicy, sweet, very sweet, very complex, lightly boozy, sweetness dominates, muddles the flavor, though its awesome... lively, dry finish, medium body, spicy finish, rye comes through... flavors pop as it warms...

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 Pours a light amber; lighter than I would expect for such a big beer. Overwhelming character is sweet malt with ripe banana and some peach flavor, very well balanced with bitterness, which is needed for such a sweet beer. I like this, but it is thick and sweet, so half a bottle is about right for me. A good aging candidate simply because there is so much flavor here that a few years or more could mellow it an make it even more interesting and drinkable.

Update 11/2012: Sampled a bottle that spent about nearly 2 years in my cellar. Now a much different beer. Both the sweetness and the hop bitterness are down. No longer what I would call an over the top beer. Although not terribly interesting and not very complex, it also is not a simple, sweet brew. Taste reminds of of sweet peaches, with just about the right amount of hop bitterness. Whereas I was previously not interested in cellaring more of this, I think I now will.

UPDATE 5/2014: Bottle at 3 years. Pour medium golden, big, lasting head. Mild aroma of malt and background of hops; not very interesting. Flavor is still sweet malt with some balancing hop bitterness. Pretty balanced. Moderately complex. Has subtle ripe fruit notes. Aging well, though not changing all that much.

Pale golden orange pour thin off white/beige head light sticky lacing .... aroma of chewy caramel malts and belgian candi sugar and some citrusy funky hops light pine .... taste is very sweet and sugary with a chewy caramel malt, faded/aged citrus hops and a bitter/sugary punch on the tongue that flows into the finish .... good stuff a bit too sugary but it covers the abv well

Drank at the tasting room. Okay lets be honest... for a 10% ABV in a Belgian golden I expect the candi sugar to dominate, drying out the pallet and turning a strong beer into a lighter beer with a slight malt background and a yeast flavor to dominate the flavor. All that I could think about by drinking this beer was how thick and heavy it is. If I drank this through a straw it would take effort to suck it through the straw. This is not an easy to drink beer. Yes the flavors are very complex and nice, but it takes effort to finish the gorgeous tulip glass it came in. My friend agreed, and then the couple to my side also agreed, offering us some of their beer if we would like it. I gave it a 2.7 because yeah it is a very tasty beer but if Im trying to kick back a few beers and hang out with friends this wouldnt be my first choice.

Pours a golden honey color with a fluffy white head that lingers. The rye malts and mix of hops blend nicely in the nose and the taste. I have used this beer as a gateway beer for those who "dont like barley wines".
Clear orange color with with a thin white head. Sweet malty aroma. Taste is good despite there is a little taste of stale beer and plenty of residual sweetness
At hotd with Carla. Pours a hazy orange/gold with white foam. Smells like a barleywine. Tastes sweet and lightly sour with hints of coriander and ends very bitter with alcohol.

Bottle, 
this beer had a clear copper (orange & red) pour with a ton of lively carbonation that made a huge head of faint off-white bubbles that filled the large tulip glass and was well preserved (cover filled the glass and stayed that way), it was fluffy, and left lots of lacing on the glass as I drank, the glass had some haze but I could see lots of streaming bubbles, there was a dark layer of sediment that covered the bottom of the bottled, 

the aromas were light and dark fruit - light and dark raisin with prune and floral hops, light caramel, some bread malt, and brown sugar sweetness on the nose (letting this beer warm up opened up the aromas), 

there were flavors of light and dark dried fruit  raisin and prune, faint caramel, molasses and brown sugar sweetness in this beer, 
the hops gave a good bitterness that complements the sweetness, and there was some sourness on the palate that gave balance to this drink, 

the mouth feel was thicker than medium but felt light for a 10% alc. beer, this was nice on the palate, there was a touch of alcohol warmth on the palate, 

this beer did not feel like a 10.0% alc., and had the best presentation I have ever experienced with a Barley Wine style beer, 
I was surprised how much carbonation this beer had, I thought the sourness and barley wine flavors worked together well, a nice enjoyable Barley Wine.
Most complex and exuberant flavor for any blonde/golden ale. Interesting thick with fruitiness

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Pinocchios.  It pours a hazy amber color with a thin off white head.  The nose is potent and hits you as you open the bottle.  Fruity at first with dark caramel, dough, and alcohol notes on further inspection.  Very smooth and rich on the palate.  Tons of flavor.  White raisin, caramel, brown sugar, a little chocolate, and warming alcohol on the back end.  Some hop presence but no real bitterness.  Perhaps a touch on the sweet and hot side but still worth seeking out.  I would love to age a few of these.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Bottle @ bros house from Bottleworks. Cloudy, yellow orange appearance with a lively, orangish white head. Big golden pils aroma and lots of german hops in the nose with a slight tangy, spicy quality. Quite strong, quite sweet, pils, fairly soapy, floral hoppy flavor with a strong German hoppy presence. Quite floral hoppy.

On tap @ Pizza Port San Clamente (2008 vintage).
Clear copper brew with a good amount of off-white head.  Nose is extremely malty with lots of caramel and toffee, nice pine hops as well.  Very sticky mouthfeel with tons of malt and resiny hops.  Very nice Barley Wine and extra cool that it was the 08 vintage.

Batch number 81.
A- Extremely carbonated, I did what the bottle said and poured slowly, a lot of good that did,  4 finger frothy white head that does not dissipate, once you get passed that this is a nice looking beer, nice lacing on the sides, clear bubbly appearance, golden yellow color.
S- The aroma is nice, sweet, malts, some citrus notes, spice, and caramel. 
T- Big spice flavors coming out, sweet, some breadiness from the malts, interesting beer, some caramel and toffee comes out as well. 
M- Light/Medium mouth feel, extremely carbonated, smooth and refreshing.
O- I had to wait a while for the head to settle which it never did, so I had to work my way through the foam before I could enjoy the beer. Overall pretty tasty, easy drinkability, the alcohol is present but does not take away from the experience.

On tap at Hair of the Dog tasting room, pours pale cloudy orange with small white lacing. Aroma of oranges, peaches, tropical fruits and a light hint of cherry. Flavour of tropical fruits, nice malt sweetness and a light hop finish. Fruity, bright, medium complexity.

Great beer overall. I was not expecting the balance that this beer has. My bottled poured rather vigorously, probably due to the bottle conditioning. It tasted very malty with the sweet candy sugar creating a good balance of flavor. It is a very interesting approach to a beer. It is very rich tasting. I will be getting a few more bottles.

pours a light brown. aroma is toffee, nice hop balance, and caramel. taste is caramel, toffee malts, raisins and a hint of chocolate. palate is smooth with a medium mouthfeel. a pretty decent barley wine but not the best.

Batch 79: The nightcap. Pours dark gold to amber without much of a head. Complex (aggressive?) aroma laden with dark fruit. Very sweet, but with a blast of hops on the back end attempting to tame the complex malt. Palate is thick and delicious. Remarkable. I thought about trying to age it but that didnt happen...glad I didnt wait, really, because it was damned awesome.

Bottle batch 81, an unexpected and very welcome surprise from Jeff.  Thanks a ton!  Nice slightly hazy dark golden pour, with a nice lasting white head.  Decent, slightly chunky lacing.  Aroma of toffee, nice white fruit, mostly apricots, sweet caramelized sugar. A bit of vanilla.  Some slight hops, but not much...leafy, but not vegetable  .  Taste is amazing...nice sweet vanilla cream, very slightly caramelized sugars, nice pine, floral, and citrus hops.  Dry finish.  Great, great beer.

0.33l bottle courtesy of and shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a murky plumjucie colored body with lots of big beige sediments and some big black floaters. Fred has no head the poor little thing... The aroma has tons of caramel, distinct alcohol, yeast, butter and a slightly sour tone. Its quite full-bodied, has soft carbonation and a near sticky mouthfeeling. Flavors are also quite sweet with lots of caramel and some butter. Theres also a little alcohol but its quite well hidden compared to the aroma. Some chocolate notes, woody hints, brown sugar, honey and it ends in a really strong and longlasting syrup aftertaste. Have one more bottle Im saving. Looking forward to that :-)

Bottle. Batch 67. Poured a clear dark orange color. The head was off white and two fingers high. Smelled of cotton candy, perfume-like alcohol, buttery caramel, and toffee. Medium bodied and sweet with a warming alcohol effect and moderate bitterness, particularly at the end. I tasted resiny/earthy hop, citrus liqueur, apricot, vanilla, and toffee.

Bottle. Pours a dark apricot orange with dense cream coloured head. Brilliant aromas of peaches honey and sweet malt. Brilliant. Flavours are relatively sweet with some fruitiness and malt showing through, Hops come through at the finish as does the alcohol. Amazing mouthfeel. Full and very sticky. Great beer.
Pours hazy golden with a off white head. Aroma is fruity and malty. Flavor is malty and boozy. Good carbonation and lacing. Overall a very good beer.

12oz bottle 2008. Golden orange with an off-white limited head. Grape, sweet malts, toffee, plum and raisins - great aged barley wine aroma! Boozy and sweet taste, nice carbonation, peat and tabacco with some heat. Very tasty - needs some age on it though.

Dedicated to Paul Clarkew.

Pours a light golden orange. Aroma is slightly sweet malt with some Belgian candi sugar aromas. Flavor is really boozy and malty with a nice hop finish. Moderate amount of bitterness. Really interesting beer. Lots of depth and character. Fantastic.

(rating 1337) bottle shared by Trevor, I think - Usually not a big fan of barleywines, so consider this as a ringing endorsement. Great malt:hop balance, doughy and toffee malts, raisins and a hint of chocolate. hops are pine and spice with a well integrated bitterness. Finishes with warm booze.
Draft at the source. Hazy golden color, solid white head, solid curtain of lacing. Aroma of pine and light toast. Taste of cinnon toast. Very nice.

A: A very nice golden orange color with a small white that recedes quickly. Nicely carbonated.

S: Smells very sweet, I am getting hops and honey or maybe sugar.

T: Sweet just like the smell, with some hops on the back of the tongue.

M: A bit coating but not too much. Very nice.

O: This is pretty good. I was expecting something different but this definitely didnt let me down.

Sampled blind at Blue Palms Ultimate Brown Bag event.  Think this either is a weird Fred strain or something went wrong but not undrinkable.  fruity and sour smell.  apple cider taste all the way through.  Yeasty bread aroma.  WIll have to re-sample at another point to compare.

Bottle from Plan B, Copenhagen, shared with Palme. Murky light brown body, no head. Looks more like vegetable broth than beer. Nose is subtle tones of sour lactic yeast and wooden barley wine-like notes; tart caramel if that makes any sense at all? :-P Taste is caramel, wood and resinous hops. Sweet up front, then a resinous bitter hop finish settle in. An OK barley wine but a bit weird and seems kinda "off". Did I get a bad bottle?
Amber pour with light off white head and lace. Aroma is raisins and sweet malt. Flavor of dried fruit, sweet molasses, and a nice finishing bitter. Medium/full bodied with good carbonation. Batch 65

Really nice fruity, malty aroma.  Caramel, grains, pleasant sweetness, some alcohol, floral hop aromatics.
Pours a dark golden to light amber color, pretty hazy from the yest sediment, massive off-white head with crazy retention.  Head persists for a really long time, basically through the whole drink, lots of clumpy lacing.
Flavor is strong malt character, caramel, moderately sweet, bready malt, a bit toasty, good deal of fruit character, pear and sweet grapes.  Some hop bitterness and flavor, nice warming alcohol.
Full body with medium carbonation, smooth on the palate, a bit of tingle from the alcohol.  Great brew, lots going on and very tasty.

850th rating. Orange-amber coloured beer. Head should be a bit bigger, but holds pretty decent and sticks nice to the glass. Hoppy, more hops then expected, specially at the smell. But also the sweetness kicks in pretty good at the taste. Malts, caramel and fruity, good fruity. Light biterness at the end. The mouthfeel is prettty good, but a bit more carbonation should to the trick for me. Good beer for sure.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass (leaving most of the yeast in the bottle).Appearance: Beautiful shade of dark amber/orange. Definitely hazy. Forms a surprisingly large, white, frothy head which retains and laces very well for such a potent beer.Smell: Non-citrus tropical fruits, flowers and Fruity Pebbles cereal. Very light and perfumey.Taste: I wasnt sure what to expect with this beer. The bottle describes it as a "special golden ale" which lead to believe it would be something like a Duvel, only stronger. As soon as it hit my palate I knew it definitely wasnt in the Belgian strong pale ale category. Fred is like drinking thinner, carbonated honey. It is extremely sweet with notes of vanilla, spiced rum, and plenty of hops. It begins with noticeable bitterness, but nothing too absurd. The middle and second half are rich and sweet like syrup and honey and the finish contains a strong alcoholic presence. Between the rich sweetness and bitterness, this beer definitely lingers and dries out the palate. Fred is definitely a very robust beer, but its not a delicious one. Sure, the sweetness is appealing, but its cloying, especially as it warms. An acquired taste this beer is.Mouthfeel: Thick, soft, and sticky with a strong aftertaste of dry bitterness and syrupy sweetness.Drinkability: Straight out of the fridge, this beer isnt exactly quaffable, nor is it a sipper. Its right there in the middle. As it warms and the palate begins to wear down the taste buds and it does becoming difficult to drink in more than a sip at a time. The 10% ABV is very prominent in both the taste and the potency. Overall, a strange beer, but a good one. Not what I would consider a barley wine (as classified by Rate Beer and Beer Advocate), but its hard to peg it down as anything else. I liked it, but one is good enough for me.

330 ml bottle. Batch #77.
Pours a slightly hazy orange colour with a large foamy white head with good retention. Aroma of tropical fruits, raisins and caramel. Flavour of sweet caramel malts, tropical fruits, syrup, mild coriander and some alcohol. Medium/full bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel and a warming alcohol finish with some fruits. Pleasant.

Golden with a rocky white head and good lacing.  Lots of caramel candy and grain in a big mouthfeel segues to a solid hoppiness that stays just below the surface.  Excellent fullness, tasty, a little hoppy, and warm alcohol finsih.  Very fine selection.

Same bottle as pictured. Poured light gold with small head that retained. Similar yeast flavours as in Adam. I liked this one a little better as it hd a lighter palate. Id like to give this another try.
Bottle as pictured, poured a hazy white to almost red colour, flavour was a bit sweet and quite tart. It had a nice lacing and it had notes of dark and heavy fruits. overall not bad.

Nightcap at home served in a snifter. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a thick creamy white head. Had to let it settle for a bit before drinking it. Aroma is floral hops, honey, dark fruits, and sweet maltiness. Flavor is huge! Much of the same as the aroma, with loads of hops behind a heavy malt backbone. Nice sweetness in the forefront and bitter towards the finish.Great mouthfeel, very drinkable. HOTD is quickly becoming my favorite brewery :-) Outstanding!

Bottle. Hazy golden with a large, creamy white head leaving a lot of lacing. Aroma: pineapple juice, toffee, honey, light spiciness. Taste: large, sweet maltiness, licorice, dried fruit (perhaps apricot), pineapples, honey, candy, floral, medium bitter. Full-bodied, soft and moussy. Warming and tasty.

POurs hazy orange with a somewhat offwhite head.  Aroma is earthyness, caramel, citrus and grassyness.  Taste is sweet with the caramel and hops coming together nicely.  The alcohol provides some warming on the finish,  Medium to thick mouthfeel.

Reviewed from notes.

Served in a snifter. The initial pour is a moderately-dark dark with a bit of a reddish hue. The nose is quite nice, bringing forward some green apples, light hops, caramel, spice, and a bit of general malty sweetness.

The taste mimics the nose to a large extent, though some of the darker, more fruity flavors take over just a bit. Mild green apple skin the background. Nice touch of caramel and light brown sugar. Good feel with a nice body and a hint of booze in the finish. Drinks quite well and is another solid brew from a brewery that just cant seem to miss.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010

Clear (with sediment) gold pour with a thick, white, stiff head which fades slowly to leave a moderate, coarse lace. Nose is yeasty dough. Body is heavy and smooth, with a nutty, fruity, light sweetness that leads into a finish that is candy-sweet, alcoholic and citrus hoppy. This is more of a strong golden ale or even a tripel to me, so its difficult to compare to barleywines. Not a session beer, or even a regular selection, but great for special occasions and group tastings.

Bottle, tfs Vaiz! Aroma is very fruity hoppy, smooth malty note.
Flavour is quite sweet at first, then a load of different hops, then back to sugar followed by alcohol. Then spicy hops. Awesome.

Bottle at home. Slightly hazy golden pour, thick creamy white head. Aroma of floral hops, some pine, German pilsener hops, fruits and more hops. Flavor is very very intense, loads of hops, very thick malt backbone, sweet and bitter in an extremely nice balance. Hugely thick body, great mouthfeel. Amazing brew.
Bottle. Slightly hazy golden/orange with small tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, sweet, bitter, hops, toffee and fruit.

Copper body, white head. Some haziness. Arom of lots of hops, some yeast, nice malty profile, raisins, some pines, slightly herbal. Flavour has fruits, sugar, malts, really well balanced hops. Very smooth and perfectly balanced. Somehow this has almost every flavour that is imaginable in "golden special ale". Not the same kind of special that your mom means.

12 oz bottle shared by Drew. Thanks! Batch 58 - 2005? Pours a rich amber hue, good sunset glow, well hazed, lighter golden edges with small frothy offwhite head. Dies to a ring, laces small. Aromas are sweet caramel, toffee, with good florals, touches of pear and apple fruit. Touches of cider spice, sweet malts. Initial is sweet, medium bodied with sweet toffee, bready malts. Touches of spice, light yeastiness, with touches of warming alcohol. Sweet malts, golden bread, doughy malts. Sweet and warming but not an overbearing sweetness. Nice, warming, a touch of sherry like oxidation but nothing that gets too cardboardy. Nice. Would be nice to compare against a new batch and see the differences.

Bottle, which I picked up in Regina, Saskatchewan at the Bushwakkers Brewpub. Apparently this had been on the shelf for over a month with no-one interested in it. WTF is WRONG with you Saskatchewan?!?!? Pours hazy golden, with a strong tawny hue. Nice thick, creamy head, retarded lacing. Nose is big and smells creamy/spicy, loads of fruit esters, along with a ton of hop pre3sence, and toffee, along with hints of fudge, creme caramel, cashew, walnut, and an overall richness that is difficult to express. Smells like hedonism. Flavours of rich cereal grains, nice fruit, some brandy, nice overall banana/citrus/ marshmallow notes. Decent bitterness to offset the sweetness, some smoke. Overall very pleasant, for a style that I really havent been into for a while.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 355 ml bottle. Batch #79. From Vancouver, WA, USA.
Clear golden amber colour with big off-white head.
Big hoppy bitter aroma with fresh forest, sweet raisins and quite perfect sugary notes. Deliciously strong aroma. Flavour is s-w-e-e-t with capital s. Sugar covering the alcohol. Strong bitter hoppiness balancing the sweetness. Sweet but delicious mixture. Probably the best Barley Wine Ive tasted.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 12oz bottle, pours with a white head, slightly hoppy aroma, earthy. Taste is strong, alcohol, and a dirty earthiness. Interesting. A slight bit if tobacco, sweet. God I love Rye. I think rye whiskey barrels could do this thing wonders.

12oz bottle poured into my Rodenbach Grand Cru glass...A confusing pour as this is the lightest barleywine Ive ever seen...A dark gold with copper in the middle. An off white head with a decent cap, great lacing...Honey bomb on the front, lemon, hoppy barleywine finish...The taste is really sweet, lots of honey, easy to drink. Hoppy finish. Strange but drinkable, a little intrigued. 

Cant recommend but Id drink it again.

bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured an caramel amber color with slightly off white frothy head that sat floating on top of the beer.  aroma was raisin, plum, caramel, toffee, slight tire rubber, and some slight pine.  flavor was was dark fruits, caramel, alcohol, and almost a wine type flavor.  body was medium with a soft yet frothy carbonation.
huge head that lasts for a long while. Opaque golden wheat look, with a bitter smell with citrus and floral notes. Apple and alcohol taste, effervescent and other fruit tones.  Good beer
Pours cloudy, orange-golden with tan head. Aromas of honey and grapefruit. Moderately bitter, but way too sweet.

A - Pours a bright cloudy orange-red color with a finger of creamy white-tan head. The head retention is okay and there is nice lacing on the glass.

S - Aroma has a lot of sweet fruits in it, such as apple. There are also some elements of wheat and yeast mixed in. Just a touch of malt.

T - Starts off with some fruit flavors (again a lot of apple) and some other sweet elements. There is also some noticeable alcohol taste alongside just a touch of sweet carmel malt. Through the middle some deeper fruit and malt flavors break through with a touch of yeast flavor. The finish is a blend of the fruity esters some bread malt flavor and a touch of booze and hop which lingers for a while.

M - Full bodied with moderate sharp carbonation. The beer is pretty thick overall, but slick and smooth. The finish is pretty pungent and really lingers for a while.

D - Fairly drinkable. Really big and complex beer, so it is a real sipper, but it is very enjoyable. There are a lot of flavors mixing around, and while it is not quite perfectly balanced, it is very enjoyable.

Hazy and thick copper/gold in the glass with a frothy white head.  Aroma is thick sweet malt, spice, nutmeg, soft aromatic hops and a touch of honey.  Taste is light hops up front followed by a huge sweet malt profile laden with honey, spice, raisin/date, and a noticeable alcohol tinge into the finish.  Unique and enjoyable sweet barley wine.

12 oz bottle from Stinky in Brooklyn. Batch 74. 
Deep amber with small head. I get a lot of brown sugar and sweet dark fruits here. A good deal of breadiness as well. With a nice grassy goat cheese, this is awesome. Could also be great as an after dinner beer.

12 once bottle poured into Duvel tulip. Batch Number 79. 

APPEARANCE:

Pours hazy, burnt orange gold. Some sparse cinnamon powder-like sediment. Off-white, cream-colored head is 1 finger and settles fairly quickly, leaving a thin film of foam on surface as well as some medium size bubbles around edge of glass. 


AROMA:

Tangy aroma that has some subtle vinous character  almost like smelling a WarHeads (sour hard candy). Strong rye aroma. Spices  allspice as well as light cinnamon and nutmeg. Hops, which seem citrusy and grassy. Belgian candi. Some honey. Grape bubblegum. Wet grain. Extremely faint band-aid.

Slightly musty character to the aroma as well  though this seems to fade as the beer warms up. 

As it warms up, displays some oak notes. Subtle orange creamsicle aroma as well. 

TASTE: Belgian candi. Rye. Tang from the rye. Hops are citrusy and grassy. Spices such as allspice, as well as some light cinnamon and nutmeg. Some honey. Faint orange creamsicle. 

Back of palate has slight grainy taste. Finish has hop bitterness, including light resinous characteristics. Light alcohol warmth on finish. 


MOUTH FEEL: Thick; almost a bit syrupy. Full-bodied. Definitely quite sweet, though unable to say it is cloying - as long as it is drunk as a dessert beer. Mid to low carbonation. 


OVERALL: Sweet  definitely a dessert beer. Despite being primarily sweet, there is slight bitterness on the finish. Seems like plenty of residual Belgian candi  whether this is good or bad will depend on the mood/environment of the drinker. Let it warm up a bit and take your time with this slow-sipper. Despite some faint off notes among the complexities on the nose, the positive attributes of the overall experience with this beer far outweigh any marginally undesirable notes on the aroma. Complex interplay of sweet and slightly tangy with a bit of a bitter finish. Interesting and quite unique.
Delicious.  Bottle from Batch 81. Pours cloudy brown with thick white head.  Malty and candy aroma.  Full body with a balanced hop to malt flavour.  Edge to centre of tongue finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Faint ester aroma with malt sweetness barely discernable.  Hazy golden pour with thin white head.  Malt sweetness, with a honey like flavor and traces of esters blend perfectly.  Slight alcohol warmth evident on the finish.  A velvety smooth drink with low carbonation and a slickness.  Great beer.  Hops are noticeable after a while.  Very smooth and deceptively easy to drink.

Az illata felkavaróan gyümölcsös és édes. Percekig lebegünk tőle. Végül beleiszunk, és visszatérünk a földre. Az íze az illatához képest visszalépés, vaskosan cukros és karamelles, majd oldalról fékezés nélkül beleszáll a komló, és végül elég tömény, szigorú édes komlószörpi lesz belőle. Az első szigorú élményt persze szépen lazítja az oxidáció, úgy bomlanak ki az ízek, mint az összegyűrt, majd lassan kinyújtózkodó újságpapír. Érdekes, medvecukorhoz, marcipánhoz hasonlatos ízek jönnek elő a mélyéből, ezeket a szokatlan aromákat az árpa mellett felhasznált rozsmaláta okozhatja. 
Ezért és más100-as DIPA-kért köszönet Balázsnak!

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2011 Bottle: Batch 81:
Pretty big, vast white head on top of a hazy yellow oranger colored beer.
Smell sweets, malts, spices, gas and hint of fruit.
Taste is a delicious mix of hops, barleys, sweets, hints of yeast and fruits. Very well balanced.
Sweet malty, barley aftertaste.
Low carbo, full body and a very soft silky (sticky) mouthfeel,
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Pours an opaque yellow-orange body. Soft but vey balanced aroma, fruits and yeast. Great mouthfeel, some bitterness from the malts, sweet fruit. Cloves, spices, pepper. Extremely well-rounded.

Batch number 66

Pours a slightly cloudy dark amber with a huge bubbly head that lasts forever and leaves thick gobs of lacing all the way down. Smells of citrus, caramel. and a bit of spicy yeast. Taste is caramel malt, grassy, citrus hops, fruity esters mixed with a bit of alcohol. Has a bit of a Belgian flair to it, really interesting and flavorful. Thick body, lots of carbonation, sticky sweet mouthfeel. I thought this one was great. I wish I had more!

Bottle from Crackedkettle. Poured hazy, with an orange color and a small, lacing, off-white head. Fruity aroma with honey, apple, grapes, cantalope and caramel. Sweet taste, maybe a bit more than expected from the aroma. Nice hoppy aftertaste. Alcohol is well hidden. Good one!

(12oz bottle Batch 79).  Pours hazy apricot with off-white head.  Very active carbonation.  Aroma of dried fruit, some wood and citrus, but the fruit dominates-mostly sweet, dried apricot.  Taste is sweet with some hop bitterness.  Full bodied with thick, sticky texture.  Very smooth.  The alcohol is noticeable in the finish, but really hits the chest and throat.  Really nice!
