Rich amber/copper color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, toffee, hops, fruit, & spice; Flavor of woody sweet malt, spicy hops, caramel, molasses, fruit, and citrus; Some alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very good brew.

12 fl.oz bottle, batch 78, from CrackedKettle, Amsterdam, courtesy of Balazs, thanks
Poured clear orange-amber with a medium beige head that slowly settles into spotty lace. Malty aroma with tons of caramel, vanilla, and chocolate, lightly bitter hoppiness, rye spice and just a hint of alcohol heat, mild floral-herbal hops, resin and lime . Malt, sweet caramel brings the wide base, vanilla and toffee with some spiceness, solid dose of hops bitterness on the back of the palate. The body is full with a long aftertaste with sweet caramel and vanilla, a bit of toffee and the resiny hops in the finish.

This is a barley wine?  Ooook... it pours a hazy golden color with a fluffy white head that dissipates rather slowly.  Aroma is malt, some sweet citrus (mandarins almost), butterscotch, and candi sugar.  Flavor is sweet malts, sweet light fruits, a good smack of candi sugar, and some booze.  This is a very unique beer... more like a heavily sugared Belgian Golden than a Barley Wine if you ask me.  It is a very complex beer that keeps showing you new flavors well after you have swallowed.  Well done beer - I cant wait to have another.

12oz bottle, Batch 77.  Pours a hazy yellow-amber color with a big white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and a hint of booze.  A bit heavy on the palate with lively carbonation.  Flavor is malty, yeast, a little booze, and the candi sugar.  A very drinkable barley wine.

Courtesy of boFNjackson. Bottle pours deep amber with a white head.  Aroma is sweet and yeasty with notes of toffee, vanilla, candi sugar, citrus(grapefruit), and a hint of rye.  Flavor shows the same with additional
notes of brown sugar and pineapple.

This Fred was of Batch 77.

Aroma:Tons of sweet malt, dark fruits, and alcohol in the aroma.

Appearance:Deep amber in color, tons of long lasting white head.

Taste:The hops are very much in force in this beer on the foretaste, hugely bitter. The midtaste lets the malt and caramel flavors start to shine through the bitterness. The aftertaste mellows out nicely leaving caramel and dark fruit flavors on my tongue.

Palate:This beer has a medium to heavy body, great carbonation, a little creaminess, and some hot alcohol. The heavy handed hops give it some harsh astringency.

Overall:Its got some great complex flavors, and is a nice sipping beer. I think that this beer may still need to do some more aging to round out the rough edges, even though its already at least 2 years old.
I enjoyed this Barley Wine and will have it again. It gave a strong plum presence to me. Dark and tan, but goldie bear brown if that makes any sense and head for days. "Thats what she said." Hehe.
Out of a bottle from the brewery.  Beautiful orange with haze. Massive white head - very billowy.  Wonderful clean hops. Nice warming.

A hazy orange/brown without much of a head.  Rich honeyed malts on the nose with a hint of estery funk and some boozy heat.  It is remarkably full of flavour rich and intense.  Honey  sweetness with a heap of hoppy dryness.  There are lovely fruity tingles but a very wholegrain bready flavour brings some excellent savoury qualities.  Bloody interesting.
1/15/11.  Bottle shared at the Sea Bass going away party!  Light dark fruits with almost a hint of wine.  Sweet dark fruits and molasses in the flavor.  Quite good!

12 oz. bottle from Delocks Liquor in Munster, IN (batch 79).  Pours a murky orangeish-brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma of pine needles, grapefruit rind, and pineapple.  The big hoppiness detected in the aroma is easily balanced in flavor by a big malty sweetness, however a little more time in the bottle should balance this even more.  Some alcohol warming is detected.  Overall, another stunning beer from this brewery and a barley wine that should get even better with a year or more of aging.

Tasted on 1/16/11 from a 12oz bottle obtained in a trade, Batch 71.  Pours clear and bright orange with just a bit of red tint and an average beige head that slowly settles into spotty lace.  The nose is very malty with tons of caramel, vanilla, and chocolate, lightly bitter hoppiness, graham cracker, rye spice and just a hint of alcohol heat.  The flavor is sweet caramel, vanilla and toffee up front, moving into some rye spice and graham cracker, and a solid dose of hops bitterness on the back of the palate.  The body is full with average carbonation and a super long finish that starts off with sweet caramel and vanilla, a bit of burnt toffee, and then bitterness.

Yellow color with a huge fluffy off white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast and sweet malts. Taste of citrus hops, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body. Finish is a little bitter and warming. Good and unusual.

Bottle; bought at Cracked Kettle, shared at the Rake during the The Kernel Black IPA launch

Big US hop aroma,. citrus, surprisingly oaky, yeasty, bready aroma. Taste is citrus hops, pine, lemon-grass, huge huge marzepan, spices and herbs. Excellent finish of marzepan; citrus and herbs. Excellent.

Bottle, Batch 74.  I have my best friend to thank for this bottle.  Bethany, I am looking forward to sharing a great brew with you again and thanks for this and many other great beer experiences together.  

This one has some age on it, but still get a nice pillowy slightly off-white head on a light coppery brown color...very opaque.  Some light hoppiness still remains in the aroma, but very slight citrus.  Apples, caramel and light toffee in the aroma.  Candy, apples, caramel, and a bit of earthy wood feature in the flavor.  Medium body and a little oily with sparkly carbonation.  Very warming, and an obvious sipper.  Would like to try a fresh one for comparison, but still a nice enough one with some age on it.

Bottle, Batch #80, c/o SuzyGreenberg.  Pours dark golden orange, slightly hazy with some tan-colored sediment, and topped by a thick, creamy 2-finger beige head made of barely-discernable bubbles.  The head recedes slowly to leave a thin white veil of lacing.  The aromas are sweet plum, cherry, raisin, brown sugar, pine and spruce, a touch of sour orange and alcohol, citrus rind, and caramel.  The flavor is plum, cherry, sugar-coated orange, and candi sugar, moving to slightly bitter pine and sweet fruity malt.  The finish introduces mildly funky fruit and leather.  This is deliciously sweet.  Medium carbonation makes this smooth and creamy, with a sweet, sticky mouthfeel, and a warming finish.  Very drinkable.  Absolutely amazing; I need more.

This beer pours orange/brown with a thin white head. An aroma of grapefruit and hops emanates from the glass, hopefully the taste is a little more distinct than the smell since there is not much going on. This brew is different when compared to the other barley wines on one key aspect - hops. It is not nearly as hoppy as the other two or three Ive had recently and is dominated by fruit instead of bitterness. If you arent a fan of hops I would give this a try if you want to have any kind of barley wine.

12oz bottle. Dark brown color, hazy and cloudy. Thick head, white and bubbly. A lot of hops in the aroma with a good amount of barley as well. Sweet and smooth flavor. Barley and a little bit of dark fruits such as raisins are present. Big ABV but really easy to drink.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 
12oz bottle served in a tulip pour was a dark golden cloudy color with two fingers of off white head. Nose was fruits,burnt caramel,bananas. Taste was spices,malts and wood this is one tasty brew and the first I have had from this brewery cant wait to try their other brews.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is a light, murky cider with two fingers of sudsy foam on top.  Nose is bananas, Belgian yeast (smells like anyway), cloves, light caramel, various spices, and light wood.  Taste is right on par, done in a close to champagne carbonated, yeasty body.  I tried a gentle pour, however, the sediment ended up in the glass.  Despite this, it is a very tasty brew and as such, should not be passed up.

Is there anything HOTD do badly? I knew this would be good - and of course it was. Straddles the divide between malty english barleywine and hoppy american BW. Lovely Lively beer. Big apricot on the nose and in the mouth. A little sticky but really smooth. Expertly put together.

12 oz bottle. Pours a slightly hazy brown pour, with a bit of off white head. Aroma is really on the burnt-caramel boozy sweet side, the hops have already faded. Taste is much the same, very sweet, kind of roasted/caramel flavors going on, but it is better than the aroma, I find there is more subtlety in the flavors. Palate is rich and creamy. A good beer, would like to try it fresh though.

Pours a orangish-yellow-brown color.  Head was unremarkable, but everything else was outstanding.  Aroma of ripe fruit and malts.  Taste is truely unique.  Sweet candy taste, raisins, malts, then some hops, and finishes warm.  Wow.

Batch # 75, bottle enjoyed at Oliver Twist. Hazy copper with a small head. Complex raisins aroma followed by nuts, raisins, marcipan and chocolate flavours. Appropriate bitterness. Full-bodied. A truly great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2013 Bottle at The Cads Pure Mad Rocket Mon The Beezer Tasting. Pours cloudy gold with a light film. Mellow nose, with bread and caramel coming through. Great flavor, lots of sugary malts, brown sugar and caramel and toffee. Medium in body with fine carbonation. Warm and sweet on the finish with lots of toffee and burnt, caramelized sugars. Just wonderful. (4.4)Bottle shared at CBC - Clerkenwell, London - thanks for another great one, Seth! Super beer, lots of golden raisins. Solid. (4.1)

Bottle from Capones. Pours a beautiful golden amber with huge head. Took awhie for the fizz to settle. Aroma is hoppy, almost thought id be drinking more of an ipa. Taste is very candy sweet with a touch of bittering hops. Really interesting beer but finishes a little thin.

Bottle shared with Naka.  Pours orange with ruby hues, little head, rimming and filmy.  Orange and honey nose, mild alcohol and some bread.  Decent lacing.  Lots of alcohol, honey, sweet caramel, brown sugar and a touch of oak.  Solid.

Bottle shared by DalzAle (thanks Greg). Pour is golden yellow with a big fluffy head thad lasts. Aroma is honey citrus and sweet malt. Taste is more sweet malt and lemon honey and yeast. Palate is full and carbonated with a nice fizzy feel and finishes dry. Nice!
Nice strawberry brown color. Taste has a little ginger, vanilla, raisin and caramel with a little bit of sugar.

12 oz. Dark orange-brown with a small ring of bubbles. Sweet nose of orange caramel and brandy. Flavor is caramel, citrus, and resiny wood. Medium-heavy body is smooth, to the sweet side, and warming.

Bottle: Batch 63. Pours a slightly cloudy copper color with huge 4 finger head that took 5 minutes to subside at all.  Lacing down the whole glass.  Complex malt aroma.  Flavor is sweet caramel and smooth. Not typically a fan of barley wine but this was great.  Maybe I dont age them enough.

From a 12oz into a snifter.  Pours a nice brow/red color with a couple inches of head on top.  Decent lacing.  Great aroma of cherries, alcohol, oranges and a number of other smells... highlight of the beer.  Mouthfeel is smooth and heavy; very full of syrup.  Taste is very, very hot.  Alcohol is omnipresent from the first taste to aftertaste.  Plenty of fruit undertones though and some pumpkiny all spice flavors.  Overall a good beer but Waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyyyy too hot for me.  Ill buy it again  and set it down for a year, hopefully that will take the edge off.

Batch #75.  12 ounce bottle purchased over a year ago at Total Wine in Tustin ($2.99).  Pours a deep color that is equal parts red and brown with a layer of very thin beige foam.  Aroma trends toward sweet with notes of sticky sweet caramel, candied fruit, sweet hoppy floral, honeysuckle, and sweet alcohol.  Flavor similarly sweet with smooth sweet caramel, honey, lightly hoppy notes (floral, citrus), and quite a bit of alcohol at the end.  Even under the strength and complexity, there is a nice delicateness to the flavor.  The finish is nicely sweet but with noticeable alcohol.  Good barley wine, and I have a 1.5 year old Fred From The Wood in the fridge right now and look forward to doing a comparison tasting in the near future.  (1050, 420)
Bottle thanks to a generous trader. Pours cloudy orange. Nose is hops, candy sugar, apricot and rye. Taste is caramel malts, candy sugar, hops, citrus and rye. Alcohol is noticeable.

Twelve ounce bottle poured into a Belgian fishbowl glass. Clear golden color, lots of bubbles. Agressive pour produces rich, thick foamy white head sticks around a while and leaves lots of lacing in the glass. I got lots of yeast like floaties in the glass. Spicy ginger and cinnamon aroma, sweet candy apples -- very aromatic. Big burst of malty sweetness with a touch of alcohol presence in the end. Dark fruit flavors and lots of caramel. Medium to full bodied, syrupy mouthfeel, lots of carbonation.
Very nice sipping beer, warming and complex.

Bottle: pours a cloudy golden with whitish head with nice retention. Interesting hop aroma (10 hop varieties, really?) with a sweetness. Mouthfeel is heavy, naturally. This brew is a bit much in that sweetness department by my tastes, but it certainly is a unique experience. My sister called it a shot to the eyeball - i cant argue

12oz bottle shared by Marcdesthya.
Appearance : Semi hazy amber with a big foamy and creamy head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Nice sweet peachy with hops. A little bit woody. Very rich.

Taste : Nice hops with sweet apricots. A bit woody. Nice hops. Light bitterness on the finish. Light alcohol also. 

Overall : Awesome stuff. My best HOTD so far. I think I like this one better than its "from the wood" brother. Well balanced. Great hops on the nose and taste. I love the balance between the hops and the sweet malt/rye. This is really my type of Barley Wine. Merci Marc !

batch 63, a 2005 if i am not mistaken. wow. very nice beer. pours with a very generous 2 inch head,both thick and creamy and spongy and sparse. tons of awesome very thick lacing and spotting. nice hazy deep amber orange body. the aroma is very spicy and sweet, pepper and caramel, funky funky fresh.the taste is to match, huge, smooth, well rounded, very unique. lots of citrus, funky old ale qualities, thick sweet caramel and toffee notes. great body, despite the large head its not to lively in the mouth at all. warming, a very nice winter time brew. HotD has been hit or miss for me, but this one is a hit!

Aroma- yeast, sweet malt, grassy hop, thick caramel, citrus, lemon pound cake.  pours thick amber gold with large resilient head with lacing.  taste is heavy caramel, thick sugar, oats, grass, lemon.  I got the feeling the bottle I tasted was very old.  It seemed like the hops had greatly mellowed, and as a result I was not able to taste all the great things I smelled in the aroma.  The real character of this beer seemed masked by the thick sweetness created by the mellowed hops.  Oh well, maybe ill re-review if i ever find one again.

Pours a deep golden color with a full white head and leaves nice sheets of lacing behind on the glass.  Very attractive in the nose.  Soft citrus fruits on the nose and bright hops.  The flavor is wonderfully deep and complex, while it is essentially soft fruits, the flavor is wonderfully rounded with the deeper darker fruits.  The finish is then lightly tart, dry, and a bit bitter from the hops.  Fantastic beer!

Perhaps this will grow on me later, but for now its not quite what I thought.  A bit hoppy (good), this mouthfeel and taste of alchohol.  I think its the bitterness that puts this off for me though.  Overall, Ill take this any day but Ive had better.

A hazed dark amber ale with a thin creamy off white head. A smooth sweet and spiced aroma, candied sugar, light treacle notes. In mouth, an interesting ABT-barley wine hybrid, with c-hops, fruity esters, coriander, such a good combo. Wow!  On tap at Hair of the Dog, Sept. 4, 2010.

Clear dark amber with a very thin white head. Aroma is caramel, resin, flower, herbs, sugar, fruits, alcohol. Full body and low carbonation. In mouth is caramel, alcohol, some, sweetness, herbs. OMG, this is an amazing Barley Wine. A MUST TRY

Batch 79. Pours a cloudy golden color with no head at all. The aroma of this beer lets it down. The taste however is like nothing I have ever had before. The alcohol will warm you but isnt noticeable in the taste. The taste then, is hard to describe... its malty and sweet, but also sour. Good beer in a style I will definitely be exploring more.

Batch 78. Pours a dark golden color with a extremely large head. Aroma is floral yet fruity at the same time. Taste is sweet, slight alcohol burn, belgian sugar and some cotton candy. I dont think I would call this a barleywine. Very unique like the other Hair of The Dog beers Ive tried. Ill definately pick up another one of these to cellar with my Adam.

Batch 77.  Pours a deep brown with a massive, growing head.  Aroma is toasted almonds and malt, with a note of piney hops.  Flavor is strong of brown sugar, maple syrup, french toast, and malts with a finish full of floral and other hops.  Obviously a very young beer that could age well, but it is great as it is now.  A little too sweet for me as is, but otherwise a perfect tasting beer.  I cant wait to put the other one away for a few years.  Well, I guess I will have to wait at least a few years, but you know what I mean.

Hazy orange/amber with think off-white head.  Big malty/alcohol aroma with hint of pine hops.  You can smell the hugeness here.  The flavor - its like a 12 oz malty shot.  Huge alcohol presence with malt following initial taste, big and hefty.  Hops make an appearance towards the finish.  While a bit cloying the finish comes quickly and cleanly.  A barley wine for todays market.

Batch 79. The aroma is citrus hops, some clove. The head is big, creamy, off white in color, mostly lasting. The color is a cloudy golden orange. The taste is sweet then bitter. The body is light to medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation average and the finish bitter. Very good.

12oz bottle from The Grapevine 
Appearance: Hazy orange/amber with a small off-white head and good lacing in the glass 
Aroma: Sweet malts, dark fruits, rye and belgian candy 
Taste: Very smooth and silky mouthfeel. Sweet malts, spices and some bitterness in the finish 
Very nice, smooth and easy to drink.

A: pours a gorgeous rich amber color, tons of red and orange hues. wonderful almond colored head with an amazing head that has a phenomenal retention level. Huge amount of lacing.

S: slightly acidic aroma, but nice. big hops nose, nothing in particular, which is great. keeping it all together is the aroma from the malts. sweet, fruity and robust.

T: very sweet malts, with a slight apple characteristic. big orange notes, reminds me of Grand Marnier almost. very robust and smooth, with a nice kick from the alcohol. outstanding palate on this.

M: smooth and creamy for a barleywine. higher carbonation level than expected, but very welcoming. full bodied definitely.

D: like everything from this brewery, it is wonderful. get it because it is fantastic. probably the most drinkable

Thick apricot with a thin tan head that retains.  Aroma of maple, pitted fruits, mild alcohol, toffee, rye and a bit of hop character.  Taste is very sweet with caramel, fruits, oak, vanilla and mild hops.  A bit fizzier than Id prefer and finishes with an alcoholic kick.  Decent, but a bit too sweet so Ill rank it a tick below the rest of the RB community.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2011 Aroma: Spicy hops plus a mix of orange and ruby grapefruit rind, dried apricot and possibly mango.
Palate: Thick but not cloying.
Flavor: Spicy apricot and mango that finishes with ripe ruby grapefruit, spicy, floral and peppery hops plus a touch of caramel. Smooth yet bitter finish.
Comments: Wow.  The hops and malt are well balanced and the aromas and flavors of both lift each other.  Layers of fruit flavors pass over the tongue, ending in a bitter (but not at all harsh) finish.  Truly outstanding as everything seems to be in proportion.  Unlike the Adam, I wonder if this had a year or so of age on it.

2009 on Draft. Aroma: Sweet roasted caramel, walnut
Flavor: Roasted caramel at first and finishes with a light-candied, caramel and orange
Comments: Rated it 44 this time.  My favorite of the HoD line up.

Pours very cloudy deep golden with a big white pillowy head.  Aroma is sweet malts with flowery and citris hops.  Taste is thick with syrupy malts and pinapple, citrus and grapefruit. A bit hot.  Too cloying for me.

No head at all on this beer that is the color of slightly dark honey.  No carbonation to be seen.  A complex aroma bodes good things to come.  Spicy, alcohol, lots of fruit.  An interesting feel.  It has no carbonation and is medium.  The flavor is even more complex than the aroma.  Again, fruit galore,  spice, alcohol, applesauce, caramel, graham crackers, sugar, and funk.  There is just an amazing amount of stuff going on in every sip.  This would make for a great Winter warmer.

Batch #77 [A] Caramel, and a light candied citrus. [A] A hazy golden color, with a white, retentive head. [F] Some astringent booze on end. Flavor is cherries, dark fruit, citrus, caramel. Pilsner malt is noticeable. [P] A touch syrupy and over carbonated. Fizzy mouth. Not something to put down quickly. [O] Reminds me of a DFH beer. Like a toned down 120 min. Not sure if I would necessarily categorize this as a barleywine. I made the mistake of ignoring the bottle, and pouring the sediment in, causing an uproar of foam in the process. This is one for the cellar to temper, and cool down. Way to hot for me to enjoy fresh. Campfire beer.

Thanks to hophead101 for sending me this bottle. This is one I have been looking forward to trying.

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a white head. The aroma is classic American Barleywine with notes of caramel malt and oranges. The flavor is sweet caramel, sweet oranges, toffee, brown sugar and a touch of alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great beer that didnt disappoint.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 Batch 1 shared at the Philly tasting.  Deep burnt orange pour with just a whisper of a white head.  Caramel and malty aromas.  For being almost 16 years old this beer is delicious.  Fred held up better in my opinion than both Adam, which I normally prefer, and Eve.  Silky mouthfeel.  All kinds of warm and inviting malty notes, deep caramels, and just a hint of dark fruits.  Wow, very impressive.  A tip of the cap to Alan.....

Batch 79. As description suggests-is deep golden and clear sporting a creamy white head. Nose is earthy hops, sweet malt, fruits and Im really not extremely complex. Taste is intense with sweet malts, fruits, wood, and some alcohol.

Pours a golden light amber colour, hazy with a small off-white head that disappears quickly. The aroma is filled with citrus hops, caramel malts, spices, slight booze and an apple like scent. The taste is candy sweet at first then becomes much more hop bitter, the finish is quite strong. Medium-full body, lively carbonation and a mouth feel that begins thin and then becomes quite thick and syrupy. An excellent beer, definitely worth a try.

Bouteille de 12 oz, batch 78. Arômes très complexes de malt (sucre dorge, céréales légèrement grillées) et de houblon fruité. Robe dorée et légèrement trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. Très complexe en bouche, le malt présente des notes de sucre dorge et de céréales très bien développées. On retrouve également une touche de whisky. Le houblon fruité et résineux est également présent. La bière est sucrée, mais sans jamais trop le devenir. Finale alcoolisée et moyennement amère. Très bon!

Bottle. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, herbal hops and rum. Appearance is a dark orange and crimson color with a very thin layer of resinous head. Taste starts off with intense dark sugar and caramel malt flavors followed by woody alcohol, vanilla, toffee, butterscotch, raisins and candied dates. Mouthfeel is syrupy and full-bodied with low-to-medium carbonation and a dry, boozy finish. Its incredibly rich and complex with a wide variety of malt and alcohol flavors accentuated by the dark sugars. Fred has all the characteristics of a great Barleywine and somehow manages to avoid being too cloyingly sweet. Its an ideal after dinner sipper.

Location: 12 oz bottle from NickD717, 7/14/10
This seemed like a good one for rating #1400...


Aroma: The nose has some sweet malts, spice, some heat, some citrus hops, and a little caramel

Appearance: The appearance gives a pretty good first impression as it pours out a somewhat cloudy golden-orange color with a few fingers worth of creamy beige head that leaves a lot of lace on the glass

Flavor: The taste has a lot of spice, some sweet malt, a bit of citrus hops, and a little bit of funkiness

Palate: The body is medium (leaning full), with a somewhat creamy feel to it, and long bitter/hot finish to it

Overall Impression: 
Thanks, Nick!  This is another really nice beer from HotD!  Pretty tasty stuff.  Not as good as some of the beers that Ive had before, but it was really enjoyable none-the-less.  A nice spicy flavor that meshes pretty well with the good mouthfeel.  Quality stuff for sure.

Hair of the Dog Fred is a smooth beer. You can down this beer easily by why would you? Its delicious. I sipped this beer through and through cause the taste was resplendent. Its got a sweet taste through the hops. Its hard to place the actual flavor of the sweetness, its like a mix of different fruits, maybe even tropical. The smell is very similar to the taste. It smells of sweetness and a slight hint of the alcohol (10% abv). Seriously, this beer is very smooth and you can just drink and drink this one. So delicious.

Golden, high carbonation. Aroma of clean malt and a mix of hops that seems german to me. Alcohol on the nose too. Flavour is much better, full mouthfeel with big clean malt and zingy hop flavours, good bitterness. lots of alcohol warmth.

Bottle from Cavie.  I keep reading that Sprinkle is the man.  Heres to that.  Cloudy orange pour with a ridiculous white head.  Aroma is alcohol, sweet spice, caramel, a little citrus, and some wood.  Taste is honey, alcohol, cinnamon, a little rye bread, more burn, caramel, wood, and citrus.  Thick.

#1900! Bottle with big thanks from Sprinkle!  Really looking forward to this. Very clouded and murky orange color. Huge head response. Woody smells, dark fruit and spice.  Nice. Taste is explosive! Flavor is woody, earthy, sweetness, syrup, and awesome caramel malts. Awesome flavor! Great finish that lingers, Im drinking more than my share of the sample.  Oh yeah.

bottle. pours murky amber, medium head that dissipates slowly. aroma is crystal malts caramel, sugar swwetness, sherry, alcohol. smells like the duchess.  flavor is hop burst at the front end, sugar in the middle and bitter dry finish, good beer.

Bottle. 12 oz. (2008 Vintage) Pours a deep mahogany-cherry amber with a thick, rich, lucious two finger off-white head. Aroma of burnt marshmallow, roast, barley, sweet malts, caramel, vanilla, scotch, and hints of oak and bitter dry hops. Full bodied with a heavy, rich, thick mouthfeel and a spicy-sweet palate. Finishes slowly with a hearty, boozy warming in the chest. Awesome brew. Bottle lists the style as a "Golden Special Ale", but it does taste more like a barley or american strong. Lovely night-cap.

12oz bottle thanks to LilBeerDoctor. Batch 74. Pours a murky golden color with a small head which fizzes away quickly. Nose is sweet malts, caramel, raisin and some dark fruits. Flavor is also full of caramel, sweetness, dark fruits and has a nice bitter finish which balances nicely with the sweetness. Bitter finish lingers for a while and can notice the high alcohol. Nice full bodied beer.

Bottle. Holy balls. This is it, this is the beer I want to drink at my funeral. Pours golden with a big white head. Flavor is sweet candy sugar with florals, light hops, and that medicinal barleywine taste. This is like a hybrid tripel and barleywine. Ridiculous, I cant believe I went to Portland and managed not to try this.

Batch 72.  Bottle pours murky rusty orange color with off white head that does not last.  Aroma has some oxidation setting in with plum, raisin, and brown sugar.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor has the aroma with some caramel, figs, and finishes semi sweet.  A very nice brew indeed.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2013 12 oz. bottle, pours amber with a big off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, caramel malt, raisins and hops. Flavour brings out notes of rye, candied sugar and a little fruitiness. No notice of the alcohol content. The rye dominates, almost tasting a bit like pot. Great stuff.

This was a magnum of batch #2 of Fred (1998 vintage??)that some locals brought to the BIG tasting hosted by "hannont" a few weeks ago. How appropriate that it was just before Fred Fest!   Colour... slightly cloudy orange-brown with a thin head. Nose... boiled fruity sweets, dates, raisins, and golden sirop. Palate... moderately frothy with loads of golden raisins, dried cherries, quercus, vanillin, zante currants, macerated Bing cherry skins, medjool dates, clover honey, Scottish heather, Christmas spice and a extraordinarily long, coating finish. Of the 84 bottles of beer/ale that we sampled over a 12 hour period, this one was the brew to rule all others! What a treat!!
Strong sweet malt aroma. Cloudy brown color with a small white head. Mild sweet beginning with a bitter middle that fades in the finish.

Bottle served in a snifter. Batch #76. Poured fresh from the fridge, cold. Too cold no doubt. Metallic copper in color with a slight haze and zero head. Still the fragrance of creamy caramel maltiness parlays on the nose. This will surely be a beast... Wow! Huge, sweet, and creamy. Full body, thick, creamy, and sticky throughout the malty, alcohol finish.

Bottle, at a very resonable price of 5 dollars and change.  Pours an amazing copper color with a tall and very long lasting white head that is a bit soapy/sea fomay, but leaves nice lace.  The aroma is of sweet dark and light fruits with notes of fig, oak, sweet green grapes, green apple, and more.  The flavor is very sweet, which I dont particularly like, but it works alright with this beer.  The flavor is BIG and the booze is most certainly present.Very warming on the mouth and stomach.  Mostly fruit notes with hints of molasses, vanilla, wood, and more.  Full bodied with minimal carbonation.  Overall: this is undeniably good, but 8 ounces would suffice.  This one is not for the faint of heart, or the genuinely thirsty.  Thank god HotD has the sense to sell these in 12 oz bottles rather than bombers or 750s like many other brewing companies would do (to make the extra buck).
Bottle. Fruity, brown sugar and hops aroma. Light orange with a huge fluffy off-white head. Flavor was sweet, fruity, a little peppery, with a nice bitter finish.

Bouteille 15-05-2010. Batch #75. Fred est de couleur dorée foncée avec de petits reflets rougeatres. Sa mousse est blanche et disparait asser rapidement. Aromes prononcés de sucres candi et dalcool. On peut également percevoir ds notes de vin blanc, de beurre fondu et de fruits tel que des abricots et des peches. Houblon strident au palais, doux et explosant de saveurs en bouche. Biere très complexe et très plainsante a boire. Ses aromes décrivent très bien ses saveurs, donc aucune surprise. Saveures de sucre candi, dalcool, de fruits et de houblon. Tres, très bonne.

Bottle. Cloudy amber with medium off white head that thins. Aroma is dried fruit (apricot mostly) molasses sugars, medium booze, a slice of pecan pie. Taste is syrupy caramel/molasses sweetness with boozy backbone. The quintessential barley wine, in my own opinion. Really well done, syrupy sweet does not overpower palate. What all other barley wines should be judged against.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Half Time (Poughkeepsie, NY). Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de petits fruits. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée voilée. Présence dune mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dhoublons et de caramel fruité. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche.  Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #3019)

Bottle.

Amber with no head. Sugar, dried fruits, raisin, apples, bourbon, malt, very thick. Complex and interesting. Alcohol was really well hidden.

Pours an amber brown haze with a medium white head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit and caramel.  Beer is very indicative of the style.  Has that biting syrupy taste, very sweet.  Some bitters on the finish.  Has that alcohol after taste you get with most barleywines.  Very tasty.

Guest bottle selection at 3Floyfs. Golden amber pour with an off-white head. Aroma of hops(light), little rye, caramel, Belgian candi sugar. Taste is dark fruits, candi sugar, rye, bread, smooth and creamy. Nice lacing.

head: normal and creamy 
colour: deep orange 
smell: sweet , very good hops , peach ? ive could a smell this beer for an hour if i didnt had the urge o drink it!!! 
taste: hops , very sweet , well balanced alcohol taste underneath , hops definitly control this beer but the aftertaste strikes back with a very sweet flavour and ends in powerfullalcoholic bitterness ... 
this is by far the best beer/barley wine i have ever tasted !!!!

Pours apricot in color. Minimal head. Aroma of cinnamon, brown sugar, alcohol, sugar, and dead hops. Cloying flavor of burnt sugar, grass, candied pecans and slight bitter grapefruit. Thick, syrupy alcohol sugar water. Not a fav.

Aged bottle originally bought in 2006. This is one I have been sampling over the years and it really does get better and better as time goes on. This is a very good barley wine. Flavor is sweet, raisin like, and malty. Finishes smooth, clean, and slightly bitter. Abv is also well hidden. Recommended.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a golden amber with a thick white head.  Nose is slightly sweet and fruity with some cherries, dates, citrusy hops.  Some pine in there too.  Taste is alcohol, initial sweetness, more fruits, spice, and bitter hoppiness.    Alright but not my favorite.

Pours a clear amber with medium off white head.  Aroma of candied sugar, sweet malt, alcohol, grass, and hops come through.  Flavor is fairly sweet - sweet malt, candied sugar, definitely with rye as well in the beginning and bittering hops heavy in the finish and lingers longer than expected and very  pleasant.  Alcohol in the nose but blends in the taste. Had to go back and re-rate this with a higher rating after letting it sit and finishing last half of bottle, sediment with of course.  Highly recommend giving it some air.

Bottle, home.  Pours a big coppery amber with a small white cap.  It looks a bit like brandy.  Lots of caramel malt sweetness and big American hops in the aroma.  Theres a great spicy rye note in the flavor, along with honey and sweet grapes.  Rich but not cloying.  Theres a bitter citrus rind finish, at least in a relatively fresh bottle.  I think the feel improves as the beer sits.

Bottle; ironic I havent had this one yet.  Poured a golden color with a big frothy, off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, fruit, rye, yeast, flowers, and citrus.  Flavor had a really nice sugar and sweet element.  Belgian yeast, fruit, sugary, vanilla, and rye.  Really nice flavor that I really couldnt put my finger on.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a yellowish brown head. Aroma is full of sweet dark grains with a caramel and toffee finish. Flavor is similar with a nice dark grain flavor and plenty of caramel and toffee finish. Nicely balanced.

bottle from JK ODonnells - Pours deep copper with no head.  Its virtually flat and I immediately asked the bartender if that was typical for this beer.  They have a very limited number of bottles but had sold some before I got mine.  She said that yes, thats what theyd seen in previous bottles sold.  It smells of woody malts and plenty of hops.  The flavor is heavily hopped with malt, some oak notes, and obvious candi sugar.  The candi sugar in a barley wine didnt work well for me, but the other flavors were good.  This brew was decent, but would have been better with some carbonation to speak of.  As that seems to be a common problem with this release, people should know.

Thanks to Stowehop for this one. Batch 73. I hadnt had this beer in at least 6 years or so, and my anticipation level was quite high.

A moderately aggressive pour into my Duvel tulip produced a cloudy, medium copper-brown beer with a thick, airy, bubbly head. 

After swirling this one around, I detected a slight cardboard smell, which was quickly replaced by aromas of apricots, canned peaches and pineapple.

The fruitiness translated to the taste on this one as well, picking up some citrus notes (orange?) which went nicely with the very present and warming alcohol flavors.

On the finish, this one was still a bit hot, and I seemed to detect a few off notes that I could not put my finger on (due to the shipping, perhaps?). Finished warming, with somewhat of a harsh bitterness. Overall an enjoyable beer, but does not live up to the expectations that I set for it.

Bought this spur of the moment from bottleworks in seattle. Think it may have been something wrong with it. absolutely no head at all. no foam, no life at all in this beer. I saw some reviewers online who had the the same problem.

Pours deep red with off white head, aroma is spicy and resiny hops with some caramel and even a bit of vanilla.  Taste up front is grass, resin, and spicy hops leading into thick sweet caramel malt and rye spiciness with some bitter and dry ending.  Really nice and fluid tastes, mixed well and smooth!

Unlike the experience of many other raters, my bottle was extremely carbonated.  It had been sitting undisturbed on a shelf for many, many hours, but blew its top when I opened it.  Once it settled down a bit, the head was light tan, pillowy, and lasting.  Cloudy, orange-caramel color.  Aroma was of candy, brown sugar, and floral hops with a little spiciness.  The spicy character really came through in the flavor, along with pit fruit and alcohol.  Enjoyable, but not quite as good as expected from this excellent brewery.  If I encounter a less agitated bottle, Ill give the rating another shot.

Pours a hazy blood orange color with a thin halo of a head from the 12oz. bottle: Nose of vanilla, cardamom, warming alcohol, dried earth, and syrupy caramel with undertones of lavender. Medium bodied with little carbonation, leaving an incredibly smooth experience. Protruding tastes of dried pear and sweet honey, followed by a semi-delicate bitter earth feel. Pretty hot, but other than that, the alcohol is almost masked. Kind of. Drinkability: Incredibly balanced for a barley wine. A real treat. Pairing: Intensified dessert. Rebuy: Yes. #326 on 07032010, DG.
Had chance to try the 03 but none of the other years at lucky baldwins.The 03 was more brown/red in color while the 07 looks golden and more appealing.Fruity,thin head.

pours  cloudy light  amber colour with minimal head.  can sense a sweetness on the nose (like a candy).  This also comes through in the taste which reminds me of apricot jam, some plum perhaps and a hint of spice.  overall a sweet brew both literally and figuratively.  A very good barley wine my fav of the night vs mm, litork, lstab)

Bottled. Cloudy copper pour, huge, yellowish-white head. Nicely carbonated. Toffee caramel and alcohol nose. Big malty taste, candi sugar, toffee, with a mild hoppy finish, lots of alcohol notes. Great stuff!
330ml bottle from DK. Pours muddy mid amber colour with low amount of white head. Nose of apricot, citrus and cinnamon. Body is malty with notes of spice. Finish is long but satisfying.

Review #100 here on RB.

A: A rich brown-amber color with next to no head and some lacing.

S: Butterscotch, caramel, vanilla, oak, and a bit of alcohol. Some pitted fruits floating around as well.

T: A caramel and butterscotch sweetness, and some of the aforementioned fruits. A bit of bitterness and alcohol bite on the finish.

M: Full body, smooth and creamy mouthfeel, almost no carbonation.

D: Surprisingly high for a barleywine. Great array of flavors on this.
Pours an unclear, dark amber beer with a weak head. The aroma is sweet and fruits. The flavor is sweet. The palate is likewise sweet. Overall a good balanced and complex beer.

Copper colour, big tan head, lacing.
Aroma is sweet, full of dark fruit, jam , honey, hops and a sticky malt backbone.
Flavour is just lovely!! Alcohol, dark fruit, jam, honey, malts and a beautiful bitterness accompanied by a warming finish.
mouthfeel is lively with small bubbles and the liquid is slightly sticky.
This is not a beer, this is art!

Pours a murky brown after the foam settles from massive carbonation. Aroma is a little funk and some plastic. Massively overcarbonated, this beers flavors unfortunately match the off aroma. Infected bottle? I hope so, otherwise this is just bad beer.

Hair of the Dog Brewing Company--Fred--1998 Release--12 oz. Bottle--11.50% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Barleywine?  Big and WOW Rich.  Hazy red amber color. Sweet buttery body.  Smooth rich body finishes with alcohol bitter bite.  Fruitiness is minimal for such a big brew.  Smooth for strength and very flavorful.  Sampled 12/10/1998.

Hair Of The Dog Brewing Company--Fred--Belgian Golden Style Ale--2007	12 oz. Bottle--10.00% ABV--65 IBUs.  (3.5 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Golden--$2.99 Each.  Foamy dense lacy off white head.  Thick sediment.  Clear rich amber red color.  Sweet malt hop floral ester front.  Rich tangy rye spice sweet caramel complex body.  Hot EtOH hop spice end.  Too Much.  Sampled 12/8/2007.

12 oz bottle poured carefully into a snifter. I didnt see any sediment that others have mentioned. The color was bright and golden. The smell was hoppy and a little alcohol. The taste was really good and reminded me a little of Old Guardian. Strong ABV did not really get in the way. Delicious beer, wish I could get it here in CO.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-30-2007 16:45:59

An unclear reddish-brown beer with almost no head. The aroma was sweet, alcohol, & slightly fruity. The taste was a little sweet, caramel malt & I just could not get into this one. Will have to try again.

12 oz. bottle from Somewhere. Way too over-carbonated (and this has happened with other bottles as well). It was carbonated to the point of being un-pourable. Once everything has calmed down, it tastes smooth and silky. Tastes pretty dark for a "golden" ale. Notes of cough medicine, alcohol, cloves, heat, and vanilla.

Great clarity. Amber color. Nose is super rich and malty. A slight bit of tropical fruit, as well as a soft white pepper. The palate has a bright intensity of fruit on top of the malty rich base. It dries out mid palate, leaving an almost refreshing dry finish.

12 ounce bottle, Batch #76.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a hazy orange/amber color with a huge frothy off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both very good.  The head was so big, I had to let the beer settle in the glass a couple times before I was able to pour the whole beer into the snifter (its a 20 oz. DFH one).  Aroma is citrusy hops (orange peel), bready malt, apricots, earth and wood.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also some spice, candy sugar and a little bit of alcohol noticable too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its rich and creamy with high, but soft carbonation.  Drinkability is good, the soft carbonation makes this brew easy to drink.  I think this is a good beer, Id definitely buy this again the next time I can find it.

12oz bottle, batch 76. Pours murky iced tea color, topped with a medium sized ivory head. Aroma of caramel, earthy hops, and floral notes. Flavor is similar, with earthy and slightly grapefruit hops, pepper, caramel, rye and some smoke. Fairly bitter finish, with earth and grapefruit. Medium bodied and very drinkable.

Drank out of a tulip and a snifter. Huge head that lasted for ever. Light flowers and yeast on the nose. Medium to heavy on the hops balanced very well with malty sweetness. This is the golden example of a golden ale. Great beer brewed in honor of Fred.

355ml bottle (Oliver Twist, Stockholm)
Fairly dark reddy orange. Aroma that is aged and a bit woody, like a barley wine should be. Sweet malty, and very full, body. Beautiful ginger cake in the taste, touch of spice too. The retronasals are sherbetty from all the hops,and the finish is cakey. Some nutty bitter hops later. Perfect balance.

On tap at Toronado. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a white ring. Big herbal aroma, with malt, pine, sugar, and berries. Taste is rich, of wood, berries, sugar, and malt. Lingering rich sweetness. Big and very nice.
Thanks be to scrizzzzzzzzz.  Nice aroma.  Yeasty and tart.  Alcohol kick and highly carbonated.

The pour is beautiful in a sniffer. A huge frothy white head (almost like a thinner meringue) on top of a golden yellow/orange liquid. Sweet candy sugar, bready, malt, peach, and banana in the smell. Taste is big on candy sugar, sweet malt, peach, and a peppery finish from the alcohol and a a nice hop bite. I love HOTD and this beer is incredible. Thanks for brewing Alan Sprints.
Bottled 355ml. Murky appearance. Interesting, complex nose of banana, caramel and melon. Vanilla and caramel most prominent in the taste.
Bevuta al ma che siete venuti a fà.... niente da dire... probabilmente il miglior barley wine ke abbia mai assaggiato..

It pours dark, almost like the Belgian candi sugar it contains in liquid form. Ther is a frothy white beautiful head on top. The ABV is not smooth on the palate and the hops are very subtle. It has sweet and malty flavors balanced nicely as well.

Batch 77
Hazy orange with tons of sediment.  Huge pillowy head that never completely goes away, tons of bubbly lace.  Very sweet bready, grapefruity and peachy aroma - but relatively light.  Very thick and fluffy feel, high carbonation.  Slight alcoholy bite to start, with citrussy bitterness. Goes into sweet bready, peachy, and then ends in a little bit of a grassy hop bite.  Yeast adds a little funk throughout the palate and some phenol notes.  Great complex beer, alcohol is definitely evident - lots of pepper in the finish, but not overwhelming.

12oz capped, batch 9.  Opens with very faint sound of carbonation.  Pours much darker in color than other, newer, batches of Fred I have had.  Crystal clear light amber/toffee with a golden tint to it.  Basically still carbonation with just a few singular bubbles around the edges of my glass.  Nose is sweet with malty toffee, caramel and honey.  Also a good amount of breadiness with moderate signs of oxidation...white port, a touch of leather and faint tobacco leaf.  Some earthiness in there as well...like some pine, cedar and damp hay.  Feels somewhat thin at first due to basically no carbonation, but as it makes it way around my palate it becomes slightly syrupy and sticky.  Tobacco, sweet candied dark fruit, honey, biscuity up front and in the middle.  More of the white port comes out toward the end as well as the tobacco notes.  This beer is nothing like it is when fresh and I am not sure where this beer hits the sweet spot for me, but I am learning.  Listed over on HotD as being bottled 7-1-98...pretty damn amazing really.  Alan makes kick ass beer!
Bottle.   Peach, malt and peppery alcohol aroma.  Orange amber color with gigantic head and nice lacing.  Sweet orange/peach, light barley malt flavor - alcohol and white pepper finish.   Great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2010 Pours a hazy orange brown, with a great, lacy head. Aroma is sweet malt and spicy hops, cedar. Flavor-peppery rye, blood orange, alcohol, sweet and lively. Aftertaste is well balanced hops, a perfect juxtaposition to the fruity malty sweetness.

V.2003. On tap at Lucky Baldwins. Deep amber. Flowers, cant pinpoint aroma. Smells like curry and metal. Taste- complex, tropical fruits, floral, pepper, salty, spicy, malty goodness. Finishes full bodied, sweet, slightly syrupy. Wow.

Clear orange body topped by a creamy tanned head. Aroma is mostly nice too with light alcohol molasses and fresh tobacco. Some sweet dough in there as well. Flavor is heavy sweet and yeasty. Moderately bitter. Medium to full body; soft and syrupy mouth feel.
This was some heavy shit, man! Maybe a re-rate candidate on  a less comprehensive night.
(Bottle, courtesy of tarjei 12.12.2009)

Bottle from Whole Foods (Houston/Bowery) NYC. Bold amber body with thin, hoppy top. Malty and barly nose. Nice and warm toasty taste, with sweet fruits, molasses and caramel. Very taste and warms towards the end. High ABV noticeable at the end.

Poured an extremely overcarbonated golden yellow. 
Nose was slightly hoppy and dirty. Odd spicy scents. 
Taste was bad, I checked with brewer to see if batch was infected but was confirmed it wasnt. Bottle tasted terrible. Gross off flavors, slightly tart, fair amount of honey flavor, tastes like old spice cabinet.
An interesting BW, in that it was neither as hoppy in its flavors nor as dominated by alcohol in either the nose or taste, despite being heavily hopped and high in ABV.

12 oz bottle. Dark golden body with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, hops, dry fruit, wood and alcohol. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, raisin, honey, bitter and warming alcohol. Long and very sweet finish. A very sweet and strong beer thats smooth and warming. Soft carbonation and oily body, a beer for sipping.

12oz bottle, batch 75, via trade with SuzyGreenberg. thanks, ben! pours a murky copper with hints of gold and a thin off-white head with a delicate ring of lace. aroma is fantastic with huge, sweet notes of toffee, honey, and dark malts with fruit notes of raisin, date, and a hint of peach with subtle floral hop notes and cider spices peaking through as well. flavor is delicious as well with an initial sweetness of toffee candy, maple syrup, brown sugar, and molasses layered on top of spicy, herbal hops, dried figs and raisins, and subtle fruit notes of pineapple and lemon with a nutty, woody finish. palate is full bodied with mild carbonation and a pleasant alcohol warmth on the swallow. overall, an excellent and complex barley wine. would love to try barrel aged version!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2013 What an incredible nose! Warm apple pie, pineapples, bananas. A tropical cornucopia. Creamy and incredibly smooth on the palate with more fruit and toasty flavors. Weighty. Hard to find anything wrong with this beauty.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 Hazy very orange with a thick white head. Aroma is honey, berry, floral hop and brown sugar.  Taste is a perfect balance between sweet thick malt and bitter hops. Good smooth texture. ... Another bottle batch 80-  huge, massive pillowy head that continues to rise. Aroma is subtle, at least since there is still some foam on top. Taste has a pretty good amount of bitterness and also a thick malt body. Now I can get some aroma, there is cherry, citrus and alcohol, also some clove and honey. Very smooth beer. Wow, just saw that there are 10 different hops in this beer. The ratio of whatever hops they used works very nicely.

Brother Jeff brought several bottles to our family reunion is Colorado. Big collection of favorite childhood flavors: carmel, malt, honey, dates, and that old fashioned herbal candy melded with some nice bitter hops and alcohol. Great for a barley wine.

Bottle, thanks scrizzz! Foam rises out of the bottle, and a massive creamy bubbly head builds on top of a clear amber. Aroma is an odd mix of sweet caramely and sugary malts, spices, alcohol, apples and a slight sour note. Flavour is pretty massive. Loads of malt sweetness going on, but also a spicy bitter finish. Fairly big alcohol finish. Carbonation is pretty fizzy, way more than I like in a beer this big. Perhaps the bottle is infected? Not sure. Didnt like this all that much. Hot, and not really all that pleasant.

Bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks, Shawn!  Pours a hazy amber color with an absolutely massive off-white head that never stopped coming out of the bottle.  We tried it side-by-side with Fred from the Wood.  Aroma of sweet malt, honey, caramel, raisin, hops, brown sugar, and alcohol.  The flavor followed suit nicely, with notes of maple in addition to the above.  Medium-full bodied, with warming alcohol.  This is a nice barley wine, and like Shawn pointed out, like a toned-down version of FFTW, so it makes sense that this is the base beer.

12 oz bottle, batch 75, poured on 11/30/09.  Pours hazy dark gold/orange with beautiful one-finger eggshell head that lingers.  Aroma of vanilla, cardamom, caramel with undertones of lavender and earth.   Medium body with incredibly smooth carb.  Rich sweet honey up front, then a mild dry earthy bitter finish.  Palate is fantastic except for a hint of booziness.  Incredibly balanced and complex brew, but could probably use a bit of age to cool the hotness.

bottle from trade with wavers1-  thanks baker!    pours a  golden orange with a big foamy offwhite head.  Tasted side by side with fred from the wood. way different beers.   everything about this beer was seemed to be a less extreme version of fred from the wood.  the fruit, hops, and booze were all much more muted, which actually led to this being significantly more quaffable.  The fred from the wood was more exciting.  Both freds could likely benefit from additional time in the old closet.  who knows.

12 oz bottle shared by MrPickles - Nice amber pour with an off-white head. Aroma is tons of honey and a bit of booze, sweet malt, caramel, and toffee. Taste is sweet caramelly malt, honey, that transition into light herbal, grassy, and spicy flavors. The whole thing smooths out nicely on the finish, and it feels smooth and velvety in the mouth. My second HotD beer...mighty impressive.
From a bottle poured a hazy straw color with a good amount of head.  Nice strong malty sweet flavor with a quick finish.

19th August 2008. Hazy amber beer. Low carbonation. Sweet start with subtle peach and red fruit tones under the rapidly blooming hops which are juicy, smooth and strong. More peach and red fruit in the finish. Spicy aftertaste. Very tasty and very moorish.

Another nice offering from HOTD brought back by my buddy Brando. Cloudy mahogany colour with a fluffy head. Noticeable alcohol and sugar on the nose right away. Sweet and sticky in every way. Candi sugar- brown sugar and caramel notes on the palate as well as the nose. Like some hot buttered rum or something. Warm alcohol that flows smoothly down into the tummy. A wonderful beer for sure. i love my barleywines so this one hits the spot. Thanks brandon for bringing back the Fred.

Flaske; Et tsss lyder når flasken åbnes. Meget lovende tegn. Flot mørk ravfarvet klar øl med en del proteinklumper i bunden der dog er nemme at undgå. Koncentreret duft af blomme. Smagen er meget frugtet men med et lille skud tobak. Kompleks og en lækker mundfylde. Ville score langt højere hvis jeg var mere vild med frugten i øllen. Men man kan kende storhed når man ser den.
12 oz bottle from HOD dock sale - This is a pretty fantastic barley wine.  Not as much aroma as Id expect, but it does go down smooth.  It has a bit of a whiskey aftertaste, but in a good way.

Amber coloured with a fresh white head. Aroma when fresh is hoppy with a thick caramell foundation. Flavour is fat malty and quite bitter, still balanced though with a longlasting finish. Gets very fat and sweet with age, more english in other words. Very tasty either way with Hair of the Dogs typical fat malt character.

Reviewed 8/10/2009 (Bottle batch#35):

Pours a golden orange colored body, with a small white head, diminishing. Syrupy aroma, sweet like something. Strong aroma. Some kind of syrup. Smells good. Strong taste, old and musty tasting. Syrupy taste, like maple. Woody taste. Sweet aftertaste, almost cloying. Very tasty, doesnt overwhelm. Some alcohol bite. Sticky sweet aftertaste, like syrup. Really good, not quite a sipping beer, could have almost a whole pint without overwhelming.

Golden amber with a shy off-white and very bubbly head that settles kind of fast. Minimal lacings.

The smell is of caramel, candy and a hint of fudge. Lots of floral and grassy hop notes mixed with a doze of yeast (like white bread). Estery with notes of strawberries and tart berries and lemons. A hint of alcohol. The smell is rather hard to nail down and every breath seems to reveal different prominent characteristics - truly complex and enticing. All in all, a really good and interesting smell.

Lots of sweetness going on in the taste, the flavor is almost sugary. A lovely malt character with notes of mostly caramel, but also fudge. A gentle taste of candy ends the sweetness as a light fruity yeastiness and wood take over. The hops, although they have clearly starting to fade in this one, gather momentum and balance the sweetness nicely. Other than a general floral character, its hard to pick out any elements derived from the hops. Perhaps I get a hint of lemon. The finish is pleasantly bitter with complementary malty sweetness, spices and herbal alcohol.

Full-bodied and oh so smooth. The slick mouthfeel is just outstanding with a nice sticky finish. The only thing holding it back from a perfect five is a slightly too gentle carbonation.

A very good beer, definitely a sipper considering the sweetness, the comparatively prominent taste of alcohol in the finish and the smooth mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

A: Golden amber with a shy off-white and very bubbly head that settles kind of fast. Minimal lacings.

S: Caramel, candy and a hint of fudge. Lots of floral and grassy hop notes mixed with a doze of yeast (like white bread). Estery with notes of strawberries and tart berries and lemons. A hint of alcohol. The smell is rather hard to nail down and every breath seems to reveal different prominent characteristics - truly complex and enticing. All in all, a really good and interesting smell.

T: Lots of sweetness going on, the flavor is almost sugary. A lovely malt character with notes of mostly caramel, but also fudge. A gentle taste of candy ends the sweetness as a light fruity yeastiness and wood take over. The hops, although they have clearly starting to fade in this one, gather momentum and balance the sweetness nicely. Other than a general floral character, its hard to pick out any elements derived from the hops. Perhaps I get a hint of lemon. The finish is pleasantly bitter with complementary malty sweetness, spices and herbal alcohol.

M: Full-bodied and oh so smooth. The slick mouthfeel is just outstanding with a nice sticky finish. The only thing holding it back from a perfect five is a slightly too gentle carbonation.

D: A very good beer, definitely a sipper considering the sweetness, the comparatively prominent taste of alcohol in the finish and the smooth mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Thanks to riversideAK. Aroma contains a lot of caramel, butterscotch, alcohol. Hazy golden pour withe a moderate off-white head. Strong caramel flavor pairs with an equally strong earthy, dusty note. Butterscotch seems off here, as does a disharmony between the pronounced alcohol warming and the dustiness. Medium to full body, smooth, highly warming.

Batch 73.  Bottle from scrizz.  This pours out really thick, a golden-amber color and a huge khacki head with a ton of it staying on top.  Gobs of lacing left on the glass.  The aroma shows piney hops, caramel, toffee, dark fruits and a strong maple scent.  Theres also a floral presence in the nose that quickly takes a back seat.  The flavors are all over the place.  This requires more than a few sips to rate.  At first I didnt think it was overly complex but theres so much more to this the further I work through the bottle.  On one hand, the flavors are rather hoppy with spiciness and a fruity zest.  Then the next sip will be quite sugary showing lots of brown sugar and maple with some plum character and even molasses.  Theres just a lot going on and overall theres the right amount of bitter hops to counter the sweet flavors.  A great beer.  Thanks Clint!  I look forward to the wood aged version.

Bottle from Beerlando. Pours a hazy brown/gold. Nose is full of honey and distant herbal hops. The taste is pretty exciting, lots of honey notes to counterbalance the herbal floral notes. Definitely a ton of honey notes, though. Pretty tasty stuff...

Hazy brown pour with a sudsy white head. Aroma contains raisin, dark sugars, molasses, caramel banana, peach, mild citrus, and subtle dough. Flavor is exceptionally sweet with molasses and brown sugar coming through powerfully. Slight citrus complements a fruity cake note. Palate is rich, thick, and mildly effervescent with an awesome alcohol note in the finish. Goddamn.

Opaque brown pour with reddish tints. Aroma holds tons of caramel, brown sugar, molasses, raisin, and prune. Also notes of banana, peach, and a bit of orange, and even a touch of dough. Flavor is great; tons of brown sugar, caramel, toffee, and the rye malt comes through as well. Hop character is subtle, but present, with a bit of dry bitterness that complements the sweet malt characteristics beautifully. Palate is exquisite, probably my favorite part of this beer; smooth, creamy, but the alcohol is expertly applied at the finish, and it lingers perfectly on the tongue. Second excellent barley wine of the night.

@Freaktoberfest from bottle, pours brown-orange hazy with a medium head, powerful aroma of pine, grapefruit, peach and citrus, sweety with some cheese acidity and peach, finishes with grapefruit bitterness (quite intense), complex and sticky. Another great stuff from HOTD.

12 oz bottle into a tulip glass.  Its a gusher!  Overflowed upon opening.  Pours golden/orange with a huge frothy off-white head.  Aroma is massively sweet, with yeast, sweet doughy bread, caramel, and light fruit.  Taste is also sticky sweet, with heavy malt, fruit, and a hop bite at the end.  Mouthfeel is sticky and a bit syrupy.  One of the sweetest beers Ive ever had, a bit much, though clearly a quality brew.

Bottle from batch 75 at Monks Cafe. Pours a reddish orange color, mildly hazy with a small head. The aroma is cherries wood, alcohol fresh pear and crab apple tree. Flavor is anise candy and cherries with earthy tones, a little sweet but stunningly delicious.

Bottle at FFF. I rarely look at the bottle list at Floyds because the tap options always take precedent, but what a great surprise.  I went in essentially blind after being denied the sold-out Adam. I assumed it was a Belgian Golden given the bottle and massive white head, but the color was much deeper gold and murky.Aroma was dominated by sweet malt and PNW hops.  Unbelievably full body with surprisingly velvety carbonation. Flavor was malt heavy with tons of citrusy hops and a warm apricot finish. Alcohol is present but not dominant.  Fantastic beer.

Pours amber with a big fluffy off-white head. Notes of sticky hop resins, tropical fruit esters, white grape, and tangy citrus. Full to heavy bodied with moderate alcohol and lively carbonation. This was extremely intense, a bit more than I was expecting, and a bit rough around the edges.

Bottle at FFF brewpub.

Poured hazy copper color with a huge fizzy white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy sour citrus and earthy rye aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation and thin particles. Moderate to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy earthy sweet finish of moderate to long duration.

This is a complex standout beer.

Has an aroma of hops, apricot, prune, cherry, peach and olives.  Tastes of prune, apricot and citrus.  A little different than most barley wines, I can really notice a certain element of quality in this. Not to say barley wines are bad, but it really seems they went the extra mile making this one.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share! Batch #74. Pours a transparent burnt orange colour. The head is quite small and quickly forms a ring around my snifter. Aroma is very bright and fresh. Flowers, marmalade, soft fruits, ginger and a hint of alcohol. The taste is quite complex and subtle (for the style). Oranges, ginger, soft fruit, spices, and alcohol. Nice mouth feel. Not bad at all.

12oz bottle (Batch 76) served in a snifter.  Cap came off with a loud pop, and the beer was quite carbonated.  Poured a hazy golden orange with a huge head of rocky beige foam that hung around for an eternity.  Excellent rings of lacing.   The aroma was a beautiful mix of apricots, oranges, honey, golden apples, and a touch of perfumey alcohol.  The flavor started with clean malt and some rye spice, followed by tropical fruits, pears, apricot, golden raisins, and then some piney bite.  Layered and complex, but not overly complicated.  No trace of alcohol other than a little warmth.  Big, full-bodied mouthfeel but very smooth.  A nice amount of cleansing carbonation.  Dangerously drinkable.  You could sit and ponder the aroma and flavor all day, but this beer begs to be drunk.  Extremely enjoyable!
Fantastic Beer. Fruity start, hoppy finish, superb mouthfeel, and a wicked heed. Glass is empty and the head is still clinging to the rim. Me likey! Bottle @ 58F.

Thank you Alan Henderson for the tip on where to aquire this tasty brew.  Batch 76 Bottle.  Pours golden/amber with a huge foamy white head.  Bottle is over carbonated and I had to let it rest for awhile.  Hard to get past the strong alcohol presence in the aroma.  Let the beer warm and the nice aromas show-up.  Toffee, pine, and dark fruits on the nose.  Very nicely balanced.  Pine resin, sweet caramel, honey, and orange peel come to mind in the flavor.  Complex but all the flavors work nicely together.  Full mouthfeel with a lingering sweet finish, slight alcohol burn as well.  Needs to age a bit, but very enjoyable as is.

On-Tap @ Horse Brass poured into Shaker glass.

pours a slightly glowing but cloudy orange color with a creamy off-white head with good retention and thick lacing down the glass. The aroma has caramel, citrus hops and is tangy. The flavor has citrus hops, malt, nuttiness, spices, toffee and finishes with a soft bitterness. Its a creamy, full-bodied beer and is very drinkable. Very unique beer overall and is one of the beer that really made me want to get closer to the Oregon beer scene. Fred from the Wood is more fragrant but this is easy drinking.
UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 Hair of the dog......FRED......... is the bomb!    One of the few American beers that that matches the quality and complexity of Belgian beers.

12oz bottle shared by matt7215 at his place, thanks for the share Matt! This one was very impressive. Pours a very hazy straw gold with a huge white head, very active carbonation and some ugly little yeast floaties. The aroma is a huge whiff of primarily American hops, super sharp, but with some nice malt and yeast presence to add some balance. Highly enticing. The flavour hits the palate like a hoppy train wreck right off (in a good way, because some train wrecks are good......), almost puckering, yeast adds even more dryness but some grainy Pils malt comes in for some sweetness which is really tasty. Any rye malt in here is merely an afternote. I think the Pils malts actually work really well with the dry hoppy aspects, yet without seeming like an Imperial Pils. Very big feeling but still pretty drinkable for the style. Thanks again Matt.
glorious, thick, hoppy, malty, caramelly, everything you want is in here, yet still smooth. Bottle from a tasting at the house of chris Montelius

Sampled with curly at scottyps condo.  Courtesy of Lithy.  Pours a hazy dull orange with clearish white head. Fruity and citrusy, hoppy, and malty.   Massively carbonated.  Good job of covering the alcohol.  A lot is going on here.  Ive never had a beer quite like this before.
Bottle. Amber pour with tan head. Spices, hop, and malt flavors. Cant wait to try from the wood, may mellow sharper notes.
bottle, pours hazy orange medium off white head.  Aroma is sweet peach and candy sugar.  Sweet apricot and orange with sweet malt and a light bitter spice finish.  Solid.

The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass modest turbid, almost no head. Very complex and alcoholic aroma. Starts very strong, sweet-hoppy, quite aromatic-hoppy. Shows more and more the alcohol, finish also woody-spicy. Goes down burning. Excellent!

Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours a beautiful amber color with no head to speak of.  Lots of sweet malt on the nose, spicy with caramel.  Sticky sweet body, caramel interlude, finishing with a biting hop bitterness.  Epic.

on tap at rogue in portland. awesome awesome awesome. i was there to enoy fresh rogue and spent most of my time with this little guy... wrecked me though. 10%, woah. i dont know how i would ever handle HOTDs 29%er.

Bottle batch 71 thanks to Cletus!  Pours a hazy slight amber deep orange with thick creamy off-white head, lots of lacing.  Aroma of citrus hops, slight floral, strong malt backbone, molasses, caramel, some sweetness, and some dried fruits.    Flavor matches well and comes together so nicely.  Slight alcohol warmth, but just enough to let you know its there.  Mouthfeel is slightly slick with medium heavy body.  One of the few barley wines I have truly enjoyed to date.

Batch 69.  Bottle pours golden brown with a huge head.  Aroma of caramel, raisins, and sweet dark fruits.  Grassy hops bitterness that quickly fades to alcohol burn and sweetness.  Alot of toffee and caramel notes and continues burn.  A bit sticky in its mouthfeel.  Sweet molasses and maple aftertaste.
Huge head on this one! Batch 73 12 oz bottle. Very sweet for a 10% brew. Strong caramel malt flavors. Good brew

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2009 Bottle from batch 59. Pours a dark goldish color with a little white head to it. Has a nice carmel, wood and some kind of fruit in the smell. The taste is just like the smell. Carmel being the prodominate flavor

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2013 What an excellent beer. Ive always admired Hair of the dog for their unique beers, and to me, this is the one that puts it all together beautifully. It pours with a golden color and a giant, fluffy, whipped cream like head. It smells like beer candy. Caramel, toffee and light, dry pilsner malts show through nicely in the aroma. The two finger head has hardly diminished at all after a few minutes. The taste is amazing, with sweet caramel, butterscotch, rum, and a complex spicy character. A very interesting combination of Belgian, pilsner, and American hoppy beers. It works well for me. It finishes with a dry, bitterness. Great beer .
Batch 87 (most recent batch, within a year of bottling) tasted on 1/18/13. The cap pops fiercely and it pours almost like an infected bottle. Tons of foam and not much beer. It has an orange/copper color with an off white head. The foam sticks around forever but slowly subsides after a while. The aroma is decidedly fruity with a lot of rye malt. Orange, grapefruit, pineapple, peach and rye spice stand out. Dried pineapple slices, big time. The flavor is very strong with fruit, rye and bitterness. The body is full and the carbonation is perfect. Powerful and tasty. 4.0   ..
Batch 84 tasted on 1/18/13 side by side with the newer vintage detailed above. It pours the same orange/copper color, only the head is much more reasonable. Nice and thick/lasting, but it doesnt overwhelm the beer. The aroma is outstanding. Dried apricots, pineapple, juicy peaches, a touch of brown sugar with a wonderful sweet toffee and caramel background. Maybe a bit of nutty oxidation, but it serves this beer well. The flavor is much more of a barleywine than the newer vintage. Medium to low carbonation with lots of toffee, caramel and a bit of sherry with apricots, peaches, pineapple, etc The main difference between this and the newer bottle is the malt complexity comes to the foreground melding beautifully with the fruity hop profile. Ill be aging this one (along with most HotD beers) from now on!  4.2

Bottle from Lone Hill Liquor.. Batch 73.. Cracked the bottle and got a slow gush...Poured like half the bottle and got like a 4 finger head...Pours an orange amber with a fluffy white head...Aroma is honey, fruit and alcohol.. Flavor is caramel, fruit and that rye bitterness.. I felt like it was a little over carbonated but still good.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2009 Vertical tasting with csbosox of Batch 49 (shared by csbosox, bottled 19-June-03), Batch 67 (purchased at Bottleworks in Seattle, bottled 26-Sept-07), and Batch 70 (purchased at Bottleworks in Seattle, bottled 1-March-08).  Thanks for the information Alan!
Appearance:
Batch 49 - hazed ruby orange, small off white head that falls quick. Cloudiest of the three.
Batch 67 - slight haze ruby orange, visible fine carbonation intermittently floats up. One inch white head falls with some lacing.
Batch 70 - golden orange, mostly clear. One inch white head falls quick. Nice lacing.

Aroma:
Batch 49 - toffee, dark dried fruit, some lighter peppery yeast. Currants. Really soft and enveloping. Beautiful.
Batch 67 - caramel toffee, soft apple fruit, straw and hay. Much milder aroma than the 49. Nice, just not as much personality as 49.
Batch 70 - citrus fruit, some bright caramel honey sweetness. Noticeable alcohol heat. This smelled noticeably younger than the others.

Flavor:
Batch 49 - really full and developed caramel toffee, followed by an earthy spice type flavor that was maybe the rye, hard to pin down.  Finish is the currants and dried fruits. Finish lingers a bit and gets some dirty earthiness in it. Oxidation is evident, but melds really nicely.
Batch 67 - toffee, same rye character as 49, woody, organic, mineral, spice black pepper in the end. Alcohol mildly evident way in the back.
Batch 70 - bright citrus and caramel maltiness, the woody resiney rye is behind that. Very evident heat.  As with the nose, it was remarkable how much younger this tasted than the 67.

Palate:
Batch 49 - mostly flat. Medium to heavy body, coats mouth perfectly with a nice lingering sweetness.
Batch 67 - mostly flat. Soft and velvety, medium to slight heavy body. Lingering heat in the finish.
Batch 70 - mostly flat. Much thinner than the others, bright alcohol heat in the finish.

Overall:
Batch 49 - really nice, very much in that zone of aged sweetness and melded oxidation that I like my Barley Wines.
Batch 67 - had some of the characteristics of the 49 that I liked, as well as some of the characteristics of the 70 that I did not.  Still nice, but not to the level of the 49.
Batch 70 - disjointed and weirdly hot.  Still an interesting enough beer, but really came into its own with age.

Final Notes:
It was very interesting to see the progression of time with this beer.  It certainly improved with age, which has become increasingly rare for me with aged beers.  Thanks again for sharing the Batch 49 with me Chris, it really made this tasting.
Scores:
Batch 49 - 9,4,8,4,17 - 4.2
Batch 67 - 8,4,8,4,15 - 3.9
Batch 70 - 7,4,7,3,14 - 3.5

Rating #1300.  Batch 73.  Bottle thanks to scrizzz.  Pours a clear bright orange color with an enormous off white foam that collapses very slowly.  Some small white particles will creep in if you pour the bottom of the bottle.  The aroma is fruits, peaches, pears, apples, brown sugar, sweet maltiness.  The taste is sweet again, sugar, maple syrup, brown sugar, then candied fruits, more apples, rum soaked raisins, caramel.  A nice beer.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 Wow. About as sugary as a tall glass of southern sweet tea. Gross. Just plain gross, imo. All the wonderful fruity barley wine flavors are bludgeoned by the excessive sugars. Forget candy sweet, this is concentrated syrup sweet. I just cant take it. It tastes like a gum drop with molasses on it. Super excited to try this one, too bad I couldnt take more than three sips of it.

Batch #75. Pours a hazy deep orange with little head to speak of. Aroma of citrus, orange peel, hops, and pina colada. Enters the mouth creamy and smooth, but as soon as I being to swallow, a sharp alcohol tinge emerges. Flavors is not your typical citrus and hops in that theres not a floral hops element to it. Theres a whiskey and hops finish which feels a bit overdone. I love how it starts but hate how it finishes.

Lots of Bottle courtesy of theisti. Pured staight down the middle and got a huge fluffy head that settled really slowly. Aroma is malty fruit, nice yeast balance and a lot of bittersweet (molasses?). Lots of honey, mango balance a good hop profile in the flavor, with significant alcohol heat to finish. While I couldnt drink very many of these, its a fine brew. Thanks, Tim.

There are not many out there like this one.  A melding together of american and english barleywine styles with the hoppy spice, butterscotch,  and.smoky creaminess all coming to play in this one.  Like a scotch ale on steroids.  Aroma and flavor have heavy notes of dark rum, light scotch and a present alcohol kick that isnt intrusive at all, it just feels right for this beer.  I wish I knew how old this one was so I could duplicate the experience.  Thanks Hair of the Dog. 12 oz.
Very smooth flowery aroma. Excellent "beer commercial" head. Starts with a caramel flavor which leads into a neutral almost honey flavor. finishes with a politely bitter finish. Excellent.

Fairly new bottle. Fruit hops and alcohol intertwine in harmony. There is some pale raisiny fruit but also dry apricot on the aromas, and a toffeeish scotch-like harmony in the malt flavors. Hops seem austerely steely yet silky. The feel is rich, dry and texturally stimulating - good fine carbonation. This brewer amazes me.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2009 [Bottle, batch 62] shared by STLWill. Pours a clear amber with a large beige head. Aroma is sweet honey, a touch of citric hops, and some alcohol. Flavor is honey, sweet malts, and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel. This tastes like it would be a lot better fresh.
Rerate from a fresh bottle. Gushing bottle, hugely carbonated. Golden color, aroma has lots of hops, but is dominated by sweet malt and candi sugar, and quite a bit of alcohol. Flavor matches well, but is just a little too sweet and carbonated for my tastes.

12 oz bottle, thanks hanniku and Timo A! Murky yellow brown color with vanishing head. Sweet, warming, toffeish, nutty, raisiny and perfumed aroma with notes of tropical fruits. Bittersweet, nutty, toffeish and warming flavor with apricot and orange marmelade. Thick viscous body with low carbonation. Excellent, but the wood version is even better.

Bottle with much love to BMan1113VR! This beer smells so damn wonderful...Caramel, pineapple/mango and sweet nectar/honey smells dominate.
