peaches, malt and brown sugar, vanilla and candi sugar.  Some honey and dark fruits as well, some funky cherry flavor.  Big aftertaste.  pretty intense

Pours a darkish amber color, topped by a thick and soft head of tan foam. Great head retention and lacing. Lots of malt and fruit in the aroma – plum (prune?) and fig. 

The flavor is thick with toffee, caramel malt, dark honey, and orange pith. These flavors are very full, and last into the finish, where they are joined by strong black tea and buckwheat. Some hop bitterness kicks in with the aftertaste, and there is a definite alcohol presence. Full bodied, solid carbonation - fantastic beer for sipping.

on tap at the Hop Devil Grill. Amber, slighlty hazy, small off white head.  Aroma is citrus and floral hops along with a good deal of caramel, some fruits such as apple.  Taste is caramel and fruity, citrus, almost got some pineapple like notes.  Alcohol warm in the finish, but pretty well hidden overall.  complex and extremely enjoyable.

Batch 62, thanks to bditty187.

Pours a hazy burnt amber, with a very substantial three finger head that takes forever to settle to a thick layer of foam, leaving behind a solid sheeting of lace.

Smell; the first thing I smell is bitter hops, which is good since I like a hoppy barleywine. Caramel and toffee maltsare there as well as a little bit of dark fruits.

Taste; the hops are there, but not really as strong as the nose lead me to believe. Even so, their presence is welcome and not disapointing at all. The caramel malts come out nicely and adds a very syrupy sweetness to smooth out the hops. In the finish theres a bit of cherries, and other darks fruits. Mouthfeel is defintely on the full side, with a good drinkabiltiy, that would be higher without the syrupy sweetness.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Tap- Dark, hazzy, and cloudy. Plenty of taste, carbonation, lacing, and hops everything combined in one. Pours a amber brown color with a bit of a copper look to it. Smells great, doughy, chocolate and oaked. Taste is of dry fruit, bitter chocolate and rye bread. Good hops that are a bit spicy and chewy. Great beer!

Bottle (Batch 66) at home - shared with myself....hmmm.. Clear reddish - white head. Aroma: Flowery, pine, resin, citrus, straw, malty. Taste: Sweet, dry, straw, pine, grass, citrus, grape, resin, flowery, caramel, malty, wood, and a lovely alcho-burn. This is very nice - a little bit of everything  - The Best Of Both Worlds !!!!

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 Im sorry i didnt note the batch # !!

Bought in Portland. Thoroughly enjoyed this barley wine. somebody said it already in the reviews... complex and smooth. I agree. 

Love it !

Bottled (Batch 63, thanks kenb!). Hazy nut brown colour with big foamy off-white head, leaves much lace. Aroma is lots of hops, caramel, some alcohol, yeast and fruits. Flavour is fruits, hops, slight alcohol and spices. A very nice beer, as nothing hits you as if it attacks you, but comes very smoothly creeping. Complex and smooth, both in aroma and flavour. Totally kickass!

Bottled (batch #63)
Hazy ruby red color, thick and steady brown head, lace. Hoppy nose with rye and brandy notes. Liquerish mouthfeel, very hoppy like double-IPA, but sweetness cuts the most of aggressive bitterness. Long toffeish sweet and bitter aftertaste. The beer to enjoy slowly in the front of fire place. Balanced and tasty.

Very thick and impressive pour, with a fairly massive head filled with small bubbles. Reddish-brown. It simply smells alive. Citrus and woodsy aroma. Very bitter thanks to the alcohol burn, with strong notes of lemon peel and perhaps tropical fruit. Highly unusual structure, which attacks you first with bitterness, then sharp sweetness, then a bit of spiciness. Very complex, smooth and intriguing.

Deep amber orange beautiful body, huge creamy off white head; Huge very US-like nose. 10 different hops doesnt necessarily bring complexity and depth and in this beer all it brings is unclearity, there are so many different hop aromas that it is impossible to describe, ripe orange juice and peel is very apparent; Huuuge soft big bubbled carbonation, soft textured full body, sweet and bitter; Long finish that starts soft and sweet and quickly becomes very bitter and a little dry still sweet though, lots of hop aromas. I would love to taste this beer made with 2 hops from 1 country!

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2006 Batch 65: Unclear amber/orange with large lasting white creamy head. Aroma of hops/citrus/yeast & flowers. Spicy taste with warmth from alcohol. Incredible lacings. Filling soft body. Easy sweetness from malts that balances fine with the high bitterness. Lasting strong bitter finish! YESSIR! 
ps. Thanks to he knows who!

Wow - I really dig the aroma of this one. Complex hoppiness with lots of citrus crest, flowers and something, that reminds me of certain rums - not quite sure what - could sit with this in the glass for hours, but the show must move on. Most of the scents are repeated in the flavour with a very nice kick of bitterness and a lovely full body - yummy. Nice notes of brown sugar, vanilla (?) and caramel. Lingers in the mouth for ages. Absolutely stunning beer.

Oh yeah - nice white lasting head, but tons of sediment, which drags the appearance quite a bit downwards. But hey - Ill just close my eyes.
Bottle. 33cl.  Candy candy candy....i love you. Aroma a bit like a dolle, a bit hazy, long bitter after tast. good strong head.
Clear amber with slight cobber notes and good pale yellow head. Hops, spice, cane sugar, grass and herbal. Alot of taste of hops and sweetness but still very balanced. Beautiful!

Batch 63. Deep cidery brow color with chunky sediment and creamy tan head.  Lovely floral and citrus aroma.  Nice balance of hopiness and sweet with fairly thick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is apparent but not overbearing. $3.50/12oz

Poured a murky copper with a creamy, lacing slightly off white head.  Strong aroma of malts and pine.  Sweet flavor, honey and candy, but also malty with brown sugar.  Finish had heat, thick and syrupy but also a touch of maple.  Good dessert beer.
Bottled. Amber coloured with a medium sized head. A bit sweet with notes of citrus, caramel and alcohol. Hints of dark fruits.

Bottle. Fluffy white lasting head. Hary orange body.  Peach hops aroma. Alcohol is very dominant. Tried hidden by high hops bitterness plus carbonation. In vain in my opionion.  I definately do not like the taste of alcohol. Sorry mates.

bottle from santa: Pours a nice amber color, almost brown. A nice white head formed. Smell has a slight citrus smell, with some caramel smell in there as well. Taste is smooth, with some nuttiness to it and a lingering sweetness to it. There is a nice warmth to this one, not overpowering at all. I like this beer.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2007 Bottle, batch 59. Hazy amber/orange with huge head. Leaves medium lacing as it slowly dissipates. Wonderful aroma of caramel, cotton candy and floral hops.  Tastes of carmel, butterscotch, dark fruits and a little hops. A little alcohol warmth. Wonderfully complex to try to describe. And to think I was worried about not aging this. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation. So good. So very good.

Pour is deep reddish gold with soft off-white head.  Aroma if hoppy with fruit, pine, spice, and caramel.  Nice flavor if caramel, sweet malt, dark fruit, toffee, vanilla, and hops.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Damn good.

12 ounce bottle.  Batch 60.  Murky tawny orange with a creamy beige head.  A total minajory of pine, spice and resin.  Nicely blended flavors.  The betterness is mild, yet it demands attention.  Creamy palate.  Long finish.  Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours with an organe color and is quite hazy. The head is medium and retains well. Very nice aromas of craamel, toffe and malts. The flavor profile is dominated by toffe, malts perhaps a hint of vanilla and some hops in the background. Very nice motuhfeel, the alcohol becomes more pronounced when the beer warms up.

"Fred" pours with a massive head and, as such, it took forever to pour this one into the glass. When we finally did, we find a light brown to medium amber colored body, topped off with a huge, light-brown head. Good lacing behind a mostly lasting head. Hazy body. Aromas are of light malts with a hint of molasses, light hops with grass notes, and alcohol. Initial taste is lightly sweet, finishing with a boldly moderate sweet. Medium on the palate, were left with a creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a moderate alcohol tinge.

Reviewers notes: "Batch #54, taking forever to pour, you can taste the alcohol in this one, a tricky golden ale that is anything but"

Bottle thanks to footbalm: Brown in color with an off white head. Aroma, some alcohol, very malty, brown sugar, molassas, caramel. Flavor, sweet, with some smoky/tobacco notes, some slight hops in there, but they are really in the background. Very smooth and drinkable.

Batch #60. Pours a deep amber with a frothy off-white head. Lots of sediment in the glass and a bit left in the bottle. Aroma is sweet malty caramel and is very nice. Flavor is very malty with hints of dark fruity with a nice hoppy bitterness and warming alcoholic finish. Overall its a very good brew.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2008 One to slowly guide your head onto the pillow, or the floor.  Rusty orange in color and completely opaque.  Aroma of alcohol, caramel, candy, flowers, barrels and barrels of scotch, and a slightly citrusy edge.  Like a boozy candy store.  Flavor is intensely woody, with peat, musty autumn leaves and a strong tobacco finish, crushed with sweet malt.  Thick and rich mouthfeel like swallowing the remnants of centuries-old wild honey. 8/4/8/4/17 4.1  

Batch 63, likely from late 04 or early 05.  A peppering of grainy sediment through a firey orange body; a generous, gooey raft of white.  Aroma first is like a french dessert white wine; full of floral tones, honey, and delicate fruit character.  Citrus fruit, white fruit, tropical fruit, candied fruit.  Bursting with fine trimmed detail.  Tanned musty leaves, sandalwood, and cinammon lend a restrained counterpart of rustic, smoky sweetness.  Yeasts layer thickly underneath; everything swarms together warmly on this chunky core of sweet dough.  Apple cider vinegar and fresh cut grass further down.  Beautifully full at first, and fading slowly given some breathing.  Flavor seems simpler.  Good vodka.  Honey crusted grilled rye.  Pineapple.  Floral perfumes.  Oak and almost lactic tartness; pear skins, vanilla, sweet pine smoke.  Mid palate is a milky softening; a retreat of sorts.  Pine bitterness and cloying peppermint cream candies.  Mouthfeel is somewhat sharp with carbonation; doughy, dense, firm.  Ludicrously high drinkability on this one.  Finishes with some citrus, peppercorns, and rye bread.  Well aged. 8/4/8/4/17 4.1

(Bottle (batch #54) from Julios Liquors (MA), cellared for 7 mos. after purchase) Pretty rich stuff, great barleywine...Pours a murky amber with a couple inches of soft, pillowy light amber-tinted cream head that recedes to about 1/4" and just stays. Aroma is malty rock sugar candy. Palate is smooth and full, head is creamy. Some pillowy lacing. Taste is malty and sweet, rock candy flavor with some pine in the finish. Some alcohol burn. A quality brew, very satisfying.

12 oz Bottle-Batch 62-Trade w/after4ever. Good solid beer, pours a cloudy orange color w/a lot of lacing which lasts thru the beer. Somewhat reminiscant of a Belgium, more carbination than a typical Barley Wine. Spicey, fizzy, w/some citrus. Very enjoyable brew-its no Doggie claws, but not much else is!! Thanks for this one Tom!!!

Had to try this because my dogs name is Fred. Batch # 59. Poured a deep amber color with a big pillowy head that lasted through the entire drink. Great lacing, too. Aroma of fruits, yeast, malts. Flavor was fruity (apples, grapes), malty, yeaty carbonation with a hop bitterness in the finish. Mellow and smooth body, warming alcohol. Real delicious brew, quite a different barleywine.

Bottle. Thx JM from the madness gathering.  Aroma sweet caramel and floral.  Poured a cloudy brown.  Flavor was sweet, caramel, apple and toffee. Palate was good nice and warming. Overall very tasty indeed.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Bottle/Batch 65.  Dark copper color with a small off white, foamy head (I followed directions and poured slowly to leave the considerable sediment in the bottle).  Aroma is caramel and butterscotch.  Taste sweet and spicy with a bitter finish.  Tastes to me like sort of a cross between a Barleywine and a Belgian Tripel.  Its an interesting beer thats obviously well made, but nothing Id like to drink often.
UPDATED: AUG 5, 2007 Will re-rate next chance I get - did not care for this, maybe was the bottle.
On Tap at Hair of the Dog Brewing Company Pours out a hazy copper topped with a off white head. Very nice barley wine. A very nice caramel and sweet tast to this one.

Bottle, 12 ounces, batch 63, trip to Beers of the world (Rochester) with Dum, Ian and Lubière, purchased on August 28, 2006; eye: burnt orange with amber reflections, nice creamy beige head made up of tiny bubbles, nice effervescence, lightly hazy, floating particles, lacing; nose: quite flowery, caramel, quite hoppy (floral), alcohol, syrup; mouth: thick, concentrated, syrupy, concentrated dark fruits, caramel, malt, quite powerful hops, finale in bitter hops shouldered by alcohol (pepper) with presence of concentrated caramel, quite sweet and bitter, full body, creamy and sticky texture, good carbonation; overall: impressive

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille, 12 onces, batch 63, voyage à Beers of the world (Rochester) avec Dum, Ian et Lubière, acheté le 28 août 2006; oeil : orange brûlée avec des reflets ambrés, belle mousse beige crémeuse et faite de petites bulles, belle effervescence, légèrement voilée, dentelle; nez : très floral (fleurs), caramel, très houblonnée (floral), alcool, liquoreux; bouche : épais, concentré, liquoreux, fruits foncés concentrés, caramel, malt, houblon assez puissant, finale en houblon amère appuyé par lalcool (poivre) avec présence dun caramel concentré, assez sucrée et amère, corsé, texture crémeuse et collante, bonne carbonatation	28 septembre 2006	Impressionnant

Batch 63. Pours a hazy/murky orange with off-white head. Huge aroma of floweryness and a caramel maltyness. Very thick and dense beer. Rich creamy toffee like malt flavors and a flowery aspect. Very gritty earthy element and an herbal hop bitterness, with a touch of woodchip. Alcohol burn is strong on the throat. Complex, nicely done.
Creamy citrus aroma.  Big off white head.  Slightly lighter than most barley wines I am used to.  Thick, malty, alcoholic with a slightly spicy aftertaste.  Full bodied with a quick finish.
Rich and malty. Hazy orange/brown in color. Taste was sweet and slightly sour, also very malty. Slight alcohol finish.

12 oz. bottle, batch 54.  This pours a burnt glowing orange brown with enourmous frothy ever-lasting light-orange head.  The aroma is deceptively light and fruity.  There are grapes, apples, maltiness and more.  The flavor is intensely strong, with quite a (good) alcohol kick.  It is creamy/oily and quite sweet, with a bitter-sweet aftertaste that just refuses to quit.  Excellent.
Good brewery, interesting U.S. Ales tastes. VEry strong, brown in colour, with good foam and some bubbles.

Batch 63. This cloudy copper ale poured with a fluffy off-white head, eliciting a fruity malt aroma. Although it is advertised as a golden ale, it looks and tastes more like a barleywine. It is a warm and full-bodied brew, with a definite alcohol finish and a sharp hop bite. The complex flavor lingers on the tongue long after the beer has been quaffed. This is a unique drink that begs to be sipped, so as to enjoy the various and everchanging flavor elements.

Bottle. Cloudy burnt orange with a quickly diminishing head, leaving a thin sheet of lacing.  Some floating particles.  Initial whiff was almost tequila-like, but aroma then became reminiscent of a brandy soaked raisin pudding or cake--Dark caramelized fruit, brown sugar, candied rind, nuts and alcohol.  Flavor of sweet brown sugary malt (due to the rye I imagine), with a bit of zesty hop in the bakground.  Slightly oily palate.  Some smokiness and alcohol warmth on the finish, along with some more tangy hops sneaking by.  Im not much of barleywine connoissseur, but I liked this a good bit.

12 oz. bottle from Shoreline.  Batch #63.  Drank on 8/2/06.  Bottle conditioned.  Slightly cloudy with some floating chunks.  Dark orangish copper, but not quite amber.  1+" creamy light tan head.  Drops slowly to a pretty thick layer of foam.  Good lacing.  Aroma - decent strength - mostly orangy citrus, some sweetness, and a little bit of wine-like character.  Some of what makes me think there will be a sourness or tartness in the beer.  Rye?  Flavor - High up front bitterness. On the tongue mainly I get some sweetness, but also some citrus, some sharp bitterness, and a faint bit of alcohol.  This beer probably has the most complex after swallow mix of flavors Ive ever had - some citrus, some alcohol warmth, tiny bit of tartness, and then it moves to a sweet, carmelly, almost molasses-like flavor that changes and stays around for a long, long time.  Palate - pretty full-bodied, almost chewy in the mouth.  A little warmth.  Good, avg. carb.  Overall - Very interesting beer.  Looks good, although cloudy with some floaties - Darker than I expected from the bottle calling it a golden ale.  Good aroma, although heavy on the citrus.  Tons and tons of complexity in the flavor - love that.  Palate is good for the beer.  Definitely makes me want to try their other beers and have a few more of this one - I dont think I can get HOTD here.

Batch 65. 12 oz bottle from Liq Sol. Pours a hazy copper with a huge 5 finger beige head that lasts forever. Mild aroma of lemon, vanilla and butterscotch. It tastes like it smells with some added caramel, citrus hoppiness, and alcohol coming through in the end. Tons of malt and tons of hops and yeast. Sweet but not cloying. lemon/orange hops kick in heavily in the aftertaste. A bit of acidity in the aftertaste as well. Almost seems like a nice Imp IPA. Is this really a BarleyWine? Wowe, best one i have had yet. Well balanced, and easy to drink for being 10% abv!

Batch 56. Pours a nice golden orange with thick tan head that lingers throughout entire glass, and leaves decent lacing. Aroma was a mixed bag of malty sour dark fruit, and citrusy hops. Flavor early accentuated this blend perfectly. As beer warmed at mid-glass, the 10% alcohol made its presence known in the taste. Finish was a good blend of dry, sour, and bitter, that left me wanting more. Hair of the Dog did very well once again, just pod that I cant get their beers in Atlanta.

Batch 63.  Pours a clear rich red amber with a towering white head, settling into a rocky mass.  The nose is truly exceptional.  Big sweet rounded, though not cloying in the least, malt.  Balance is achieved by a culmination of sharp spicy rye and slightly grapefruit seed hops.  There is a strong underlying fruitiness (reminiscent of guava and slightly pineapple?), which I wouldnt have thought of working with the rye so well.  The palate is truly top notch.  Thick and viscous with low carbonation, though still a bit creamy.  Even a bit slippery/chewy.  Near perfection.  The flavors are truly a kick in the mouth.  Rabid rye dominates this incredibly sweet deep malt.  The spice compliments the pungent grapefruit seed hops.  Theres some grass, tropical fruit, and a slight touch of alcohol.  Perhaps some more or less tannic (reminiscent of tea?) flavors appear in the finish.  the aftertaste quickly becomes amongst the most hoppy and bitter (in a very good way) experiences.  Perhaps there is even some roast in the aftertaste.  Even my lips taste bitter.  The alcohol warming kicks in a bit later than in most beers.  Truly complex.  Though Im not a big fan of hoppy barleywines, this is clearly one of my favorite beers to date.  I think this is because this reminds me much more of a strong IIPA than a barleywine.  In any case, I wish I could get this stuff in my state!  Oh, and how is this Belgian?

Cant complain about the appearance, it has a clear orange-brown color with a large white head.  This beer has lots of rye and huge hops, especially in the aroma but also in the flavor.  There is also a good deal of alcohol, sweet caramel and toffee.  The palate is creamy and thick.  The rye, along with some bitterness, lingers for a while.  I thought it was an excellent beer!

Bottle from...secret admirer?  Cherries and oakwood aroma, sublime, fruity cornucopia, not the boring coria-sugar the "special golden ale" moniker brought to mind.  In lower light it looked more opaque brown than deep golden, though I did include a portion of the yeast, the beer was close to this colour without it as well.  It has a sharp,crisp sfresher coriander and brown sugar, with cherries, oak, flowers, quality alcohol; as it warms, opens up to a green apple hoppiness.  Alcohol is warming from the start, and is has a beefy (thick & flavorful) mouthfeel, and a lasting delicious finish.  lots of unique flavor, yet you can still detect nice hops and yeast underneath.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 12 oz. bottle- color of mahogany , with a thick tan head - nose of brown sugar , dust , roasted malts , apricots , and raisins  taste of coffee grounds , caramel , malts , and slight hops in back palate - body slightly chewy, and acidic  aftertaste of bitter hopps ,  and molasses

MMM! If only all American Barley Wines were done like this! It was a pleasure to meet Fred!

Appearance: Pours a golden caramel color.

Smell: Sweet and spicy. A bit of yeast and caramel dominate the nose followed by a nice whiff of alcohol.

Taste: It had a nice spicy citrus fruitiness sitting beside the toasted brown sugar character; Fantastic.

Mouthfeel: If you are a liquor fan or a fan of the Barley Wine style in general you will have no problem with the boozyness and find the beer very smooth.

Drinkability: I really like big beers. This would hardly be a session beer but it is easy drinking IMO. Well done Hair of the Dog Brewing Company.

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!
Had this at HotD on July 28th, 2006.  Hops, hops, hops. very complex.  IBUs hit straight off the bat!  hazy golden color.  aroma of hoppiness, very nice beer.  Perfection.
63.  Light malty sweet aromas.  Alcohol and grassy flavors with a yeast bite.  The detected alcohol is a little more than I remember when I had a few months ago.  Good brew. Warms your insides.

Bottle, batch 63.  Hazy copper color with some yeast and a white head.  Sugary aroma with some alcohol and floral notes and a little grass and yeast in the background.  Also a little bit of cider and alcohol.  Sharp up front with marked sweetness, that gives way to great bitterness and a spicy, alcohol laced finish.  The bitterness is like super, super dark chocolate and almost makes you pucker.  Great chew in the mouth with a little bit of an oily finish and perfect carbonation.  Another nice beer from Hair of the Dog.

12 fl oz bottle. Apricoty orange coloured with a haze. Thick soft fluffy creamy white head. Egg-whites. Bready, wheat flour, marshmellow aroma. Quite intense. Alcoholic when it enters the mouth. Quite bitter, and sweet marcipan flavours. Intensely bitter in fact. Oily texture. Finishes powdery dry, almost like cocoa powder.

Biggish offwhite creamy lasting head over orange body with yeast particles. Intense bready alcoholic plum and flour aroma with unidentifiable hop notes. Intense bitter sweetness marzipan malt taste with resiny, oily, alcohol, and pine needle notes. Some mint, citrus, and cocoa as well. Extreme amounts of taste. A bit overwhelming. (0.355l bottle.)

(bottle - 12 oz) Murky copper color with a creamy tan head and lots of sediment. Aroma is chock full of heavy malts. Very sweet and caramelly. The flavor is very heavy and malty as well. Lots of raisins, caramel, and toffee throughout. Oddly enough, the flavor doesnt last long on the palate. Chewy and very sweet with a nice warming and spicy kick at the end.

Very strong tasting beer. Pours a golden brown color with a two finger head that sticks around for a while. The taste is huge with alot of dark fruits jumping out at you. Very sweet and earthy aroma. A great barley wine.

Pours a dirty brown, huge head. Aroma of piney hops and sweet malt.  Flavor is more sweet malt, some spiciness, pine and wood.  Finish is alcoholic.  A lot going on, just too sweet for me.   Just not one of my favorite styles.

12 Oz bottle.  Batch # 63, purchased at Bottle Barn, Santa Rosa, CA.

Wow!  This is it.  I have found the perfect barley wine.  This beer looks almost too pretty, I dont want to drink it.  Big chunks of what I assume to be yeast everywhere.  This is absolutely delicious.  Perfectly balanced.  Hoppy, yet tamed by the malt.  Sweet, but not overly.  One of the best.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 Bottle at Isaac Newtons in Newtown, PA. I sense a very licorice-like flavor with heavy carbonation, a healthy but not too exuberent dose of alcohol and and a malty finish. Very well balanced but Im not sure Id hunt after this again because it has a certain yeasty flavor that seems to conflict with the sweetness. Re-rate 5-23-10. Bottle from Abes. Back in 2005 I didnt appreciate the complexity of this beer. I picked up on how silky smooth it was but missed out on the sweet mix of malts and wonderful hoppy bite which seems to match the malt quotient perfectly.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2008 Batch 54 - Very Excited to find a case of FRED stashed away at the local beer distributor.  Nice Caramel Taste and Smell.  Alcohol present, but not overwhelming.  Will definitely enjoy the 23 I have left.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2009 Batch 58; Sweet caramel and hoppy aroma,  hazy amber that got cloudier as poured even though I was careful not to agitate; Flavor changes from malts to caramels, to raisins as the brew warms. 8/4/8/5/17 4.2 
Batch 75 From Imbibe Wine. Nose of caramel, light toffee, and golden raisins. Lightly hazy copper with a medium, lightly lacing beige head. Flavor is spicy with some contrasting light sweetness and bitterness, bubblegum, and caramel. Finish is light bitterness.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 Bottle Batch #36 opened on New Years day 2005 thanks to my father-in-law. Awesome, awesome smell. I couldnt get enough of it. Very heavey alcohol taste that takes a little to warm up. Turns into a great sipping brew. Fantastic ale. Cheers!

Batch #63 -- Great cloudy orange-brown body with a light tan head.  Honey-walnut with maple sugar aroma, some light oaking as well.  Pine, caramel and warm hops, nuts are also present in the taste.  Warm, sweet, woody ending.
Batch 63. Clear caramel color with a small light brown head. Sweet caramel aroma. Lots of pine hints. Sweet hopy flavor, lots of pine, with some sweet caramel in the end.
Very cedary.  Rich ruby amber colour.  Sweet but intense woody flavour.  So piney!

Made sure I had this before I cracked one of my FFTWs. Aroma started out very floral hoppy, strong earthy notes and sage. As it warms, caramel and milk chocolate take over, underscored with said flowers along with a harsh alcohol burn. Pour is deep brown with a small but perfectly creamy (dare I say Guinness-like!) head, and lots of yeast chunks in the bottom of my snifter. It burns in the mouth, though the taste is deep and rewarding, though a little "brown" in the finish, with the delicate hop notes playing fiddle to the 21-instrument orchestra thats collapsed upon itself. In other words, all the flavors crash together in to a big mess. Still, a very nice beer. Im excited to get the oak notes from fftw.

From the steel.  Pours a murky amber body with a large creamy off-white head. Aroma is citrusy hops and flowers with some earthy mineral note. Flavour is sweet caramel malt which moves into a spicey flavour before ending with a very dry hoppy bitter finish.
UPDATED: JUL 17, 2006 Bottle - Batch 63. Great smell! Caramel and fruits. Smooth taste.

"My first run in with HOTD. This is a very interesting beer indeed. The pour is golden brown with an off-white head. The aroma is of straw, and thats about all I got. The taste was a big suprise, as the earthy hops cut through everything in this beer--you have to let that first taste sit on your palate awhile so you can acclimate to the flavor of this one. After that, the taste will be more manageable. The rest of the flavors--nice caramel malt and some lively fruits--will start to come through. The hop presence never leaves mind you, but simply lets the others come out to play every once in awhile. A good beer, but not one that I would go out of my way to get."

Bottle - batch 58.  Pours a dark hazt orange with light yellow highlights and a boatload of sediment.  Checked the bottle after the pour and there was still a pile sediment left at the bottom.  The aroma is caramel and butterscotch upfront followed by yeast, peach, and apricot.  Taste follows with slight bursts of sweetness.  Finishes with a pronounced alcohol burn that takes away somewhat from the overall experience.
batch 62. amazing beer, great smell and appearance.  color changes from top to bottom of the glass.  Complex flavor due to 10 types of hops.  Looking forward to dave and fred from the wood.

12 oz bottle batch 63. Well before I plunge into one of my bottles of Fred From the Wood, I figured Fred regular and I should tango first. Great appearance from well designed label to the solid caramel colored liquid with a yellowish-light tan head. The aroma holds a lot of the qualities youd expect from a barley wine: caramel malt, a bit of citrusy hops but also some of the spicy/fruity/yeasty elements youd find in a lot of Belgian styles. The flavor seems like a good combonation of the two: lots of bitter pine and grapefruit backed with yeast, alcohol, cherry, and a light malt character. A nice creamy yet carbonated mouthfeel, starts bitter then a bit yeasty and comes to an end with a long bitter finish. Not my favorite HOD beer, but certainly an amazing brew by my standards.

12 oz bottle.  Batch 59.  Cloudy light brown with some head, lacing and dark floaties.  Barley wine nose with a bit of floral.  Fruity, sorta like a tripel.  Little hops for balance.  Medium body with active carb.

Looks like the new Fred from the Wood; translucent amber with thin white head.  Nose is similar, but not as complex as the wood version some fruits and light hops.  In the mouth, you can taste the rye malts and the hop complexity, but it just doesnt come together like the oak-aged version.  More sweet than bitter.

Batch 54, poured with the largest non-Belgian (heck, it may have been the largest Ive dealt with) head Ive ever seen. Color was a weak cloudy dirty orange. Aroma was hoppy with some floral notes most prominent. Flavor was definitely hoppy and sweet, but the alcohol was very detectable. A bitter finish to the thick and somewhat creamy (and very carbonated) mouthfeel. Nice beer to try, but Im not coming back to this (I dont go back to many barleywines anyway).

pours a copper orange color. thick creamy head.  nice bit of malty sweetness that is well balanced with the load of hops.  Alcohol is not overly present but does as the beer warms.  All in All very good.  I need to try all the others

Bottle 12oz.(batch 49) Pours a deep garnet color with a thick creamy yellow head. The sweet smells of hops hit the nose, man this beer smells awesome. The flavors in the brew are incrediable with 10 different kinds of hops, you can just let your imagination fly. This is a beer I think you should try if you get the chance.

From bottle, batch 61.  Pour a hazy orange with huge tan head.  Nose has mangoes, sour yeast and honey.  Flavor is sour, bitter, with a multitude of flavors.  Heavily carbonated and syrupy mouth feel.  Light alcohol throughout.  A big beer.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2007 BATCH 14 (around 1999 vintage).  Poured a hazy amber color with a orange hue and beige colored head.  The beer looked pretty viscous in the glass.  Aroma of thick aged malt.  Woody notes with like red wine tannins.  Plenty more of the sweet aged malt in the flavor.  Light notes of oragne juice and lightly tart on the finish.  The finish was pretty dry and has thinned out over the 7ish years.  I will try a recent one when I get the chance because even this one was still decent.  It got a few bonus overall points for holding up so long.  Batch 23.  No notes just yummy

From 12oz Bottle.  Pours the color of fresh honey, tinged with a splash of sunset red, and topped with a giant pile of creamy head.  The aroma is pleasantly full, but in a peaceful, laid back kind of way.  Supple brown sugars entwine with washed iris petals, creating a floral garden bouquet thats delicately sweet.  A few tender dark fruits also meagerly peek through, taking the shape of strawberries and unspiced fig.  A very subtle splash of dry sherry completes the olfactory experience.  Very creamy, expertly crafted mouthfeel with a honeyed tangerine sweetness accompanied by some mild pine.  It is at this point that the contemplation of a plus-four rating starts to fade out of mind.  As the delicate flavors fade from the palate, sweet light fruits removed one-by-one, a bitter piney hop blast is nakedly exposed beneath.  Strangely out of balance - the delicate lei of flower petals and honey is the stand out feature on my palate, but unfortunately, the strong hops presence erodes this pleasant sensation away before a final smack of rye seed and pine cones.  Still, a very interesting and highly enjoyable beer overall.  Thanks, Tom!
Great beer.  The aroma of hops is strong, but the taste is beautifully balanced, with not as much hop taste as you would expect.  Some nice sweet notes with this beer

From a 12oz. long neck with batch number 58 on the front of label, a blurb on the left side and pouring instructions on the right side, poured as instructed, leaving sediment in bottle.

Made a good appearance, poured a golden amber with a frothy, foamy white head that slowly settled into a thin, sticky, foamy lacing, good carbonation.

Had a sweetish tropical fruity nose with a caramel maltiness at the edges and big whiffs of spicy alcohol.

A crisp. slick textured and carbonated smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good sipping drinkability. 

Tropical fruity and spicy rye malty taste, the hop bitterness rolls on the tongue through out the taste, a subtle toasted graininess, a nice warming alcohol presence in the palate, and a spicy, yeasty and sweet fruity finish with the taste lingering in the mouth.

A really nice barley wine from Hair Of The Dog, tasty and warming on a chilly spring day.

Lovely bright golden color with an aroma that was surprisingly reminiscent of Hair of the Dogs Doggie Claws barley wine.  However, the comparison ends there.  Freds flavor is initially a bit tart, almost citrusy, and very, very hoppy.  Some of the hops even tasted fresh and green.  Nice after taste subsiding relatively quickly.

12-ounce bottle. Pours dark murky amber with an off-white head that drops to a cap and leaves some sticky lace. Lots of cotton candy in the nose, and a sticky sweet body. Its incredibly dense and thick, almost goopy. Very much a dessert beer. Its taken me two hours to get through ~6 ounces. Where to begin with the flavor? Vanilla, caramel, herbs, a tingling bitter hop finish. The sweetness is a bit mutable; at times there seems to be butterscotch. Incredibly subtle, complex, and delicious, but its the most occasional of rare treats.

Pale hazy copper, with a lasting head that held on the sides of the glass like it had claws. Interesting nose, a lemon like hop that stands out over a mild chocolate coffee aroma. This has a vanilla sweetness that balances with the hop bitterness. A long finish that starts out sweet and ends dry. The alcohol becomes evident as it warms up during the tasting.  Recommended.

pours think orange with an off white head. great aroma of chocolate chip cookies and toffee. sweet toffee and chocolate flavor blending seamlessly with a hint hops. full bodied and slightly fizzy. hot alcoholic finish. great beer.

Thanks to boboski who, as usual, generously opened some hard to find brews at a small tasting with Jen, mgumby10, redlight, and SoLan. BE CAREFUL! Batch 62. Appearance: caramel brown with a foamy sponge light tan head. Aroma: caramel malt, grainy multivitamins, Magellan gin, resinous hops- strange, but nice. Flavor: roasty caramel, cotton candy, flowery hops, light fruits, same crunchy mvs, just a subtle accent from the alcohol. Palate: full, smooth, expanding. Very nice barley wine- sweet, lively, and a little roasty all at the same time.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle at issac Newtons with Stegosaurus. Pours reddish amber with a white head. Aroma is excellent, fruit, sweet malts, citrus, sugar, floral hops. Flavor is sweet, alcohol, fruit, citrus, and a bitter finish

Noah comes through with a Batch 22 (22!) and a Batch 58. Amazing work, thanks htsprint1! Enjoyed on the night of Robs barleywine tasting, and a wonderful way to break the Lenten fast. The batch 22 pours a cloudy color, but the palate features a variety of flavors. Its rich, silky, and notes of vanilla and grass meet the typical barleywine profile. Theres unfortunately, just a tad bit of wet cardboard that i thought might be the age, but I also noted this on Batch 58. 58 is much lighter in color, not as complex, and still way too hoppy for my tastes. I get more cherry flavors from the 58, although the recent batch didnt blow me away. The experience did reveal, however, that ageing this would be a great idea.

Hair of the Dog beers always remind me of good strong homemade beers. This is a bottle from batch 54. Beer has a rich complex aroma of smoky malt, spicyness, fruity esters with some high alcohol coming through in the end. Beer is a dark amber cloudy brew with a thick and full light tan colored head that hung on quite some time. A very good malt flavor with a nice hop bitterness and flavor to match. The beer has a slight oxidation that comes through in the finsh but it blends well in most good barleywines. It is unique compared to most american style barleywines in that it seems to combine some of the english and american style of barleywines. This is a very good barleywine that I will buy again.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 12 oz. Bottle purchased at The Warehouse - Duluth, MN Pour of clouded amber and brown, with golden fringes and an array of varying tones. Topped with a super foamy off-white head. Aroma of warm bready figs and pears, backed with gentles fusels, like spice and a touch of celery. Flavor continues on a similar note with warm rich brandy, more pears and a hint of cinnamoned apples. Spicy yeasts. A very mature and complex flavor, with alcohol that is a touch too hot. Figgy for a paler beer. Complex, with brandywin figginess. Lemon and coriander bright ness. Finishes with a light dryness of grass and euro hops, again sophisticated. Well balanced. But, I dont agree with this as a Barleywine. 

Tasted Blind. Batch #10. 12oz Bottle. Oxidized cheese. Light vomit, cardboard, and dust. Faint, faint caramel. Pours a lightly hazed copper-amber, with a rim of off-white. Flavor is ragingly sweet, raisined and old. Dust, dust, dust. This is freakin old an full of fur. Really old cheddar cheese rages through the finish. Celery seed finishes it. Ragingly sweet. A bit of oak and then nothing of the former self.  Not going to let this really old bottle affect my rating.

Bottle at issac Newtons. Pours reddish amber with a small white head. Aroma is excellent, fruit, sweet malts, citrus, sugar, pine hops, and floral. Flavor is sweet upfront, alcohol is present, fruit, citrus, and a very hoppy bitter finish. Good body, good brew.

Big Excellent in aroma, appearance and flavor. Very coplex hop character in the aroma and the flavor. Amber color cloudy very dense. Heat in aftertaste that is good! A slight sweetness on palate. I think there should be a Fred vs. Frank (Pizza port San Diego) duel

Two bottles at Volo shared with DougShoemaker, mds & mustang3. Amber colour with a wispy head. Big, BIG hop aroma - lots of grapefruit and resin. Flavour starts sweet, with notes of brown sugar, but the sprucey hops soon take over, kicking ass in the finish. Nice contrast to the Adam, it was great to try them one after the other.

Bought @ Steilacoom Wine and Brew. This beer cracks me up every time I have one... The bottle conditioning is the first thing you notice as it bubbles forth from the bottle! This is an outstanding beer that is like a belgian beer and a barley wine combined. "Golden??" Try this dark, murky beer with flavor that doesnt stop. If you like BIG beers then youll love it!

Two single bottles of Fred were hiding in the back of my local store for quite some time, so I decided to finally give it a try. The bottle from Batch 51 poured with a huge fluffy yellowish head above a clear orange body. Soapy alveoli formed against the sides of the glass while the top of the head was enveloped in a creamy blanket. The nose is immediately hoppy and has only furthered my confusion about the definition of a barley wine. Nonetheless, grapefruit, pine and burnt toast are prominent in the aroma and conjugate with the walnuts, pineapple, coriander and surprising ketchup fragrances. A certain floral quality is decidedly noticeable as well as smooth salted caramel that becomes increasingly emphasized with warming. The flavor reflects the nose, especially in the citrussy hoppiness promoted by grapefruit and orange zest, nuts and carbonized toast are also quite conspicuous. Mango as well as butter and mustard are also apparent and are really the only defining traits of this brew. Admittedly the thick creamy texture is appreciable but the strong bitter aftertaste is detracting to me. Fred reminds me of a sweet IPA, and as such reverbates the narrowness in character of this beer.
Bottle - Poured a beautiful amber color with a big white head.  Hoppy floral aroma.  Very intense flavors of fruit, malt and HOPS.  One of my favorite Barley Wines.
Dark amber, slight haze, little head. Aroma is amazing, mostly floral. Big flavour with some decent bitterness but theres plenty of room to improve.
Its hard not to respect a barley wine that weighs in at ten percent--but this tastes like a very harsh version of Gold Label...  Too much hop is NOT a good thing.
Bottle.  Pretty nondescript overall.  Doughy, chewy flavor, but nothing really stands out to me.  Average.

Bottle, Volo.  Yeah, I said I was on lent, but damn it, I had something to celebrate today, so I went there with Blankboy and my wife and company.  Dark orange, bubbly white head.  Lots of bubbles.  Smells really sweet with lots of hops.  Taste is very sweet and malty but also lots of hops.  Medium to thin boozy, which really accentuates the hops.  Lots of boozy fruity notes.  Almost spicy.  Very very good, thanks Ralph for bringing this in!!

This beer has a variety of fragrances that add to its aroma.  There are the scents of yeast, barley, prunes, apples, caramel, sour mash, and over-ripe peaches.  This thick beer numbs the tongue as it deposits a dry and bitter taste on the palate.  The taste is a mixture of sour and sweet as the flavors of caramel and apple merge together.

Hazy golden colour with a simple frothy head.  A bready smell with caramels and a slight hoppiness.  I actually expected some more hops, but it was pleasant on the palatte nonetheless.  Interesing fact , when it warms to room temperature, it actually starts to taste more like the Adam!  It the mot complex of the HOtD I have sampled.

bottle at Volo. hazy copper-brown with a creamy white head. the aroma has soft biscuit malt but is dominated by resiny pine hops. wow! nice big and hoppy body which I find to be quite similar to Bigfoot. a solid sugary yeast and malt balance. very flavourful ending with alcohol and chewy bitterness. very drinkable.
On tap at the Beveridge Place Pub Baleywine Bacchanal. Cloudy light brown, not much head. Stong hop smell with...a little bit of vinegar. Pretty smooth, fig, banana and a little caramel flavors.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry at Bar Volo. Pours a hazy bubbly dark amber with a small somewhat lasting off-white head. Aroma of hops, hops, hops -- smells awesome. Theres enough malt and yeast there to balance it out. Delicious flavour of hops, rye, sweet malt, yeast and fruit -- so tasty and well balanced. For 10% this goes down incredibly easy. Medium to full bodied. After being letdown by the HOTD Rose I was a little hesitant but this knocked my socks off, a truly great Barley Wine.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  At Volo - yay! - shared with blankboy.  Poured hazy light mahogany with a smallish beige head.  Rich hop medley aroma - resiny, floral, citrus in turns - with thick oil-paint malt backing and doughy yeast; very blended, balanced and appealing.  Taste is also rich roast oily malt and yeast, noticeable fresh rye, and the shifting solid hop medley ... also alcohol and a hint of oakiness; awesome!  Creamy, astrinent and alcoholic mouthfeel, solid body - this is a winner, and so easy to drink - Id almost call it a barleywine but by the end of the glass it was going down smooth and easy as a a lager, despite the long resiny mild hop finish.  Fantastic.

(02.24.06) 12 oz bottle obtained from trade with Thaichile.  10% ABV. Batch 62. Pours clear dark red amber with small white head.  Soft carbonation. Fruity citrus in the nose.  Full bodied golden special ale  that starts with moderate malt sweetness and grapefruit hop/caramel/peppery alcohol flavors. Slight sharpness (carbonation?) in the mouth.  Finishes with lingering hop bitterness and flavor.  Definite alcoholic warmth.  Smooth and well-balanced.  An excellent drinkable beer with nice hoppy aroma and flavor.  Thanks Thaichile!

Hair of the Dog Fred is a top notch barleywine.   The ten different hops blend well with the rye malts and the yeast.   This could pass for a Belgian Strong Ale.    After the foam settled down this was a chewy spicey barleywine.    Portland Im jealous.

Aroma is not great, grassy, bready and alcohol.  Pours out cloudy gold/copper color with very little head.  Flavor is very unbarleywine, Id classify as american strong.  Where are the hops in this beer?  Lots of malt and alcohol.  Not worth the money.  The flavor seemed to change after I poured the last of the bottle out with the yeast.  Added a bitter element, not good hop bitter either.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2006 [12 oz. bottle] Pours a sort of orange color. Thick, fluffy head. Flavors are fruity, floral hops and strong alcohol warmth. Very good.

12 oz bottle.  Pours orange color with a large foamy off white head.  Aromas of prune, caramel, molassas, brown sugar a little nuttiness.  Flavors are very malty.  Big alcohol warming,  more caramel and dark fruit.  Some lingering bitterness.  Pretty nice sipper

Woh......6.50 a bottle, seems a bit much no matter how good this stuff may be. Lemon and herb that finishes with with overwhelming alcohol attack. good by any standard however, gave me some stomach pains afterwards
Pours dark orange with a white head.  Beautiful complex floral-hoppy balanced by malt nose.  Mouth is strong, but very balanced.  Wonderful beer.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2006 Bottle from bockeyhorsy. Pours orange with ncie diminishing white head. Some lacing. Aroma of alcohol, hops, caramel. Intense sweet and malty flavor, nicely balanced by a spicy hop kick. Finish is dry, sweet, and warming. Another great beer from HOTD. I wish it was easier for me to get.

Poured golden with a thick white head.  Good thickness.  Aroma of courant, caramel, honey and white wine.  Quite yeasty for a Barley Wine.  Taste was very smooth but a bit too syrupy.  I would think it was an American Strong Ale but the maltiness suggests otherwise.  Palate was smooth with quite a bit of sugar.  Overall very good.
I remember this tasting good and strong...not much like a barley wine though.  It had an amazing dark red/brown color, but it was was filled with tons o chunks o yeast.  Flavor was very sweet.

Orangy golden body with a thin white head, very cloudy.  Aroma of yeast and baking bread.  Taste has some grapefruit and honey, but dominated by the yeast and bready flavors.  Moderatly carbonated, tingly mouthfeel.  Interesting beer.

12 oz. bottle from OhioDad, thanks Scott.  a great looking pour with an amber, brownish color and a pretty big tan head.  aroma was very sweet with caramel malt coming thru quite strong.  palate was almost full but yet not quite there.  flavor was very swett with what seemed to be honey dominating.

Batch 54.  Pours with a huge into a snifter with a creamy head -- a few big bubbles, othwise uniform small.  Head gradualy subsides leaving tracing at the rim and a mound of foam in the middle.  Bread and caramel.  Nice gold with circulating yeast.  Very sweet burnt caramel/vanilla with a tingly finish.

Huge malt aroma, caramel with a hint of honey. Opaque golden tinted brown color with a pretty creamy head for a barley wine. Flavor is oohh so malty to the point of being very caky and sweet, but its one of the easier drinking BWs Ive had.
Copper, orange body with hazy floaties and medium bubbly, off-white head.  Aroma is brown sugar, yeast, sweet malt.  Flavor is maple syrup, vanilla, alcohol.  Creamy palate.
"Batch 54. Poured a cloudy straw/orange color with a massive head, fluffy. Smelled very floral. Tasted of hops and was a little to sweet for my liking in the barleywines."
sweet, fruity aroma with hints of brown sugar and vaniall, copper orange in color, very sweet, carmel flavor, a bit syrupy but still smooth

Bottle. Hazy burnt orange with floaties and a creamy, everlasting head. Aromas of sweet aged dark fruits, caramel, and fresh, crisp hops.  Strong and appetizing for sure. Sweet with plums, raisins, peaches, and caramel at the start- then a caraway-like spiciness and a hop wallop kick in with a hop bite that burns for an everlasting finish. Surprisingly dry at the finish. A smoother, quicker drinker than most barleywines for sure. Alcohol present, but not hot or biting. Very well done Barleywine with lots of flavors-all of them acceptable.
Pours a hazy orange amber with a medium off white lacing head with small floaties.  aroma of dark fruits, caramel, pear and floral hops.  Flavor of prunes, sugary, maple syrup and a smooth palate.
this beer is strong and full of flavor - A real good representation of its style - its style just isnt my cup of tea.  But for those who enjoy barley wine - this is one of the best.

Batch 46, bottled 12-12-02.  Cloudy, deep amber appearance and little lacing.  Huge head dwindled quickly.  Sediment settled in the bottom of the glass.  Aroma has developed  more sweet malt accents with brown sugar, molassas and toffee overpowering the well documented hop profile, probably because of its age.  Smooth, rich, full-bodied mouthfeel with moderate carbonation.  Rye malts add to the distinct flavor and the high abv leaves its warming impression in the finish.  A vertical tasting of the different vintages would be most interesting.

This is an excellent beer.  I didnt think it was a barley wine but an American strong ale. Very dark orange and a long lasting tan head.  Light hops in the aroma suggest an ipa.  Complex flavor that includes bitter hops, sugar, sour, fermenting cerals, and some alcohol.  Alcohol is also present in the palate and lightly burns the tongue.

Aroma of sweet malts, yeast, fresh bread and molassis. The flavor starts with a hint of bitter, citrus and grapefruit hops that yields to sweet malts  caramel. The high alcohol content comes through in the finish along with a lingering hop bitterness. The medium body and carbonation accuntuate the flavors and present a smooth mouthfeel. Excellent.

300th Rating - it seems appropriate to rate the beer that first turned me onto good beer for this rating.  Honey-clove pour with little head.  Mild hop aroma is real fruity-juicey, noting pear and apple.  Loads of spice and alcohol in the body balance with clean, bready malts.  The ABV warmth is immediately present, warming both my stomach and my mouth.  Silky mouthfeel helps to blend the complex body and the moderate hop bitterness delivers a definite, crisp finish.  Another great offering from HOTD.

Deep orange with a huge foamy off white head that is like jello. Lots of yeast sediment floating around. Aroma is roasted, sweet, fruity (pear), breadlike, vanilla, a hint of chocolate. Very thick, sticky, oily, with sweet fruits and big malt. A little bit of the hops shine through in the end with some alcohol warming.

Fresh and fruity aroma. Beautiful reddish, orange body. Picture perfect thin, fine bubble, light tan head and excellent lace. Beers that look this good are rare. Wonderfully complex flavors. This is a fine and exquisite brew.

The bottle calls it a Golden Ale but I knew from tasting it that it had to be a barleywine--and a big one at that!  The bubbles struggling to ascend through the thick, mildly hazy, orange body reminded me of films showing sperm swimming to the egg, all going their directions but slowly and deliberately.  Here a decent, rich head was the result.  A fine aroma, of pine, grapefruit, vanilla, and fruit was huge, and then the flavors were similarly bold.  My wife thought it was medicinal, but I really enjoyed it, even though it had characteristics of tea and tobacco amid the pine that I usually do not like.  By the bottom of the sipping, I was really liking this thick, syrupy barleywine.  The bitter finish was mild.  Excellent beer.

Bottle from Santa  Pours a rich amber with a nose of raisin, yeast, and a slight peach.  Flavor is full and surprisingly hoppy; definitely not any barleywine Ive had before.  It seems to have more in common with a creamy IPA than the aforementioned style.  Nice hints of citrus are evident in the finish and the aftertaste.  Palate is thick and coating.  Damn good beer!  Im forever in debt to my Secret Santa!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: This is one big ASS beer.  Pours a nice deep dark golden brown.  Aromas of hay, hop flowers, carmel malts, candy sugar, honey.  Flavor: oak,  caramel malts, grapefruit, light hops, brown sugar, and alcohol.  This beer is to big and bad for my palate.

Whooo! From first opening the beer, it actually fizzed out on me. I was surprised. Very thick head, with a strong aroma of hops and definatly molasses and a really dark complex smell.
The texture is a bit surprising...it wasnt as thick as I thought it would be. Tastes very complex, just like the smell, but really doesnt bite. Its smooth and feel good once you swallow. You can feel its strong power of alcohol...but I didnt taste it.
Great beer, 10% alcohol you cant beat that, 1/2 way through I was already feeling it! A little pricy beer, but worth it!!!

Golden brown color with a tan, almost white head that had good retention and lacing.  This beer had good complexity and mixture of hops, malts, and citrus.  The hop taste is pretty constant throughout.

Dark amber color - thick foamy head that lingers a bit.  Aroma of malts, molasses, spruce and other hops.  Flavor is quite robust, with a complex profile of malts and hops throughout.  Wonderful hop character.  Finish is bold but clean, with a strong presence of alcohol.

white head, dense copper body, honey/alc. nose, huge and intense flavor, rich  malts, hop bite is wild and balanced well with that distinct rye flavor, man these guys are good at what they do, brew burley beers

What else can you say about Fred that this is a strong golden amber brown color that has a hop aroma of the Beer Gods.  There is a hop flavor through out the whole beer and it seems that Alan put his heart into this beer.  A great beer that just hits all spots.  Be sure to get this fresh it can get a wild bite if older.

A distinctly American take on the barley wine, this comes on strong and doesnt quit.  Full body, loads of flavor (citrus/grapefruit, if I recall correctly), and loads of alcohol on the tongue.  Excellent.

Batch 49... Poured a hazy amber color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of floral hops, citrus fruits, caramel malts, sherry, and light alcohol.  Much of the same in the taste, hops were still forward, and the alcohol was also a bit strong.

Poured murky orange with sediment and a huge head that fades to a rocky one. Big spicy aroma which carries on to the flavor. Lots of alcohol, citrus, and a finish like fresh rye bread.  Just so much going on in this one. Bravo!!

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2009 Batch 56. 12oz bottle. Tasted at around 54° in my NB worthy glass. Pours hazy orange, gold, red with a fat cream colored head the collapses slowly. Plenty of settlement, throughout, but really concentrated in the bottom of the glass.  Guess I should poured more carefully... The aroma is caramel long john with a lot of spicy, citrusy hops. In fact I think different types of hops really give it a multi-layered aroma. Smells fantastic. The taste is brown sugar and cajeta at first before the hops invade with their complex flavor and moderate to substantial bitterness. There is some yeast and flour in the aftertaste along with a tingly mouthful of pleasantly bitter hops. The mouthfeel is huge. This is just a big beer in every sense of the word. Big alcohol, big malt, big hops, big flavor. Powerful stuff. 8/4/8/5/17   
Vertical tasting with Theisti. We had the 49, 67 & 70. It is neat to try this beer in different stages of its maturation. New, it seems to be alcoholic and very spicy, but in 6 short years, it mellows into a sublime beer. This rating is for the batch 49 that is 6+ years old. Cookie dough, dark caramel, toffee, black pepper and a slight vegetal aroma. Flavor is sweet, malty, moderately oxidized, with dark caramel and woodsy and herbal notes. Moderate alcohol. 9/4/8/5/17.

Bottle, from Julios, batch # 54. Good nose, sweet. Orange, grapefruit, whisky, little corriander, caramel, honey. Hazy brownish orange color, BIG head, needed second glass to pour rest of bottle. Bitter flavors. like aromas with citrus a little more grapefruity and whisky standing out. Thick body, creamy oily mouthfeel, dry sweet finish. Tad hot, tasty brew. I wouldnt of had this a couple of years ago, but now its something to look foward to.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle Batch 36 poured a cloudy orangr with an off white head. Aromas of wet cardboard, some vinous notes, earthiness, grapefruit and a hint of pine. Palate was heavy, smooth and warming. Flavors of carmel, light grapefruit rind, pepper, and some vinous notes with a smooth warming finish.
24SEP05  On Tap  at Spuyten Duyvil. The best balance of malt and hops Ive had in a long time. This was an almost perfect brew.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 Huge light orange lacy head (took minutes to clear).  Very complex flavor, strong malt, complex hops (cannot distinguish separate hops.), perfect sticky and thick mouthfeel.  Very strong alcohol content, but sufficiently masked.  This is a beer snobs dream.  Very excellent.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2006 Bottle, batch 56. Hazy orange with lumps of yeast pouring into the glass. Creamy, rocky whipped egg whites head - very much like the one found on Duvel. Aroma of apples and candied fruits. Bittersweet flavor with the bitterness taking the lead. Notes of white chocolate, cola and grapefruit hides below the bitterness. Sweet, but not cloying. It seems a bit Belgian, but is less funky and more bitter, making it more drinkable, even though the bitterness becomes a bit mouth numbing in the finish. Creamy mouth feel in spite of the relatively powerful carbonation. and feels thick on the tongue. The alcohol is incredible well hidden.
Rerate Dec. 26 2006 (Batch 65): Still gorgeous looking beer, but way to sweet, with the bitterness sticking out like sore thumb and coating your palate. Cloying and unbalanced and very close to becoming a drain pour. But its Christmas, Im in a good mood and I wont change my scores until I have tasted another one.

Batch 51.  Pours hazy copper with a huge foamy off-white sticky head with excellent lacing that lasts throughout.  Banana and yeast (wheat, dough) honey malt (meal, cookie) and straw aromas.  Wheat acidic hoppy flavor with a malt body and fusel alcohol notes.  Medium bodied and fizzy palate with very lively carbonation and finishes dry.

Batch 58. Pours with some much sediment and chunkies, looks like a lite chocolate milk, no kidding. Nice amount of creamy white head. Just a beautiful looking beer in an ugly sort of way. Smells of hops and hops and oranges. Taste is lots of malts, and lots of hops and a fair amount of yeast. Very caramelly and earthy initially, then the hops add a nice touch. Finishes somewhat sweet. Alcohol is well hidden, but noticeable. HOTD never dissapoints.

([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Twist) Muddy dark amber color with a small but tight tanned head. Yeasty, hoppy and spicy nutmeg aroma. Quite hoppy, slightly harshly bitter and alcoholic flavor with some vegetable tones and raw maltiness. Crisp lemony tones when warmer. Medium-bodied, quite alcoholic and carbonated palate. Quite a disappointment compared to Adam. Too raw and alcoholic to be enjoyable.

Smells of nuts and a tad bit of raisin upon opening. Looks a delicious golden orange/brown with a very dense and creamy head. Tastes of a whole bunch of nuts, smooth, malty, a very thick creamy liquid. Ends with some hoppy bitterness on a high note. Mouth licking good.

On tap at Horse Brass in Portland.  Pours dark gold/amber with a thin off-white head.  Lots of malt in the aroma.  Same for the flavor with a little banana as well.  Balance of hops and malt is very nice.  Very complex flavor.  I didnt think the alcohol was too overpowering.  Excellent beer.

Another interesting beer from Hair of the Dog! Cloudy with a white head. The aroma is wonderful and slightly nutty. The initial taste is almost pure maple syrup to me with a kick of alcohol. The different hops all seem to get along and harmonize wonderfully. No fighting and they are not over powering. A brilliant beer!!

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2013 Had an aged version which was fantastic, i had to raise this score. A fine-smelling brew and pretty darn fine brew. Its hoppiest hair-of-the-dog Ive had, but like the others, the alcohol is too noticeable (but not like the Adam or Rose). Unfortanutely, it gave me a slight headache in the end.

Had a Fred from Batch 4. Amazing. Id give that a 4.7 or 4.8

on tap at horsebrass. tastes way different than i remember it from bottles ive had. hazy dark amber pour, small white head. aroma is alcohol, spicy, lots of bananas. lots of bananas in the flavor as well, good yeasty, fruity sweet, spicy flavor, with a good alcohol bite. nice full mouthfeel.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 batch 58: piney, buttery, and creamy; a bit spicy, lots of perfume-type aromas going on--hops are in full force; a good sweet and creamy backing, though, which completes the fullness of this pretty complex brew; an overall great drink! i need to sit with a few more because i have only had a single bottle... batch 70: wow! it has been awhile! rich, sweet, and slightly fruity aroma; thick, cascading head that leaves itself as a thick, off-white head, with plenty of lace; so smooth, rich, syrupy not cloying, barley wine--the rating remains the same though the brew appears to differ ;o)

Medium Head.  Brown gold murky color with sediment.  Complicated doughy smell. Strong Fruity smokey hoppy flavor tails off with bitterness.  It dances around a bit with the bitterness and slivers of sweetness (must be all the different hops and the rye malts  in it.) The sweetness is caramel like.  Overall it feels  very Belgian in nature.

Bottle; batch number 56. Had a decent fruit aroma. Dark golden body with good head and lacing . Had sedinment on the bottom of glass and lot of floaters. Had a fruit flavor and alot of alcohol maybe too much for my palate. Also that syurpy taste wasnt good either. If it werent for the appearance I would of probly drain poured this one.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 Rating Aug 11, 2005: From the bottle.
Pours a cloudy dark brown with a big generous head. The rich and complex aroma offers up apples, nutmeg, strawberries, raisins, and molassas. 

Palate is thick, syrupy, and amply carbonated; the taste begins sweet and raisiny followed immediately with a strong nip of alcohol. Notes of smoke and wood follow in time, before yielding to a pleasingly bitter hop finish.

This is a robust beer, rich and complex and strong. Challenging and interesting and delightful on the palate

2 years old ’06 sampled July ’08. Splendid barleywine, soft fruits, rich caramel, well-blended, delightfully softened flavors, basically no oxidization. Excellent at this age!
Monster head.  Settled into a thin cream.  Sugary fruit aroma.  Syrupy alcohol fruity flavors ... the 10% is quite evident.  But drinkable and fun ... if  you can take the bite.

Finishing my dog beer spree. Batch 54 to anyone who cares. Whoa. Huge head. Body is a brownish orange, thick. Aroma reminds me of Arrogant Bastard Ale (Stone). Hops and malt are easy to detect. Also its fruity, flowery, and alcoholic. Very nice aroma. However, the comparisons to Arrogant Bastard end here. Huge malty alcoholic taste --> raisiny/plummy. Id rather enjoy the quality thats here rather than the 10% that they cant hide. How do they title this "Golden Special Ale?" Special? Sure whatever. Golden, no.

Cant remember batch.  Pours a nice amber color and i had some floaters but oh well.  Smelled of bready yeast, citrusy hops, and hints of sweet fruit.  So there is rye in this beer?  Good addition in my opinion, adds a unique flavor that brings this beer up quite a few notches.  If its one beer i wish i could drink on a daily basis it would be this one.  A great compliment to steaks, with its sweetish fruity and hoppy flavor.  The hints of spice and yeast in the beer would wash down just about any good cut of meat.

12 oz bottle batch #56 - Either came from my secret santa Mullman or ClarkVV as a bonus beer.  I got one from each of them.  Thanks to both of you!  Poured slowly as the bottle said to keep the yeast in the bottle and was pretty successful. Pours cloudy amber with a short tan head that laces some.  Aromas of caramel malts, toffee, yeast, and a touch of grapefruit hops.  Taste is quite malty, caramel, toffee, some oranges, a little brown sugar too and a little citrus bite on the back side.  I felt that this was blended beautifully and silky smooth and creamy on the palate.  A delicious brew that I truly enjoyed.  This brewer is top notch.

bottle batch 60. pours a hazy red with a golden hugh.  or the other way around. thin white creamy head. aroma is almost dusty and malty the taste is light fruit and malt up front with a sharp hop bite in the end you can definatly taste the alcohol which isnt neccesarily a bad thing. good beer.
Bottle, nose was hops with some caramel back bone.  Lots of flowers as well.  Poured hazy, (yeast). Tasted yeast. This was nice, the % was big but well made.

Aroma is quite hoppy and from the bottle it could pass for a pale ale. In the glass, however, sophisticated vapors of caramel and orange creme are dominant. Pour is hazed by the little floaties, about dandruff-sized; color is deep amber with a long lasting, substantial peach white head. Taste is pleasantly malty with elements of Pacific hops, barbecue sauce and wintergreen. The main negative is that there is a strong alcohol burn carrying through to a finish not unlike a plug of Skoal chewing tobacco. Overall a very nice beer though somewhat overpriced at $3.99 for 12 oz bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2007 Batch 56 per Chuck!  Thanks!  Pours to a hazy golden straw color with a thin fully lasting white head, huge perfect lacing.  The aroma is very nummy.  Malty, toffee, oranges.  mmmm...  The flavor is very delicious.  Piney, malty, barleywine-ish.  The palate is rich and full.  Creamy.

Batch 44 consumed on 2/24/07 per Tom!  The beer is still good but not as good as the batch 47 Adam we also sampled.  Rich caramel body with a nice white head and nice lacing.  A touch aged but still good.  I did not change my rating but this one was more like a 3.8-4.0.

batch 56
pours a cloudy almost orange color w/ a small thick white head and a nice amount of lacing.  Smells great.  Smells like a barley wine to me very sweet malty aroma some hints of a sweet carmel and plums a light grass hop too.  Full smooth palate creamy light carbonation.  Flavor has a touch of alcohol in it, very sweet and malty w/ a good dry bitterness that lingers on the tongue, a different type of hop flavor. Some dark fruits almost like candied fruits.  Some great stuff.. aquired via trade..

Batch 58 for those of you that give a damn.  Hazy golden amber in color with a bubbly tan head.  Aroma is golden oranges, toffee and caramel.  Bitter and dry taste.  Slight ABV tinge.  Some pine and cedar flavors mixed with a potpourri Christmas scented candle.

Batch 56, 1.5L bottle, opened 7/2005

Aroma:  some hay, light hop flowers, sharp cheese, light pineapple, carmel malts, candy sugar, and light honey 

Appearance:  dark, golden yellow-orange, large creamy head, lacing

Flavor:  oak, honey, carmel malts, pineapple, grapefruit juice, light hops, brown sugar, and alcohol

Palate:  sweet with sharp, hoppy bite, stinging bitter hoppy aftertaste, coats the mouth well with flavors that fill the nose

Overall:  an excellent beer!  yummy!

Bottle. Pours a murky copper color w/ huge foamy off white head. Retention is amazing, took several minutes for it to recede leaving a very nice lacing. Nose is sweet and caramely. Taste is thick and chewy w/ caramel and apricots. The beer covers your entire mouth.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2014 Deep, rich taste, batch 54. What an initial head-read instructions, pour slowly. Creamy barleywine taste, honey sweetness and drying with spicy bit of burnt barley taste at end, orange citrus. Golden orange lucious, great hop experience. Thank you JoeMcPhee. version on tap 9 years later at pine box just too boozy.

Couleur ambrée, apparence presque entièrement brouillée, grosse mousse blanche concassée formant une multitude de reliefs.  Arômes très épicés, phénoliques, vapeurs dalcool rappelant le vernis, de sirop dérable et de levure.  La signature des levures est très belge et rappelle celle de la brasserie Het Anker.  Pudding au butterscotch, sucre dérable, rhum, raisins secs et alcool fraternisent avec les houblons se faisant de plus en plus marquants.  Corps dune belle épaisseur, texture sirupeuse, carbonatation semble un tantinet agressive, une tonne dalcool nous réchauffe sur son passage.  Une grande bière!!!  Bouteille partagée avec Joce et Léo, 24 Juin 2005.

Thick warm amber color with small creamy beige froth. Very expressive nose with hints of sweet malts, Baba au Rhum, agorn sirup, caramel, sweet spices, flowerpollen, lavender-honey, pine needles and many hops. The taste is very mouthfilling, soft and smooth. First the caramelly sweetness with hints of agorn, sweet Rhum, bread-pudding, honey and caramel-malts are filling the mouth. Than the more exotic spices and flower accents are comming forward. The whole sugary smoothness is turnig into a complex bitterness of herbs, wild mint, sage, orchidee flowers, geraniums and loads of hops. The afthertaste lingers on and on, it has a taste of forrest herbs, hops, freshly roasted nuts, and Marc de Bourgogne mixed with wild honey from the mountains. At the Kulminator in Antwerp.
Bottle. Hazy orange colour with a medium baige head. Sweet malty friuty aroma and a sweet fruity hoppy light alcoholic taste. Medium body and a sweet light dry alcoholic finish.
Murky amber/ brown colour with a small off white head. Sweet malty aroma with some plum fruityness and an alcohol note. Malty caramel and fruity flavor with a clear alcohol taste. Dry hoppy finish.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2005 Bottled.
Hazy orange coloured with a lacing beige head.
Sweet aroma of malts, alcohol and hops.
Nice sweet flavour with lots of malts, hops and dried fruit.
Nice long bitter finish.

Batch 54 courtesy of ClarkVV.  Nice dark redish color and a small foam head.  Aroma is hoppin  with some light spice and caramel notes as well.  With the amount of hops in this one its impressive that it comes off so well rounded.  Now if only I got some Fred from the Wood...

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2007 Bottle in trade from BuckNaked. Only for Wohlfs to surprise me with one. Thanks to the both of you. Batch #59. Dark hazy golden-copper. Off-white head lasts the whole beer. Aroma has lots of rye, hops and some other spice. Initial flavor is sickly-sweet, then a big hop bite with lots of rye in the finish. Long lingering aftertaste. First impression was Founders Red Rye. This has a little more hop presence is about the only difference IMO. 3-10-07: Batch 44 bottled 8-8-02. Malt sweetness dominates aroma, toffee, mollasses, very bready/yeasty, light phenol/alcohol. Flavor much the same, tad oxidized, slightest cardboard setting in. Dont know which is bottled with honey, but this has a certain mead-like character about it right now. Probably a 3.8 at this point, prefer a little less age. More notes to come.

batch #40 something, cant remember.  pours out dark brown in color.  hoppy and floral nose as well as flavor.  pretty good beer, not my favorite from these guys.  after drinking a bottle of duvel this one came off as rather sharp and offensive, but after a few sips, it was much better.  all in all, very good beer.
Fruitée!! Très goûteuse. Robe ambré aux reflets rouges. Très bonne bière. Alcool, rôti, pommes, fruits rouges, houblon floral. Excellente découverte.
Nice flowery smell which I like a lot.  Dark cloudy amber color and thick foamy foam.  The taste?  bitter.  Way too bitter for my liking, Ill tell you that (but it smells so nice!).

From batch # 54.  Huge thick creamy head (that is lasting quite a long time) over a cloudy dark orangy color.  Pleasant rye and hop aroma.   Somewhat fizzy mouthfeel, but not overly so.  Smooth slide in of easy hoppy and floral flavor.  Ive been getting away from hoppy beers lately, but this one is very hoppy but in a well-balanced and very flavorful way.  Great stuff!

Bottle, batch 54. Pours a hazy golden color, foamy white head, not that much lacing on the glass. Head vanished by the time I had finished the glass. Aroma is malty, hoppy, caramel, with a lot of ethanol in there. Solid malt flavor, the rye malt adds a good dimension of complexity, finish is heavily alcoholic with hops in there too. Carbonation level is about right, aftertaste is long and pleasing, medium body feels about right for an ale of this color. Almost barley wineish, I really enjoyed this beer, a real gem. Im looking forward to trying some other Hair of the Dog beers.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2007 My top beer for 2005. Batch 59. Cloudy orange with a thick polyester fill head. Big delicious grapefruit and spruce hop aroma. Flavour is a little rough and uneven. Competing teams of alcohol, hops and yeast compete for territory on the tongue. Lemon, yeast and hop finish. The parts do add up to more than the whole. A meal of a beer.
Nice golden pour with little head.  Caramel nose, with lots of hops and a bit sweet.  Taste was like a toffee bar with some hopage, quite wonderful.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2005 Batch 22
Bottle poured a murky, rusted orange-brown with absolutely no head. Close to a barleywine in aromas and flavor, being lushly caramel-malted with heady grapes and an earthy, bitter finish. Syrupy & warm with enough alcohol to make the bottle last a very long time. A much better Hair of the Dog offering than <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/hair-of-the-dog- in my opinion.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL<font size=-1>

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2005 Bottle:  Very hoppy aroma with a balanced sweetness.  Aroma reminds me of a IIPA.  Pours a dull reddish-orange with no transpareny.    Off-white head fades quickly.  Comes across as a barley wine the same way as Old Ruffian.  Im not saying it tastes like old Ruffian, but it comes across as a IIPA more than any other style.  Very sweet and malty with lots of caramel up front.  Tons of hops in the finish to balance out the sweetness.  Excellent.  A million thanks to wolhfs again.

Hazy, light golden color topped with a cramy head that just wouldnt die.  Aromas lean to the sweet side, with a bit of spice, orange, and some yeast.  Soapy mouthfeel.  Flavors are also a bit sweet, but quite complex.  Layers of fruit, corriander, yeast, and spicey hops.  Lingering finish that really makes you want more.  Very nice beer.

The aroma had dark fermented fruit, coriander, and oaky notes.  The flavor had the same w/ a slight hint of flowers.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied and creamy.  This beer poured a pale cloudy orange-ish brown color w/ thin lasting head and lacing.  Thanks Dr. Bill!

Pours an almost opaque orangey amber color.  Massive head that required multiple pours to manage.  Aroma is complex, almost Belgian-esque.  Candi sugar, fruit, and alcohol aromatics.  Nose is slightly grainy with a twinge of alcohol flavor.  This melds into a Belgiany sweetness, with a sharp floral spiciness.  The finish is fairly acrid, dominated by alcohol flavor.  Mouthfeel is very full, but fairly unidimensional from the pronouced alcohol character.  I can see why a lot of people like this, but it really isnt me.

This things been aging for about a year; theres some brown fuzz on the inside of the cap, and the sediment on the bottom has kind of chunkified. Big pffft when opening.   I was pouring very slowly, and noticed how clear the beer was  until the very end when a few of the chunkies slipped by, immediately making everything Very cloudy.  There is a general wispy-white cloudiness, but also some dark brown flecks that settle to the bottom of the glass after about five minutes.  Lets hope none of this adversely affects the beer as a whole.

On to the important stuff.  This thing has Belgian written all over it.  The aroma is yeasty and a little spicy, with some apricot showing through.  The flavor is kind of musty and dry, mouthfeel a little chalky.  The head was big and grainy when first poured, but now just lies in a thin sheet.  I think this has got to be the most opaque golden ale Ive ever had.  

But the sum of the parts is a relatively coherent, tasty whole.  Reminds me a lot of one of the abbey ales, perhaps Orval.  I like this, but was wondering what happened to the hops.  Certainly not your typical American strong ale, even if it is tasty.
